review_title: Great company, but little growth in the future
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Columbia, MD
pros: Very strong company values. We strive to do the best for our clients and provide the best service possible. Strong company values are incorporated in many aspects of daily work.
cons: Long hours especially during production. Production is monthly so the long hours are a regular occurrence. There is also a lack of direction due to the recent collaspe of the financial markets. There is no clear future for CTS and layoffs are expected in the near term. Employees have no hope for promotion or growth in the short term. Training could be better, but due to heavy production, many new employees do not get the necessary training.

review_title: A good start if you can tolerate the ups and downs.
pros: The best reasons to work at Wells Fargo is the brand name and the resume building,  There are a lot of room for lateral shifts to keep people working fresh and challenging positions, the store manager is key whether you will enjoy your job or hate it.
cons: The place is a chop house kill or be killed, somtimes I feel my ethics are tested every day from my co-workers and boss.  The starting salries are nothing to go home and cheer about.

pros: Excellent PTO and benefits package.  Variety of locations and great team members.  Strong vision and values.  Conservative bank growing their reserves.  Post merger, the company should be ready to seize market share more rapidly again.
cons: The environment is highly political.  Some management corrupt and incapable of meaningful leadership.  Team members pressured daily to meet goals that are frequently unrealistic.  The employees work like a smattering of 'rock stars' rather than a 'rock band'...not team oriented.

pros:
If in the right market, good pay for easy work.
Flexible - work from home and more or less decide your own hours
Decent benefits
cons:
Conservative lender with tight guidelines; prevents a lot of business opportunity that other lenders are happy to receive.
Pay is lower than other lenders in terms of basis points.
Operations is consistently understaffed, company does not seem to learn from past mistakes and has miscalculated the size of the market numerous times. 
The wholesale channel of business is marginalized. 
Management makes knee-jerk reactions to events and then reverts to what the competition is doing months later.

review_title: Very positive - had complex, challenging and very diverse project assignments, but with a lot of support from management
job_title: Project Manager IV in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good focus on customer satisfaction and employee recognition.  Superior benefits and compensation.  Very open approach to sharing information, listening to ideas, communicating strategic plans, etc. with all levels of staff.  Wells Fargo is a very ethically-run bank, with strong emphasis on doing business the right way for the right reason.  Great at giving back to the community and enabling employees to get involved.
cons: It's difficult to get promotions in the project management department; there tend to be very few opportunities for moving up.

review_title: I have earned many opportunities during my time at WF, but the future is dim with layoffs ever present.
pros: The people I have worked with over the years are knowledgeable and strive to reach the goals of the organization.  It's been a pleasure to learn and grow alongside some of the best and the brightest.
cons: Management decision making and regulatory pressure is pushing productivity to levels that are burning out many employees and leaving all fearing for their jobs. I've seen many layoffs and watched excellent talent leave for external opportunities.

review_title: I'm a top performer so why doesnt my pay show it?
pros: Great medical benefits and reputation also looks great on resume. professional and customer focused
cons: was a great asset to company especially in sales and customer satisfaction, exceeded goals and expectations however received same pay as other tellers, managers were not on top of sending us to classes in order to exceed and move up. sales goals and threshold raised making it even more difficult to make extra money for the end of the quarter. really pushing sales and scripting. pay is lower than other banks. worked there over a year and a half now and since I started I have only received a $1 raise.

review_title: I'm happy with the products/services we can offer, less so with the human side of the equation.
pros: One-stop shop for almost all things financial, we're not pressured into using particular products or services, we can use what we feel is best for clients.  Lots of tools and technology to get the job done.
cons: Management talks a lot about providing support to the advisors, but you're on your own in this company.  You've got the tools, but you better know how to use them.  If you can work with that, you'll get along fine.  Professional development is up to you.

review_title: Less than mediocre place to work.
pros: None that I can think of.
cons:
The absolute worst health benefits in the industry.  Also, starting PTO is very bad.  The moral is dreadful.  

In my years of service, I didn't see anyone get promoted.

pros: The term "misery loves company" comes to mind. My co-workers and I muddled through this job together. The upside of an otherwise wretched working experience was getting to connect with regular customers on a regular basis.
cons: Where do I begin? This was a greasy sales job, plain and simple. You would think I was selling a car to someone. And don't get me wrong, I've been in high pressure sales environments before - I sold art in a gallery on a commission-only basis. But that experience doesn't even hold a candle to what I experienced from the management at my branch. There is so much pressure to open accounts that no one cares where they come from - which means bankers and tellers are left to their own vices. You have to connive to survive at Wells Fargo. If you want to know what's wrong with retail banking, why no one wants to step foot inside a local branch? It's because places like Wells Fargo are rotting from the inside out.

pros:
Good Facilities, Salaries. 
All departments are good at organizing things, except the IT project management teams.
Events are conducted every quarter.
Work from home can be availed at will.
Good Infrastructure and workplace set-up.
Experience this company once, if you are bored of service industry.
cons:
HR & All Manager say, Wells Fargo India is an extension to Wells Fargo USA. They even go ahead and claim WF India as partner to WF USA.
But in reality, entire WF India is treated as a official contractor hub for WF USA. 
There is no process at work. No knowledge transitions like in service companies, when a new member joins etc.,
Not for onsite-seekers.

pros: Abundant PTO. Job Security. Recognition for a job well done. Decent pay after a certain point. Infinite room for growth if you try and plenty of locations to choose from.
cons: No work/life balance: If you are FT you will be here every minute of 40 hours and possibly more; managers always expect you to cut lunches or come in early/stay late and if you don't, you will be scorned for it. There seems to be no labor to account for so if it is slow you Now check credit reports for almost any position other than teller, will not hire/promote if there is ANYTHING negative on your report. There is NO CONSISTENCY in anything: if you call another LOB for help, you will receive 20 different answers with no conclusion.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Denver, CO
pros: No come to mind. The training is well funded but short on delivery and constantly "Required," especially when you're really busy trying to make money and don't have time to do the same trainings over and over. Don't get sucked in by their BS - you'll regret it!
cons: No loyalty to their employees. You're just a number and can be, and will be, replaced tomorrow with another insignificant person. The people who somehow remain there for any real period of time, say 5 years plus, are wore torn and battle scarred. They have seen many, many nice, intelligent, good people stabbed in their back and fired or forced to resign by Wells Fargo for no good reason other than, "I don't know, the decision came from high up, too high up to contact anyone there, and there is nothing we can do about it..."

review_title: Providing outstanding customer service 100% of the time and turning service into sales.
pros: I love that there is so much room for growth, Wells Fargo have over 80 lines of business so you can always find something of interest.  Recognition is very important to Wells Fargo and you are consistently reminded of the great work you are doing. Competitive pay compared to other financial institutions.
cons: Sales goals are very hard to reach and the pressure to get sales is very strong. The customer service that we provide is always improving and the stress of providing that excellent service can be damaging to how you feel about the work place. Almost always have to use a scripted sales pitch, sounding robotic.

review_title: Systemic Management Issues but Great Benefits
pros: Depending on what position you have (I was in product management) there is a lot of autonomy. The benefits are great,  the PTO is good. Ability to work from home one day a week (non-branch role).  Promote volunteerism. You have the opportunity to change roles.
cons: The culture changed dramatically in the last 8 years and especially after the merger with Wachovia.  There was very little training which surprised me given it is such a huge company.  Hard work does not seem to be appreciated and acknowledged by managers.  The compensation can be good but the merit increases are 2%, if you are lucky, so negotiate well going in.

review_title: Great place to get your feet wet...
job_title: Teller At Wells Fargo in Annandale, VA
pros: At the time, management was going thru some difficult times, specially since the branch was lacking sales and upper management was being replaced too fast too often. However, while there, the  branch Manager was well educated, smart, but a bit cocky. Teller Supervisor, great person to work with and for. Stuck his head out for most if not all, great mentor, not enough recognition given to him.
cons: It's a bank. You are a teller. Either you sell it or you don't.

job_title: Portfolio Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Everyone is a salesman so you learn entrepreneurial skills. A lot of teaming.  Company roots are good so even if the beast has grown is unmanageable ways I think there are still some good people trying to do the right thing...the jury is out.
cons: Bulging middle management fearful of being found incompetent so try to show their worth by pointing fingers or managing up, not good for clients or subordinates. Company so large it feels like it is having a hard time finding its way so direction and policy often seem disjointed and fluid leaving one wondering "who is in charge and what are they drinking?"

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker II in Alexandria, VA
pros: Salary is good  but that is about it.
cons:
Super micro-managing of daily activities. No room for work flexibility, a hassle to take your vacation and or sick time. Encouragement of terrible managers who advise unethical behavior. Senior management does not seem to care about employee retention or about creating a supportive and encouraging culture for employees. 
I would not recommend friend unless you are in dire need of a job. It is honestly one of the worst places I have ever worked.

pros:
I was hired as BA by support group to write text scripts & perform QA for software release, gather info and update process documentation.  Lower level personnel are knowledgeable and were very willing to assist.  The ones I came into contact with definitely cared and took ownership of their job responsibilities.  I learned a lot and appreciated the opportunity.

If you're into the party scene this is a place for you - there seemed to be a birthday, wedding, baby shower, anniversary, or work accomplishments party every week...
cons: Slow to make / implement even simple decisions.  Normal for large companies but coming from a small company environment this led to delays wish can be frustrating to all.

pros: Theres only one way to go from here, up.  There are some good people who work there, but there is an informal deal that everyone has the opportunity to make in order to advance and get taken care of.  Sell yourself out and compromise your values and sanity or don't, and if you don't, don't expect raises or promotions or even courteous treatment from upper management.
cons: Almost everything.  Get paid little for high stress.  Expect to buy into cheesy, transparent culture/propaganda if you want to stick around.

pros: Have access to our fulfillment partners.  Our processors and underwriters are in the same building, and in my case just a cubicle row over.  We are paid on units with a tier system per month.  Not bpps.  Obviously the more loans your close, the more you make.  With added bonuses for loyal surveys, and audits, you can add another 40% to your base amounts from your loans as well as getting an hourly pay .
cons: The compliance issues of what you say, and how you say it are crazy.  It seems that sometimes if you breathe wrong, you may be out of compliance and be in the office for counseling.  Very strict underwriting guidelines.  It seems underwriters are looking for reasons to decline loans instead of finding workarounds to help borrowers get into homes.

pros:
No work, full family time simply nodd head and go with flow
If you are from Hyderabad and Tamil Nadu a good company to play politics and sit and slop with no career growth.

Hot skill bonus trap <  career growth and real projects 

Most of the people have side business as you will get enough time in the life balance
cons:
Pathetic company to join as a  no vision / no value / spineless management 

If you respect your career don't join, it will ruin and all experience you gather is waste as most of the time is no work, or mostly below  average  maintenance work
 If you are good, you will be bored to death either Java / .net  / UI 

All so called dev even if little bit is happening onshore just have to blindly follow orders even from  Tamil or Telugu folks with no  clue about technology

Wells Fargo India Bangalore and Hyderabad  is a joke

job_title: Food Service Manager in Tampa, FL
pros:
Personally I liked Wells Fargo because I opened an account with  Wells Fargo in in 2016 when  I was in Scranton Pennsylvania and because bank of America was not there any more I need it to have account in a bank for my direct deposit than I opened  one with Wells Fargo .
Now I do have two accounts with Wells Fargo because I do like the way they do business and their banking services also is very good
cons: the only one thing I did not use with my accounts with Wells Fargo is pay my bills online I do not like  the way it locks me out  in couples of times and I did keep my account with bank of America for that reason and because banked with them since 2006.

job_title: Customer Care Representative/Operations Analyst/Operations Processor in Mississauga, ON
pros:
- Good work/life balance, you're able to work from home after one year of employment 
- Good benefits 
- Great culture 
- Amazing diversity, you get to work with a diverse group of smart individuals
cons:
- Limited growth opportunities, you basically would have to seek other companies if you want an advancement (varies by department) 
- Favouritism 
- Bullying from a different Department (Belittling One's work, causing loss of confidence) 
- Limited resources to perform day-to-day job functions. There wasn't a clear sense of direction  on what the business was expecting

review_title: Company in need of culture change
pros: As someone who has worked for the company 10+ years there are many great things to say. The benefits are great and the people make it a joy to come to work each day. If you are looking for career advancement the opportunities are there. So many different lines of business to learn and grow your skill set.
cons: Senior management makes it hard to do your job effectively as a manager. The culture of the company has turned into one that does not care about its employees. The hard work that you put in day in day out goes overlooked. For career advancement senior managers hire who they want not based on the most qualified candidate. If I was not for the people doing your job would be unbearable.  You are over loaded and the pay does not compensate.

job_title: Project Analyst in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Got to use the newest technology (e.g. piloting MS Office 2007 sooner than many places). IT projects were almost necessarily large-scale, because of the number of employees.
cons: Unethical behavior and bullying was tolerated. I personally had a good manager who kept his committments, but others in the department weren't so lucky. Several affairs going on, some of which were a conflict of interest. Zero opportunity for advancement, improvement, or recognition of a job well done or skills developed. Of all the places I've worked, Wells Fargo had the worst interdepartmental cooperation, and fewest mechanisms for sharing data, information, and best practices.

pros: A fairly stable and reliable job until the recent market changes took place.  You can receive overtime in many of the positions.  Great learning evironment with up to date systems.  Many friendly young people to work with.
cons: Expectations can be beyond reasonable in terms of hours per day and work load.  In many cases there is a lack of concern.  Can be difficult to get ahead in certain groups and under certain managers.  Appears to be some reverse discrimination taking place in some groups.  The over all group hiring strategy was to take advantage of recent college graduates.  They would pay the minimum and expect the world.

review_title: There's lots of good and more than a little bit of "meh"
pros:
-Great benefits and good pay
-Expected to work independently - fulltime tellecommuting for some
-Nothing but positive reviews from my managers
-Education opportunities are provided in-house and there is a variety of classes
-Some real sharp and helpful coworkers
cons:
-Neglected by management (I like being independent and alone but so much so I wonder if I matter or if I'm missing the party)
-Taken for granted if you do a good job (attention is paid more to day to day problems)
-The expensive training you really want and need just isn't going to happen
-Some dull implements in the coworker drawer also

review_title: Not the company I joined anymore
pros:
Flexibility to work from home
Great people
Training classes available online or external
cons:
Lots of managers lack integrity/very political. Most managers actions do not match their words!
Management doesn't seem to care as much about retaining their best people or providing a career path. Starting to hear about people leaving which is not a surprise since due to the merger and working hard for the past 3,years people are burnt out and don't feel appreciated.
No ability to move up in the organization.
Raises are pathetic considering how successful the bank is
Culture has changed since the Wachovia /wellsfargo merger and not for the better.
Big company bureaucracy/hard to get things done. 
Although we are told we are empowered - that is not reality.

pros: Benefits are great.  Have met some great people - coworkers and customers.  Diverse company that wants to value its people. People are competive advantage is one of their catch phrases.
cons: Sometimes the sales focus is so aggressive the customer is not the priority.  Worked for Wells in another city and it was so different than in Houston.  There is a definite disconnect between upper management and what goes on in the locations. Also scheduling - sometimes do not receive until day before!

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Des Moines, IA
pros: PTO, job allows you to work independently. Creates a sense of independence working on the job. B enefits are good but I would look closely over medical coverage. You should be able to find that cheaper.
cons: Management does not know direction of company. Leaders do not lead, they simply follow instructions. Company lacks integrity and respect for it's employees. Ideas are not shared throughout department, only senior managers and directions make decisions. Company violates basic ethics principles which the company states is one of it's values. Very misleading, the direction of the company is clearly geared towards top management and not towards the actual employees who make the company what it is.

pros: Banking is a business with a lot of room for advancement, if you are willing to relocate in order to get behind the senses.  Wachovia had some issues but Wells Fargo ???
cons: Wells Fargo is a very negative company to work for.  They treat their employees like children. The ethics sound good on paper but I saw a lot of unethical behavior. Part of this I think is due to the high (near impossible to maintain) goals they set for their employees as far as sells goals. Turnover is extremely high at the branch level. When they took over Wachovia we were told by people that worked for them that they churn and burn employees and that has proven to be the case.  They told us no one would lose their job due to the take over but if me did not make our numbers all bets were off.  Goals (numbers) were set so high that ethics went out the window.

review_title: Demanding, but really value their employees
pros: There are many opportunities for growth within the company and supervisors are very career and skill development oriented. The benefits better and more affordable than to be expected. There are many ways to get involved in the company and give back to the community.
cons: In the consumer area, there are very demanding sales goals that are often emphasized more than customer service, which seems contrary to company values. You have to be in your current position for quite a while before you can move within (6 months within departments, 1 year out of department) the company, so it had better be a good fit.

pros: the provide a great corporate working environment for entry level positions, and even promotion from within.  The working Culture is not the same across the company, as the experience on the west coast inside Wells Fargo is very different then that of the east coast.
cons: This organization here in the southeast is very must about who you know and not how you perform.   Of course one must perform at any level to maintain employment, but even top performing employees as not always recognized and promote into open positions.

job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Shoreview, MN
pros: It's a call center position, so you don't have to spend money on clothes. Next year bonuses will be monthly but we don't know the changes in criteria, yet, so it may or may not be a positive change but I'm hopeful it'll be good.
cons: Sales criteria to receive bonus has too many variables that you have no control over, one example is surveys have to be all 5's or its considered a zero customer satisfaction survey, most customers do not know this and it's a way to be knocked out of bonus.

job_title: Client Service Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Wells Fargo is an excellent company and, given the size of the organization, does an outstanding job of taking care of its employees at all levels.  Excellent opportunities for career advancement within and amongst the different businesses and great support for continuing education.
cons: As large a company as WF is, it is easy to get lost in the crowd if you do not go out of your way to network and connect, especially between business units.  They do offer many opportunities and programs to help people overcome this, but if you are not willing to put in the time and effort, it may seem overwhelming to move up.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Fountain Valley, CA
pros: Decent work-life balance but there are times where you will need to stay late to meet end of quarter numbers and Saturdays.
cons: Contradictory goals however because they both preach great customer service but want you to push all kinds of products towards customers even if it's not good for them.  Too aggressive with sales goals.  Poor compensation for Bankers if you only 'meet' your goals.  The good compensation is very difficult to meet.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Madison, WI
pros: Individual success is just as important as team or regional successes. Lots of opportunity to grow and move up the ladder. Can be at your own pace. Also great 401k and some great fringe benefits.
cons: Health care for families is expensive and does not come close to covering my families' needs. Forced to use public assistance. Also salaries could be much better.

review_title: If sales are your thing, this is the place for you.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits such as 6% 401(k) contribution match after a year, awesome Wellness Program that hands out free money for completing health tasks. Depending on the branch and who you work with, it can be passable.
cons: The emphasis on sales is insane. I've seen people fired or forced out for not hitting their goals for two weeks. I can honestly say that as far as bankers go, no one seemed to want to be there and most were actively looking for other opportunities. The way the branch's customer service is graded is just a joke, since it's done as a team effort. Why should everyone suffer when someone else dropped the ball? They also expect perfection from their anonymous surveys.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: If you want to get a first job and want to get ulcers to make your life more interesting and surround yourself by self-center individuals and clueless managers then this is the place for you. To be fair, they do provide tuition reimbursement and other good benefits.
cons: Sales pressures are immense. Poor vision and values, total disregard of the actual needs of the customer. High turnover rates at the local branches. Highly political and unethical. I personally witnessed unauthorized credit applications bankers did to make their quotas and were protected by managers who also needed those numbers, I saw bankers open bank accounts for fake customers or customers who had even left the country years ago. If you do what is actually right for the customer you need to find a new job.

review_title: It's got its good and bads
pros: Bank hours. Only thing is now that is extended to 7:30a-6:00p (which often can turn into 6:30 or 7) and Saturdays 9-2. Very straightforward with what they want from you here. Job itself is easy :)
cons: Low pay, and the bonus they tell you about is pretty much nonexistent, after taxes as a teller. (Gets much better within the banker role) Maybe a couple hundred dollars every 3 months. Very strict on outages- stay in balance. period. Personally, I had had different experiences being at two different branches- one very laid back (slower store), but the other was very high pressure and even though they say you start with 3 weeks of PTO, that store then told us that we were not allowed to use that PTO on Fridays or Saturdays because it was too busy.

pros:
Almost 4 weeks of PTO
Overtime
Usually one year to wait to go for next tier of job
Healthcare is ok
Nice enough people
cons:
PTO is considered both for vacation and sick time
If you quit, you owe what you haven't accrued. Basic sense when you see it but they don't tell you until you quit.
When it's usually one year for next tier , I mean usually. Some of the people I've worked with had to wait for a couple years to move up because management said the person didn't qualify yet for skills even though he person was a top performing team member with awards to prove it

pros: Benefits, convenient locations, compensation pay
cons: No work life balance! Vacation time consistently declined. You have to take time off when senior leadership wants you to take it even though they take time off whenever they want.  Too much pressure now since switching to unannounced audits since employees were trained to sell and pretty much not required to know anything else prior. 0 training and 0 support from senior leadership. They do not know what we go through on a daily basis and basically tell you to do the job or get written up or terminated. Employees are unengaged and under too much pressure because of bad decisions the bank has made.

pros: I have been working with Wells Fargo while attending college and I couldn't ask for a better place to work as a student. Great experiences, room to grow, and you truly feel like your team members care. My managers encourage my growth, I have a great supporting team that value my work. As a student, the pay is above means and work with management to create your schedule so that you could attend school as well. Working 20 hours with benefits and 401K plus holidays, what more could you ask for!
cons: Scheduling is pretty set so, depending on where you work or who you work with, you may need to compromise with how your work and school life balance would work.

review_title: Good place to work but medical benefits and leadership are not the best
pros:
Overall good environment 
Good overall benefits 
Focused on developing employees
Offer some telecommuting depending on mgr
cons:
Managers have no clue what they’re doing 
No accountability for management and up
Lay offs due to recent issues 
You’re just a number to HR 
Workload does not allow for development
Medical benefits are high deductible plans

review_title: Wells Fargo - big, but it will be around
job_title: Marketing Data Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work-life balance is good, support for employees is good, benefits are decent.  The bank is large, but reasonably well run and conservative, so it will be around for the long haul.  It's not going to be the fastest moving, but that is part of it's stability.  The people are generally good adn the company does seem to value them more than other companies.
cons: very large and bureacratic.  Compliance issues are a huge headache right now, and if you are reasonably innovative, you will be frustrated many times in trying to implement your ideas.  There are not immediate consequences for incompetence or failure.

review_title: High Sales and Customer Service Goal and not a very rewarding pay. Overall great benefits!
pros:
Great Benefits.
Great Opportunity for advancement.
Many branches in the West Coast and moving Eastward.
cons:
Culture of branches is just downright wrong in terms of sales goals
Many employees may game the system to achieve goals.
Ridiculous current requirement for service and high pressure from management.
High turnover

job_title: Loan Servicing Sp in Des Moines, IA
pros: great benefits, stable company that i believe works hard to do business in a fair and honest way. def a place you can be proud to work.
cons: large number of employees makes it easy to feel as if u are just a number and that upper management doesnt care about you as a person. you are simply a body at a desk and everything is driving around producitivity and the tracking of it.

review_title: Great Benefits, not worth the stress.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Sauk Rapids, MN
pros:
Great training
Fantastic benefits
Hardworking colleagues
Exponential advancement opportunities (if you meet your sales goal every quarter)
Customers are wonderful to work for
cons: Sales is the only thing that matters. There is no respect for family and private life. You'll get called in early, stay late and texted by your managers continually. If your store isn't making its sales goal you'll be punished and micromanaged to the nth degree. Turnover is very high, so it's difficult to gain continuity with your team. There can be a lot of gaming and unethical behavior that goes unpunished because the sales goals are so high. If you're honest, your goals will be very difficult reach.

review_title: Look at other options if your in the financial field.
pros: It's a job in these hard times, and not much more.
cons: Goals are so out reach it's not even funny , from the store manager right down to the tellers. Very hard company to work for without getting written up, and I've been doing this for 20yrs., so I know a little. Also any given time in Fl., there's literally hundreds of openings because experienced  employee's are fleeing to the other banks to work for. Suntrust is soaking up all the experience employee's faster than you know.

pros: Wells Fargo is a huge company. More business lines than you can count with all your fingers and toes. There is a lot of opportunity for advancement. benefits and pay are competitive
cons:
Well, Wells Fargo is a huge company. Change can be a cumbersome process and the corporate double-think one might expect from a company with over 200 thousand employees does rear it's head from time to time. 

The biggest "Con" is the industry its self can be volatile. entire teams, or even departments can disappear at the whims of the market.

job_title: Payroll Account Manager in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Good benefits and PTO policy with most banking holidays off. Company website is informative. Free checking and savings accounts with Wells Fargo.
cons: Unorganized and very inexperienced managers. Payroll is too much of a new product that they are behind leading providers such as ADP and Paychex. Trainging is horrible as upper management tries to push new employees to take calls they are not prepared for. Extremely high turn around due to low morale and inconsistency between managers and employees. Pay is not level with other account managers at competing payroll providers. Worst department I have ever worked for at Wells Fargo.

review_title: Opportunities to advance exist once you get in the door
pros:
Decent Pay and Benefits
Good Work/Life Balance
Opportunity to move around once you are hired and have completed a year of service
Opportunity to use skills and education
Managers and subordinates work together on initiatives
cons:
Your experience will depend, to some extent, on your group.  The cultures vary among groups, with some being more collaborative than others, and others showing more favoritism and office politics.  

As I mentioned in the pros section, there is opportunity to move around once you have been onboard for a year, so if you feel as if you aren't being challenged or don't fit in with your group, there are other opportunities that may be a better fit.

review_title: I am a personal banker at a branch location
pros: Good hours, most weekends off, many avenues for career advancement
cons: Incredibly boring if you are in a slow location.  Sales goals are not adjusted according to the volume of your branch.  If you work in a slow branch it can be especially challenging to hit your goals.  Conversely, if you work in a busy branch it can be especially easy regardless of your skill level.  Bonuses are also minimal even though you are asked to do a lot of extracurricular sales in order to achieve your numbers.

pros: Great culture if you find the right team. Managers work with you to help expand your career and skills. This again is dependent upon finding the right team, so be sure to ask detailed questions during the interview to get a sense off team dynamics. People in senior positions are quite down to earth, approachable, and happy to talk with everyone.
cons: Sometimes, because the organization is so large, you can feel like you are lost in the sauce. Perhaps if there was a way to roll-up your accomplishments and share with the broader portfolio. This would help additional people to understand your accomplishments.

pros: Benefits are great 401K is awesome and you meet some great friends along the way, those were the only Pros for me and I have been with the Company for 7 years total.
cons: I started out as an Wachovia Employee the changes over the years were not the best. The opportunity for growth is limited I ended my career in Dealer Services with the bank. I have my MBA and I made less than all the people in my department that had just started with the company. Management needs more leadership training, my manager told me having a MBA doesn't mean anything I then knew it was time for me to leave. You work really hard for horrible pay.

job_title: Lead Teller in Fort Myers, FL
pros: I love my team. There's so much motivation, encouragement and recognition daily. They push you to reach the next level and coach you to be the person you want to be.If you work at a branch that's closed on Saturdays, you're in luck. Considerate amount of paid time off (80 hours per year after the first year).
cons: Too much micromanaging. A lot of pressure to sell from managers makes it uncomfortable. Other team members not sharing a workload. Overtime is not tolerated anymore, ever, and it creates a lot of stress when leaving at the end of the day.

review_title: Dont expect a raise or a review
pros: Wells Fargo name is a household name. There is your PROs.
cons:
Be prepared to be sitting in one position for awhile. When reviews come around, you may or may not get one. Your raise (if anything) has already been pre determined. I am not even sure it has anything to do with your performance. Matter of fact, i know it doesn't. Basically it doesn't pay to work your butt off. You will not get rewarded for it.
It seems like managers and supervisors are only in their position because they have been with the company for awhile and the only way to give them a raise is to add another title and duties to their current work load. 
Time to look for a new JOB!

review_title: Technology Environment in a Large Company
job_title: Business Systems Consultant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Working in technology in a large company ensures decent funding of important initiatives, while ensuring that change is embraced because it is the latest or greatest, but because it is the correct fit.
cons: Major changes are not embraced or funded in an agile manner. Versions and hardware are often a year or more out of date. For example, new project requests started today will not be funded or started for at least 18 months. Corporate wide technology advances can take even longer.

review_title: Happy with the various opportunities presented
pros: Strong company values, excellent PTO, bank holidays, 401k that matches up to certain %after first year, room to grow if you are in the stores, fair pay. You can start as a teller and grow to be a recruiter, a financial advisor, a district manager... You choose your destiny.
cons: Once you reach a certain level (out of the stores) it's more and more difficult to promote. Managers don't always discovers career plans with individuals. Work life balance is not always there. As a recruiter your position is stressful. Turnover is increasing as people leave for more money and less hours... Team members in stores are not loyal to company.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Charleston, SC
pros: If you CAN sell, you will be well compensated, and move up quickly to upper level position, the sky is your limit, as there's no degree requirement for ANY position. Not even a drug test before hiring:(  Management will kiss your butt, even when you have customer complaints against you.
cons: You can be at your best  in your assigned duties, have the best attitude and excellent public relations... it means nothing to management if you can't sell.  The Bank is referred to as a Store.  Their logo should be Wells Fargo Sales & CO. They DO NOT DRUG SCREEN.

review_title: It has its ups and downs.
pros: Great communication, training, and benefits.  Off Sundays and holidays.
cons: Lots of selling.  Promotions based on numbers.  Pays the same as retail with 10x the amount of work.  Can get fired easily.  It's hard to like a place when everyone talks bad about it.  I know a teller that's worked there for 5 years with no hope of advancement because she doesn't get enough people to open accounts and credit cards.

pros: 401K- match up to 6%, that’s one good thing.
cons:
I would strongly recommend no one working for Wells Fargo.  To sum it up: constant chaos, process and procedures changes every time you turn around, low morale, poor management, poor raises, and the list could go on.  This place was so bad, every time you look outside there was an ambulance.  That should tell you something when people are having heart attacks and blood pressure problems.  “Where is so and so?”  “Oh, they’re on short term disability for a stress related illness.”
 This place is so bad, people just quit without a job to go to.  How crazy is that?
The benefits suck- HSA or HRA.  No PPO or HMO.  Comprehensive, really?  Competitive in what way.

pros: Geographically Wells Fargo is everywhere so you have opportunity to relocate. Overall the company is solid financially so you don't have to worry about them going under.
cons: If you have the right skin color or gender you will go right to the front of the line for career advancement at Wells Fargo. They are very open about their desire to preferentially promote minorities and women. I'm not saying this is a bad thing but if you are a white male you are swimming against a STRONG current at this company.

pros: Excellent benefits, decent pay, and great opportunities for advancement. Your experience with Wells Fargo, as with any job, heavily depends on the managers you work under. I've had great managers and really enjoyed my job with Wells and I've had horrible managers and really disliked my job with Wells.
cons: The aggressive sales goals were definitely a con but the company has done a lot to rectify that and now the sales goals are extremely reasonable and all of the practices surrounding sales are very ethical. I think the company has done a good job of correcting their mistake.

job_title: Service Manager in Maple Grove, MN
pros: The road map is gone, allowing you to be more personable with customers. Great 401k match up to 6%. Time off is decent as well.
cons: Wells Fargo says they are all about inclusion & diversity but yet your appearance needs to match the “community”.  There is absolutely no work/life balance. I open the branch and typically close the branch minimum 3 days a week. Hard to be in management if you have kids. Customers are allowed to disrespect us. If you ask me Wells is afraid of another lawsuit. Observations are back, if feels like we are slowly going back to the old days when management was down our back.

review_title: No room for advancement in the military department
job_title: Premier Military Banker Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: I was able to train the new bankers and ensure they were given the proper material and access to systems they needed for success.
cons: There were quite a few lawsuits going on with people opening unauthorized  accounts which we had to try to defuse their anger and mistrust. Also when training full classes there was no compensation or pay increase as the trainers are paid quite a bit more than bankers.  There was no appreciation from upper management for fixing a situation that they had caused.

review_title: numbers are important but the people who are making the numbers are also very important
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
great learning environment, company will send you out to license if you express interest.

you learn a lot about finance, good life skills.
cons:
the management.

also, seniority in my branch kind of means you can basically do whatever you want and management would not care. Except if you do anything illegal or show any dishonesty in business, obviously.

review_title: Wells Fargo a great company, but not always great management.
job_title: Registered Personal Banker in St. George, UT
pros: The company is solid.  It is the only AAA rate bank in the Nation and only one of two in the world, the other being the bank of Scotland.  I scored neutral in compensation for my particular situation I feel I am undervalued and underpaid.  However the benefits package on a whole is one of the best I've seen out there.
cons: The sales goals are extremely intense.  Working for Wells Fargo in not a job for the easily stressed.

pros: Wells Fargo is a stable company, with good benefits.  They seem to make sound business decisions and take on less risk than our competitors.  This has served us well this year as several banks have either failed or had to be bought out by someone else.
cons: We are always changing to keep with the market place which is a good thing to help us stay competitive but the downside is when these changes are not well thought out before being implemented it creates a negative team member and customer experience.

pros: Wells Fargo Financial is a good place to work if you're good at sales.  There's a lot of opportunity to make bonus, a successful person can make 40k+ right out of college.  You can set your own schedule to some extent as long as you are working 40 hours and booking business, so it's great for people who need to leave early or arrive late sometimes.
cons: I don't like making cold calls to people in order to sell them a loan.  Some people are really nasty on the phones and you need to have thick skin to be successful here.

review_title: It  provided a good opportunity for career growth for those interested in putting in theextra time and actively pursuing
pros: WF offers a variety of business's to be involved in and grow your career.   It is a solid, large and respectable company in Minneapolis metro area.
cons: The merger with Wachovia has change the dynamics of WF in Minneapolis.  Decision making is further removed and much more bureaucracy to get things done.

review_title: Rewarding during a difficult time in the finance world
job_title: Business Systems Consultant Manager in Chester, PA
pros: When a lot of finance companies took large losses and found "good" accounts go bad during the credit crunch Wells Fargo as a whole was almost unaffected by it's conservative lending style.  Godd for the parent Wells Fargo but Auto Finance had pricing issues that went back years and when they surfaced at the same time as the creidt crunch and we saw more loans move into collecting they had a very difficult time.  Overhauls at the top and in credit risk and collections risk were swift an thorough.
cons: A bit slow to change because of their size but then again they're conversative and that served them well in the worst economy in recent memory.

review_title: Respectable place to work, if you are not presured to sell sell sell.
pros: hours are flexable, pay comparison is okay, very respectable work, the good felling you get when you put people needs first.
cons: very sales driven, which causes bankers to sell sell sell and forget about the customer needs.  Too much churning of checking accounts.  Compay is so concerned with selling checking accounts that when you open IRA, or Loans, the first reaction is "so what !  now  get me checking accounts"  Good place for you to make money, bad place for consumers to shop.

review_title: Loved working for them at first, not now.
pros:
Unlimited advancement opportunities if you are willing to bend the rules
Decent vacation/time off policies
Multiple locations for a short commute
cons:
Health care benefits for 2012 are terrible
Company uses employees as pawns for political agenda
Management work load is incredible because staffing is being reduced

pros: decent money and steady work. No layoffs and constant fear like with other jobs out there. easy work for the most part.
cons: I like the job but the sales pressure is definitely strong. Alot of changes to the work environment, including frequent desk changes, what manager you report to and what co-workers you sit near.  You really can't do this too long and not  feel burned out.I also feel like my manager doesnt like me but for no reason. It's also repetitive having to repeat the same thing to a bunch of people in a row, you begin to unintentionally get short. And a good deal of the time you get treated and talked to like sh!t by the customers. BUT i wear whatever i want and sleep in every day.

review_title: Under paid, under valued, and so over them.
job_title: Operations Specialist II in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The environment is very laid back. They give you your PTO immediately and are pretty lenient with how they let you use it.
cons: The pay is slave like. How in the world do they expect working adults to live off of $30,000 a year? Then they want you to dress in business professional for the environment. I despised working for this company because as much profit as they make, they continue to run a sweat shop underpaying back office workers slave wages.

pros: Company is one of the most stable banks so employment is pretty much assured as long as you don't break any rules.  Paid Time Off is generous, up to 25 days paid time off for 5 year employees. 401(k) 6% match.  Easy hours, typical 9-5 job, most branches open on weekends.
cons: Most managers know or understand very little how to use the internal systems or how to lead.  They translate asking for more from you as leading.  The position is considered a sales position to your manager not a position where your sole goal is to help clients succeed financially or to lead staff.

review_title: Great managers and projects, but the time investment is unrealistic.
pros: Great managers that allow you to have some freedom during your work day. Taking PTO is a simple and painless process. Salary is competitive and worth the long hours if needed.
cons: I have been working on a project for another team the past month with unrealistic deadlines and a lot of overtime. I've worked weekends and barely get to see my family. This is just a short term thing, but it can cause a huge amount of stress and give you the feeling of not wanting to go to work in the morning.

review_title: Wells Fargo has a lot to offer as far as pay and benefits, but can take a toll on employees with some of their goals.
pros: Wells Fargo has great pay and also great benefits. They are a larger company so if need be you can transfer to another branch.
cons: They put a lot of stress on their employees with what they call wow! Wow is basically customer surveys. While it's good to have amazing customer service sometimes there are some unrealistic expectation that if they aren't met you are punished for. The surveys range from 1-5, 1 being extremely dissatisfied and 5 being the best. If the employees don't receive all 5's, they can be written up. They also have similar sales goals.

review_title: Service Manager 8 years with the bank
pros: Opportunity for advancement is there, people I worked with were wonderful, store manager was fantastic, great vacation time
cons: Upper management is terrible.  Too much micro managing .. They say they care about the customer but not true .. Unattainable goals for quarterly incentives that are not great .., long hours if you are an exempt employee .. Worked 50 hours a week with no overtime pay

pros: Management is fairly hands off  and easy to get along with.  Excellent product depth for the mortgage piece of the business.  When you start there is a lot of training and support, especially with leads that are funneled your way so it is much easier to build the pipeline.  Good culture  and if you have a good bank store things will work out well.
cons: There tends to be favoritism amongst management as to who get what bank stores and quality leads.  Processing is often only as good as the processor so if you are not on top of things and even if you are things get missed, delays happen and relationships damaged.  Very little room for moving vertically into other areas of the bank mortgage tends to be a silo.

pros:
If you have had previous customer service experience, it isn't hard to get the quarterly bonus that they give out.  This is up to about $900 at the max and is based on customer survey.  
They also give monthly bonuses based on cross selling.
cons: Job security is based on how much you cross sell, but there are so many restrictions on how you can sell to the customer it makes it a little difficult. You are also dependent on the customer to say yes they want your product, which makes job security a little bit out of your control.  Also, not really a good position for someone that doesn't like micromanagement.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Warner Robins, GA
pros: The compensation plan was pretty amazing. The personal banker had a great base salary in an area where cost of living is low.
cons: The incentive plan was extremely difficult to get paid out (especially at the higher levels. The management team is terrible. District manager was very micromanaging and required conference calls multiple times throughout the day (despite the traffic in the branches). When we were without a store manager for months, as a personal banker, I had to step up and partake in all of these conference calls without the additional pay or credit (and it affected my bonuses severely).

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Seattle, WA
pros: This is a great place to work as a mortgage banker, especially if you are just getting started in the business.  WF provides you with training opportunities, leads, and referral sources.  If you are willing to put in the work, you can make good money at this job and not have to scramble to find business.
cons: Our reputation with local realtors is somewhat tarnished because of the extensive underwriting guidelines and long turnaround times.

pros: Employer 401k contributions and matching program. There are some genuine people within the organization that make coming into the office easier. With certain positions you are able to work remotely if needed to finish work or assigned tasks.
cons: PTO is combined with sick days. Compensation is a joke. I work primarily with sales consultants and most treat you as number rather than an individual. Workload to employee ratio is ridiculous. Constantly working overtime however,  not compensated for it. Overtime is treated as an expectation rather than a personal choice. Wells Fargo doesn't seem to value their employees or give them a healthy work to home life balance.

pros: Networking, benefits, and growth opportunities are great. You meet amazing people along the way. If you play your cards right and build a solid relationship with your manager and district manager they will help you get promoted quicker.
cons: Inconsistency in promotions. Although there's always opportunies to get promoted within the company - it depends on how your district manager handles the district and the promotions. Some districts will have no problem promoting someone in less than a year or six months even if they lack the skills for the next step. Other district managers won't approve your promotions for 3 years even though you're performing or over-performing and also loyal.

pros: Pretty good pay, and amazing benefits that make me feel safe in life - 401k match, dental, vision, life, disability and medical insurance, stock purchase plan, employee assistance and condition management programs, paid volunteer and pto days from the start, tuition reimbursement, discounts on many things like wireless services with Verizon, AT&T, etc. etc. Development and career planning is also great - many helpful resources! Love working for WF, and so happy to be a part of the team!
cons: In the branches the entire experience depends on the management you are working with (like most jobs I suppose). I've had both, but the good thing about corporations is that terrible people don't typically last too long.

review_title: Good, the Bad and the Ugly
pros: They have an experienced and knowledgeable team so it's a great place to learn the ropes.  If you work hard and pick things up quickly you are acknowledged for it and recognized by promotions.
cons: Have to use multiple antiquated systems to access necessary information to do your job. When learning a new job there is zero work/life balance. Tons of unnecessary bank regulation trainings that have nothing to do with your job.  Pay is sub-par for the area and the amount of work and hours you put in.

review_title: Good Benefits, Lots of Red Tape
job_title: Personal Banker in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Great benefits package
Consistent hours
Generous Paid time off
Like to promote from within
cons:
Working with other departments is a hassle and not dependable.
Policies often change without notice which can cause problems for you and clients and you are often thrown under the bus for mistakes outside of your control.
If you have a coworker who is terrible it takes a loooong time for HR to approve termination.
Systems are often outdated and software is released too soon resulting in outages often.
Almost toxic “Customer is ALWAYS right” mentality

review_title: Executive Assistant to EVP and SVP
job_title: Executive Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits, personal banking services w/out fees; changes in management from the top down are starting to take place.
cons: Salaries are low not at par with industry standards or cost of living standards; barely a raise 1-2%; yr sometimes "0"; no bonuses, discourage to pay OT yet demand work to be done; retaliation towards team members who 'raise their hand'.

pros:
Fairness:
- Salary equality. Smart compensation system is based primarily on job responsibilities and geolocation.
- Ample opportunities for lateral and upward career advancement.
- Open support for gender equality. Met many other women and LGBT people who felt supported by the company and loved their jobs. 
- Excellent benefits.
- Making an honest effort to innovate and improve.
- Truly diverse (intellectually and ethnically) global workforce.
cons:
- Some old, ineffective corporate structures remain.
- Large company, which means that certain policies are not applied uniformly, even if upper management makes an honest effort. 
- Should do more to prevent the types of fraud that came to light in recent years.

review_title: A great place to work with good people and smart leadership.
pros: Wells Fargo has weathered the recent Mortgage crises because the company has employed a conservative business model.  That translates to higher stability for the company and it's employees.   Wells Fargo also has favorable benefits (e.g. 100% 401K match on up to 6% of salary) compared to similar positions in similar companies.  I've been with the company for 10+ years and have had the opportunity to work on a number of interesting projects.  It can be stressful at times but I have never been bored.  I've had several co-workers who have left the company to take positions with other companies and everyone of them later regretted their decisions.
cons: The company is very large and has become increasingly bureaucratic.

review_title: Best of class company in financial services
job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Sacramento, CA
pros: stability in uncertain times.  Good pay compared to competitiors.  Decent bonus structure.  Not for entitled crybabies.  Has a good structure for moving up or moving locations if you want to.  If you truly want to be promoted more quickly then you need to be willing to move.  You always know where you stand with management and the company culture is great.  Once you catch on, not stressful at all.
cons: frequent change.  Must embrace change.  Don't count on lots of huge commission checks.  But you can get decent consistent ones if you're a top performer. Interviews make the commission out to be a little better than what is realistic and common (as interviews are wont to do)

pros:
- GREAT benefits
- Opportunities for growth across company, if you excel
- Strong bank, even in today's economy
- Generous paid time off (20 days/year, can rollover days)
cons:
- Intense sales focus each day creates tension and stress for team members
- "Grunt" workers must excel at sales and have good luck with random customer service surveys in order to advance--sales are valued above all else for promotion at banking branch level
- Micromanagement

review_title: Working at Wells Fargo has given me a wide variety of transferable skills to obtain a better job elsewhere
pros:
Promotions don't take very long
Transferable skills
Good place to get experience 
Teaches you about sales, how to manage money, and how to deal with customers
cons:
If you don't hit your sales, you are invisible to your managers
EVERYTHING is sales based...even people with no managerial skills can become a manager if they get enough sales
Micromanagement 
Demotions if you don't hit your numbers
Inflexible schedules
Sales goals

review_title: Sales is all that matters and don't forget it
pros: Good benefits, co workers are great
cons: Worse management I have ever seen.  Micromanagement to the extreme.  They don't care about you, just the sales numbers.  They act like they care about customers but they don't.  The reason why many have high sales is because they are shady.  If you don't make sales numbers you will not get anywhere.  They will work you when they need you, then not give you the hours you need after you've worked when they are short staffed.  You will give all you can then they will throw it back in your face.

review_title: A lot of changes due to mergers and the economy, but overall good place to work
pros: Generous paid time off; volunteering is encouraged; diverse networking opportunities from company-sponsored networking groups; 401k profit sharing; some departments and job roles allow for flexible shifts and ability to work remotely sometimes.
cons: Leadership without authority is a bizz word and line associates are rated on it. The problem is management does not help associates develop this skill, or are even able to explain what it means or to give examples. This means many employees in some divisions are rated as poor performing in this area, but are not given the support or tools to develop.

pros: They had good benefits and the managers are able to work with you on schedule.  They had a good software to use for tellers and it was easy to learn
cons: The pay was really low, the environment could be very unprofessional since a lot of young college students usually work there, they want you to do a ridiculous amount of sales for the small time frame you have with a customer at your drive thru or lobby interaction, they micromanage you like crazy and you can get fired if you don't meet the minimum sales requirement, customers would get upset because they hear the same sales pitch every time they go in to do a transaction

review_title: A solid Company but you better Think Twice...
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in West Chester, PA
pros: Solid company and good overall work experience to take to another employer
cons: This is a solutions based preformance environment.    It's said that the customer come first but in reality the bonus structure is based soley off of solution or production.   In reality it shove as many products done the throat od the client that you can.   Wheather they will ever need or use them.    In essance open as many relationships as possible with as many fees to be charged as possible.     Additionally the bonus structure is almost impossible to earn.

review_title: Great Company, Opportunities for Advancement, Competitive Pay
pros:
Great starting pay
Managers are very flexible with work schedules
The benefits are outstanding
Bonuses are not too hard to obtain
You can advance very quickly, I just had to leave to go back to school!
The training is paid and trains you very well
cons:
There is a large bureaucracy at Wells Fargo, all sorts of reports and silly things for you to sign
Parts of your conversations with customers are scripted, down to the phrases you say. 
Goals are large so they are pushy about you at least making sales pitches, but its easy

job_title: Teller At Wells Fargo in East Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Wells Fargo as a company has many benefits opportunities, including excellent heath care, great training program, decent pay, and an environment of pretty educated and helpful individuals.
cons: As a teller, I wasn't aware how sales-oriented this position would be. There are sales goals that you have to hit quarterly and I just am not the person that operates that way. I really lost  respect for people upon learning how common it is to do things that aren't necessarily beneficial for customers and aren't usually very honest, just for the purpose of pushing their sales numbers. Kinda sad.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good benefits. If youre lucky, you can find yourself in a position of support from management when it comes to getting promoted and reaching your career goals
cons: Very pushy with sales, when the store is not performing, not a fun time to work for the company. "What have you done for me lately?" I do not think employees get treated well. Not enough praise, too much critisicm and getting "written up". So many worthless, time wasting, market wide conference calls where nothing constructive is accomplished. A ton of managers and bankers flirt with, and severely crossing the lines of unethical practices. Very hard to get out of retail, really have to put in your time and put up with a lot of crap while still doing your best to outperform your peers because that is the only way to get promoted.

pros: Great training staff! They really create a sense of value for what the organization should be like.
cons: The drive to push so much sales at customers can be a bit overwhelming, Not so much in the sense of how we can help the customer, but I get the feeling of how many useless products can we shove down the customer's throats. Also, I feel ashamed that I receive some of the same poor customer service and hold times from the help lines as the customers perceive they get.

review_title: Awesome Company. Awesome Employees. Challenging so you can grow, but like a family where you are at home.
pros: You work to live, not live to work. Wells Fargo makes it easy to be comfortable doing what you do. After going through training, bosses and peers help you learn the business. The sales aspect helps you grow in the company, allowing those who put in the effort to really shine and receive added bonuses. Tuition reimbursement for students and by far the best benefits of any bank. They promote you extremely fast if you try!
cons: The sales aspect can be stressful, but it keeps the job interesting. I have been here for almost 2 years now, and though I have gotten numerous offers to go other places, I won't leave the company. They treat both me and my family really well.

review_title: Great company structure. Single parent? Don't expect to raise a family on your income.
pros: Solid company structure, excellent HR, clear expectations, decent benefits, highly regulated industry with aggressive business growth focused upper management.
cons: Big goals and low ceilings for compensation bonus. Highly complex compensation bonus requirements. Widget-focused shark-like sales mentality. Company focus on the stock price and shareholder. Limited respect for the employee and the customers that have built this US$ 23.0 billion (2014 profit) banking giant. The highly respectable message of the company's Vision and Values has been overshadowed by profiteering and vast salary inequality.

job_title: Banker Connection Customer Service Representative III in Fargo, ND
pros: Decent benefits, understanding and caring supervisor, amazing tuition reimbursement, room for advancement if you're working in the right department
cons: Hourly pay raises are complete BS. Some of the new hires I train are making more than me and I've received the maximum raise possible every 6 months for the last 5 years. Anyone working in DDA queues will get sh*ted on by other departments and always work horrible hours. Checks/OBC queues employees get paid the same as those in DDA and only have to work half as hard

review_title: Too strenuous for a retail job
job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Working for Wells Fargo was a fast paced job that was well suited for me. I enjoyed interacting with customers and working on the more complicated accounts and loans. I enjoyed coaching and managing to a lot of the operational activities.
cons: Way too much micromanaging, cookie cutter sales approach to all customers regardless of their relationship. Expectation of every customer to complete a financial priorities worksheet for any service interaction. Ultimately this job has too many rules and too much stress for something as simple as retail banking.

pros: Job stability, mobility in terms of internal promotion, coming encourages growth from within. Great relationships to be made with coworkers. Good benefits package, especially for Maternity leave
cons: Lengthy hours at peak production times, Extended hours required each month to be worked in order to meet deadlines. Turnover is an issue (mostly from persons being promoted or moving to another department). Compensation for entry to mid level is reasonable, but arguably for more senior positions, the pay does not suffice for the amount of work required

job_title: Full Time Teller in Titusville, FL
pros: The pro's of working at Wells was that I was able to be full time and I had great management. The job is above minimum wage but still should be higher. Also unlike some other banks we can have food and drinks on the teller line which is a plus!
cons: The con's is the pay, the intense drive for sales that drives down customer appreciation. The bankers have it even worse to make sales. There was a high turnover rate because employee's did shady things to meet their sales quota. bottom line at Wells it's not about the customer it is about the profit.

review_title: Nice Atmosphere in the STL Headquarters
pros:
-Nice atmosphere in the STL headquarters
-Opportunity for advancement/other job paths in most areas
-They are client-centric - no matter what the news is saying 
- Their benefit options are a nice spread
- Pay seems comparable
cons:
- If the bank has a bad year, ALL of WF has a bad year (Speaking from the Advisor side)
- Yearly goals are completely unrealistic for the board, never reaching them yet always coming out on top, exceeding the previous year's profit record. It feels like it's a way to keep bonuses and raises to a minimum
- Due to recent light in the news on the bank side, there's been a lot of Exec movement. We don't know what that will mean as the trickle down effect is sure to come.

review_title: Great firm, could be much better
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Great place to begin or end a career in IB
Strong reputation and a real player in capital markets
Balance sheet gets foot in the door with leading companies
Pay is in line with the street
cons:
Primarily U.S. focused and very risk averse which limits the types of transactions you'll work on 
M&A platform needs to start pulling its weight (top 10 on the U.S. league tables in every other product) 
Like other firms, politics can be a challenge and there are a handful of VP/Directors who will ruin your experience if you're placed in the wrong group

job_title: Part Time Teller in New York, NY
pros: For the most part, a lot of my coworkers were easy to get along with and willing to help.
cons: The company has a horrible way of choosing who belongs in management and upper management. They claim everyone is a team memeber but do not extend opportunities to help those “team members” grow within the company. The more you extend yourself to help and the better you are at your position, the more you get taken advantage of and held back from movin on because they can’t afford to lose you in that position. They do not compensate properly for the amount of work they request of you, nor do they treat you properly. The most stressful job i’ve ever had, based solely on the company’s standards and horrid management.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
-Lots of room to grow; it's possible to be promoted from teller to banker within 4-6 months. 
-Great team environment. Teammates reach out to you almost all the time, so communication and problem solving was always smooth. 

Honestly, it really depends on which branch you're working at or who you're working with. I  was lucky to be working with a great team, because I've seen other branches where it things were still great but didn't go as smooth. 

Also, even though I was a student working only 20 hours/wk, Wells Fargo offers benefits, PTO hours, and is very compliant with employee policies, so that was nice. If I were to choose a place to work after retirement, it would be here.
cons: - I can't think of any :)

job_title: Personal Banker in American Fork, UT
pros: The pay is fairly good for a starting position and I was in school while I worked there so it was extremely good for a college student. Benefits are good including paid time off, incentive bonuses, great hours, tuition reimbursement, medical, dental, eye, and other insurances.
cons: EXTREMELY sales oriented. In slower branches you spend over 50% of your time making sales calls. These calls are generally cold-calls about credit card offers or other bank products. If you think you are going to be service oriented in this job or an old school banking job this isn't for you

review_title: Horrible workplace. Tellers do all the hard work and get paid very poorly.
pros: Off the top you get your benefits. Including health and Pto time. Also they do like to promote within, but its very difficult to even be considered if you are in a branch who has poor service. Now your branch's performance reflects on your personal performance which is horrible.
cons: As mentioned before, Wells Fargo makes it extremely difficult to move up in the company and make your month to month goal. they are a very selfish and greedy company and do not appreciate hard working employees.

review_title: Great Company with aggresive sales numbers and unrealistic expectations.
pros: Wells Fargo has great benefits, a diverse workforce, and a financial history that is unique and deeply rooted in American expansion.
cons: Wells Fargo's sales are aggressive and based on what are referred to as "solutions".  With Wells Fargo's acquistion of Wachovia it was a mess.  Merging both company's systems and personel with one another presents a lot of frustration.  In getting loans and credit cards approved sometimes I feel the company is too big.  Additionally managers and district managers sometimes try to keep prized bankers within their district, even when that employee voices a desire to go elsewhere.

review_title: The company and management have lost touch with reality...an absolute joke.
pros: Benefits are good.  Pay is average.  401k matching.  Company has recognized brand behind it.  Potential to move up quickly to a point...but then your stuck.
cons: Management treat employees like children.  Widgets are more important than quality business. Management promotes unethical sales practices on the hush hush,..but will fire someone in a second if a situation arises.  Management says one thing but expects another.  Constant micromanagement...multiple daily conference calls "intimidation and threats".  No respect for personal or family time.  Unrealistic goals...zero flexibility.  In my honest opinion... Just a circus.  I am still shocked at what goes on in this place.  What a joke.

pros: Pay is decent, I guess.
cons:
Way too much sales pressure. Bankers are nothing more than glorified car salesmen who are forced to use their influence to pressure customers to opening more accounts than needed because a.) the branch manager is trying to save his/her own ass and b.) the district manager is trying to save his/her own ass. Unethical behavior costs people their jobs and creates mistrust among customers.

Also, stage coaching is annoying and only creeps out customers. If someone is in a hurry, NO ONE wants to be led to a banker's desk to take a deposit and lectured on additional unnecessary products that the company wants to push on them.

job_title: Personal Banker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Management is always interested in your improvement and advancement in the company. You will be taught useful skills on a weekly basis no matter what role you are fulfilling. There is seemingly endless opportunity within the company, and a decent amount of support to get where you want to go.
cons: There are vast differences between jobs concerning how you are treated. I am currently a Personal Banker and it is a very stressful sales-oriented position. In most sales positions at Wells you will be pushed beyond your limits. If you like a challenge, this company gives you what you need to be challenged, absolutely.

review_title: Manager never satisfied, constant growth of goals, unattainable and unrealistic!
pros: The manager was ably to work in fitting a great schedule that worked well with family life.
cons: The stress of the calls! Clients are very rude and irate. Some managers don't appreciate the de-escalating of calls that aren't transferred to them but are very quick to put you down on the weekly one on one meetings. Before you complete a goal the pressure is on to complete the next. It makes you feel robotic and unappreciated. Worst of all we were asked to work on a holiday, paid at time and half but when paid it wasn't as such. HR stated it was regular time per hour and we were never compensated.  Shortly, after I resigned. I lost any ounce of pride that was left to work with this company. They have no integrity toward their employees and much less for their clients.

job_title: Business Process Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Sr. Leaders are doing the right things to align departments with the overall strategy. Company values are solid but they aren't embedded into the DNA of the culture -- at least the department I was in.
Compensation is good, work life balance was not consistent.
cons: Some of the managers are the worst I've ever seen -- not skilled or educated and the culture was back-biting, petty, with no direction. Decisions weren't based on what was good for the business or for customers -- they were made based on what was best for managers. Customers rarely came up in discussions. The amount of waste was staggering. They attract good people but can't retain them.

review_title: Extensive borrower and lender interaction, mitigate delinquencies and work with borrowers to alleviate defaults.
pros: Office culture is key. Important to lead and integrate diversified individuals into a team environment that ultimately will share their personal and work experience by exchanging ideas. Lead by example, strengthen the overall team environment by listening and facilitating answers to problems. Office should be professional, promote employee well being, show concern for the well being and personal development of each individual, open door policy. Transparency in day-to-day operation. Compensate employees based on performance, meeting goals, office and other departmental interactions as well as adapting and following banking guidelines presented by senior management.
