cons: Excellent growth opportunities within the organization, strong company values and time-off-policies are flexible.

job_title: Personal Banker II- Service Manager in Fayetteville, NC
pros: Advanced technology. Very up to speed with products for customers. Very good benefits for employees. Good traffic flow.
cons: COMPANY DOESNT CARE ABOUT EMPLOYEES OR CUSTOMERS...ONLY MONEY!!  Required to do a minium of 3 checkings per day, 10 solutions, 500 proxy MINIUM!!. No expections.  I was a top banker in my district because I ACTUALLY ENJOYED HELPING PEOPLE. My morals are bigger than this company. Therefore i left. DONT BELIEVE ME? SEE FOR OURSELF.... GO TO YOUTUBE.. TYPE IN WELLS FARGO MIDSESSION... THIS IS WHAT A BANKER GOES THROUGH EVERY SINGLE DAY..WITH EVERY SINGLE CUSTOMER.. !!!

pros: A great company to work for with a good benefits package. Many opportunities across a range of financial services businesses. You can spend your entire career here and never work on more than the same subject matter. They don't burn out their employees - the company culture is not one of working long hours late into the night. Your mileage may vary on this, depending on where you work, but Wells is a company that truly values balance in your life. It offers the flexibility to get your job done and be with your family more often. A great group of people that put the customer first.
cons: A large company that can be difficult to navigate if you have worked in smaller organizations.

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: There are a lot of fun activities that the company puts on to try and make it a good place to work at, there is some room for growth, and the university campus is amazing literally everything you could ever want on site (Doctor, dentist, Salon, convenience store, Eye Doctor, Laundromat, Volleyball courts, basketball courts etc)
cons: Very low on the payment scale with little opportunity for bonuses or raises, some people in your department are made to become robots while the rest work hard and do the bulk of the work with no reward

review_title: Great company with Uncapable Managers and HRs
pros:
Package with Fixed pay
Work from Home 5 days a month
Work Life Balance
Some of the benefits
No disturbance in weekends
Helpful team members (Except Managers)
cons:
Managers - Some of the managers are non-professional. They feel like servants to onsite. You will  be screwed even if you are right. Escalations are very common things here and managers can't defend it so they will directly fall on your head.
HRs - They are very much close to Managers. They don't even listen to Associates. If a Manager targets you, then you will be screwed no matter what.

job_title: Home Loan Processor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: decent base pay with 3 different ways to bonus each month.
cons:
The region I process for, the management is not all on the same page and the lending officer is not very approachable. 

One of the ways to bonus is customer surveys and you have to score a 5/5 or 10/10 for it to count for you, anything lower hits you negatively. They also aren't based on the questions about us a processors through the process but are about Wells Fargo as a company and if they would refer people to us and with everything in the news these last few years it seems almost impossible to get a perfect score, I have closed on loan in 2 weeks from application and still get 4/5.

pros: The people were great.   Good benefits .  Team environment with all the help you need for growth and learning.  The metrics and bonus structure was not fair.  No matter what, if the department improved and started bonusing, the metrics just got harder and harder to bonus.  The call monitoring was not fair and would pick your calls to pieces, no matter what.
cons: You never felt like you were doing good enough.  They wanted perfection all the time in all metrics which is impossible.  Pay very low.  Raises were insulting, lowest I have ever experienced.  like 1%, not just me, but most.

pros: Only Brand Name  Nothing Else
cons:
-They don't offer good package , even service based companies are offering better compensate than this  , they are able to fool using brand name and hire employees on lower compensate

-useless managers hired from service based companies are spoiling work culture badly  , even wells fargo doesn't have their own culture , in every LOB managers are driving team as they want , no one to stop them. 

-micro management , you have to fill time tracker for every day activities and  hours for those activities 

-it's no more a product based company , it has been spoiled by indian mncs managers.

-0 on shore opportunity 

- my biggest disappointment was work culture and rude managers which i didn't expect from such brand.

pros:
The people are really nice at all levels of the company and leaders promote a strong work life balance. 

Benefits: Very generous PTO policy especially after 3  years with the company (25 days!), generous maternity leave at 4 months, and standard 401k match of 6%. Generous bonus as well that increases the higher the level.
cons:
Expect constant change while continuing to figure out how to restore trust with the public and regulators.  More of a typical bank that is not innovating enough and way slower growth than peers. They can be cheap with letting you do professional development trainings/activities and have cut back on business travel. 

Benefits: Average health insurance with either high premiums or lower premiums with high deductibles ($3K plus). Low annual salary increase that barely keeps up with inflation.

pros: Wells Fargo was a great company to work for. I like all their upper management and was able to enjoy the people I worked with. The hours and tasks were very fair and there was always scheduled coaching and training. There was great PTO, sick time and benefits including maternity. I only left because I graduated college and my career field is public health not banking. Overall I loved the corporate setting and the professionalism of everyone I met. This also includes similar ways of doing things from branch to branch. Nothing is perfect but overall I had a wonderful experience working for Wells!
cons: I can’t really think of any cons, I guess that some branches open Saturdays? Some see that more as a pro though if you need a day off during the week instead.

review_title: I love this company, and am proud to work here.
job_title: Phone Banker Team Lead in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Wells Fargo is such a large company and so diverse that your opportunities for advancement are almost limitless. Professional development is highly encouraged and I'm great friends with my co-workers and work in a great environment. The 401(k) plan here is pretty nice and the pay isn't too bad either.
cons: My department is in a corporate environment, so although no one will ever come right out and say it, money is always at the root of each change made. Management can be difficult to contact at times because they're forever in various meetings.

pros: Great Training!!!!  By the time you complete training, you should hold a series 7, 66, and Life Insurance, and CRPC designation.  Even if you don't stick around you at least very valuable licences.
cons: Everyman for themselves.  Once training is complete it's either sink or swim.  Management will not advise you on how to obtain business, so if your a newbie have a plan prior to applying.  The licences are great but if you don't know how to attract business your going to fail.

pros: Large profitable enterprise with very conservative banking model making it stable from job security perspective
cons: A giant with a highly federated model where individual entities have more power than the corporation itself. Individual product, lines of businesses and regions control everything that means strategic focus is not customer-centric, rather product widget sale driven. Very slow to get anything done and strategic proposals to go through the system significantly delaying the implementation in the market giving fast moving competitors significant advantage. From corporate culture perspective, individual thinking and risk taking is frowned upon. Bonus policies create a lot of laziness and hence many people who here just to collect paycheck (so very long tenures). Favoritism reigns supreme at all levels. Not much care for the line staff from salary and compensation perspective.

review_title: Boiler room, slave type of work environment
pros: Pays a little higher than competition
cons: Wells Fargo is so cheap they work everyone at the entire loan center to death. Continuous, non-stop bombardment of work overload if people express it, they blame it on complainers for not managing their work properly. Management discourages even minimal socializing so you can sit all non without moving at your desk to focus on your work. Management pretends to give you personal time off but it's a pretend personal time off because you pay for it and work twice as harder for taking time off because no one will do you work for you..  and if you plan on going on vacation, you better plan on working that weekend before the start of your vacation on Monday to work to finish your work. In short, WF bleeds everyone dry to the bone.

review_title: Great place to work, good incentive pay if you are good at sales.
pros:
- Most managers are sympathetic to your personal life and understand if you need time off.
- Well known company, provides a sense of pride
cons:
- Pay is good, but not excellent.  If you are good at selling, you can make much more.
- Dealing with customer and changing policies can be very difficult, but as with any job, you must learn to work around this.

review_title: It was a nightmare where every decision set up a conflict of ethics versus fear of retaliation.
pros: They do actively seek to promote professional growth, and the feedback is immediate and clear.  Recognition is readily given to those who do well.
cons: The corporate culture seems to promote a "do as your told or else.." mentality.  There is no room for objections even when sales ethics and professionalism are called into question.  Exceeding sales goals is the only activity that is rewarded.  Favoritism and retaliation are rampant, mid-level management operates with complete immunity as long as goals are met.  Those who don't meet goals are forced out by any means necessary.  The pay is quite low and customer service experience is not a priority.

job_title: Personal Banker I in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Great experience selling to high net worth cleints
- Benefits package = A+
- Fun people to work around
- Great on a resume
- Top tier retail banking experience
cons:
- Management ONLY cares about your numbers
- Your total worth is based on your daily and even hourly performance
- Low pay for the amount of work
- Its a political game to succeed
- You need to spend MANY years struggling for any career payoff

review_title: Very stat oriented, micro managed,  inconsistend daily changing guidlines,
pros: Great coworkers, guaranteed hours, good 401k match and benefits.
cons: Very stat oriented the more you work the better you do causing a vicious cycle of employees working more and more hours to stay on top. Ok until you get burned out. Bottom line don't go on vacation or get sick. Micro managed quality monitoring with daily changing guidlines adding a lot of additional stress and confusion for employees. Lot of anxiety in my particular department for job security, high turnover expected in the Real Estate Collection Dept..

review_title: Wells Fargo does not allow for a good balance of work and life.  The more you give the more they want, will suck you dry
job_title: Branch Manager in Long Beach, CA
pros: great training and meet a lot of nice people. Since, you will be at work for about 70  hours a week you will spend a lot of time with co-workers and they will become your best friends.  Good recognition events and upward mobility.
cons: Very competitive industry and WF will get the most out of you with pay that is not worth the sleepless nights and stressful days.  Enough will never be enough if you are doing great they will ask you for more and will raise your goals constantly until you start recenting the company and management, and eventually quit.  Will work you to the bone will never see family.

pros: - Good time-off policies and benefits are good.  Promotions are possible but decisions are based on current job descriptions which may not be accurate.  Training is available but can be slow in some divisions due to limited funds in budget.  Employees are able to relocated within same department.
cons: Entry level positions are easy to get but as experience is gained its hard to transition up due to job descriptions that are being referenced a crossed divisions.  The company values have changed in the last few years and the direction of the company also changed for the better.  Often times lots of change and employees aren't always informed which causes them to leave the company.

review_title: Good overall, room for improvement, decent salary and work-life balance.
pros: Tuition reimbursement, matching 401k, good work-life balance.  Also many online training classes available. Very good retail customer service standards. My manager was in MN and I was in PA.  He was not a micro-manager, so it was a fairly autonomous role.  As long as I did my job, and answered his questions, he was satisfied.
cons: Wells won the merger with Wachovia and they seemed intent on dismantling all of Wachovia's systems, even though they were superior in many cases.  Benefits were reduced including less holidays, smaller bonuses, higher medical costs. From a work perspective, I felt like my talents were underutilized.

pros: The are effective at providing most customers with what they want. They have good internal structure, they policies and procedures are usually fair. Pay and benefits are above minimum wage jobs.
cons: Wells Fargo would rather spend $15 getting a new customer than spend $1 to retain old customers. They are continually force feeding customers things they do not want nor need. They treat employees like slave labor and ride your case if you have an off day in sales. They have completely unrealistic goals for employees and force the management to be slave drivers. They lost a lot of really talented caring people when they bought Wachovia because they didn't treat their customers or employees right. The call center is so stressful that you literally need days to recover from a week of work. Wells Fargo also has integrity and ethics issues.

job_title: Consumer Sales Banker in Shoreview, MN
pros: After a year of being in their call center, you have the opportunity to  apply to other opportunities you are interested in...MAYBE..and that's a big maybe. A lot of their opportunities require significant experience, so they make it hard for someone with 3 years experience and want to start you out at level 1 so they won't pay you. I guess this is a con but a pro to those with 5 years experience or more and willing to sit in their call center for a year.
cons: Management isn't effective nor sincere. High turnover, long hours & the pay isn't great. Benefits are offered but aren't paid. Level 1 pay no matter your experience.

job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Commerce City, CO
pros: Online Service, Friendly Tellers, The idea of what they should stand for is excellent,
cons: Constant intentions of Adding, Selling, Pushing products, & promotion of products Customers do Not need.  In an attempt to get more accounts, or more products so the bankers can make daily goals.  The company doesn't put the needs of the Customer first. They believe that the more a customer has the more difficult it will be to leave. And the fee's on the banking side are outrageous.

pros: working with customers was great and the professional work dress code.
cons: for how little the company pays you they expect so much from you. the stress of sales was ridiculous for hourly pay and defiantly not worth it. also the biggest problem was having your manager stand behind you and force you to try and get sale with a customer when it was something that was not in the best interest of the customer. all they really cared about was sales and  hitting their goals, the customer is the last priority.

pros:
Great benefits, great corporate leadership. 
Nice 401k match, good benefit options. Good opportunity for advancement. 
Our region has experienced a major philosophy adjustment focusing on customer experience and lowering the sales goals and pressure.  Nice bonus opportunities.
cons: Retail banking sales culture.  Regional and district management focused on ineffective cold calling methods. Long workdays and full Saturday workdays. Bonuses are achieved only by meeting all metrics, not paid if you excel in certain categories but not others. This presents a real challenge if your position is located in a rural area or low income area.

pros: I work for Wells Fargo as a "part time" employee but am given full time hours due to lack of staffing. So the hours are a plus.
cons:
As a teller you are a space to the bank. You are required to do a lot and everything is strictly enforced. It makes sense because you work at the bank but you have to make sure you do everything by the book. Also, it takes two people to do most of the work behind the teller line so opening and closing takes forever. 
The job requires a lot of sales and you have to keep up with your numbers. Management pushes you to the max to sell especially during the beginning of the quarter.

job_title: Branch Manager in Myrtle Beach, SC
pros: Great company that really cares about the success of the its team members.  Great local Managers, dedicated and loyal Upper Management, and life long friends.  I  worked for Wells Fargo Financial from 2004-2007.  I started my career as a Credit Manager, then was promoted to Senior Credit Manager after 9 months, then to Assistant Manager shortly after that.  Offered promotion to Branch Manger.  Incredible relocation package and benefits.
cons: None to speak of. Unfortunately this division of Wells Fargo started to downsize during the housing crash, and closed its door in 2011.

job_title: Information Security Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great schedule, great salary, located with 30 minutes of my house but I can work from home. 18 PTO days to start for my position. Many internal job opportunities. Best benefits I have ever had.
cons: Some people have ben here for so many years that the passion for their work has faded and become drudgery. Most of my team has 10 or 15 years so tribal knowledge and cliques are the rule. Many great people but it seems as if it is difficult to get rid of sub-par employees, which is discouraging to those who strive for excellence. There also seems to be some disconnect with upper management when it comes to decisions around my technology.

job_title: Service MANAGER I in Murray, UT
pros: Great team culture. I can't think of much more. There is a lot of Cons than Pros to report with this company.
cons: Company is trying too hard to make it look a best work environment. Benefits are ok. Structure of the company is all over. It's hard to promote within company. Only 25c a year increase in your salary. No great perks like other company has to offer. Upper Management makes it look like they care, but they all say and nothing comes out of it.

review_title: A solid Financial Institution with competitive pay.
job_title: Home Loan Processor in Englewood, CO
pros: Great benefits, plenty of room for advancement, a strong history of growth. A variety of roles nationwide with stock options with yearly profit share payouts.
cons: Every year the bonus payout goals increase but the payout to employees decrease. It becomes more difficult for the ones in the trenches to thrive, while the executives take more and more for themselves.

review_title: Does not care about their employees and only does what it takes to make it look like they do
pros: Very goal driven company which I like and love the challenge. Good benefits and offer 401k  and love the volunteering
cons: Don't care about their employees just the appearance they have. Employees are replaceable and sales goals are still a must regardless of what they say on the news.  New bankers make more money then employees of 20 years.

review_title: Emphasis change has lead to relaxed environment
pros: As of 2017, Wells Fargo has taken emphasis off sales by eliminating sales goals. Performance is now based off customer service entirely and evaluated at a branch level. Company does a good job ensuring they have the right people on board and that their team members are well trained and ready to assist. Advancement is entirely dependent on you. Wells Fargo has extensive training resources that you can access any time to learn more and advance your career if that's what you want.
cons: Somewhat compartmentalized and with new evaluation methods it is hard to quantify individual performance.

pros: If you have good leadership then the job will be so beneficial, if not RUN!
cons: The management looks out for each other so try not to make one mad because if so they will make sure you regret it! There is room for advancement but the management guidance isn't always there. Some are STILL numbers driven since they 'changed' the policy. Its still more about gaining to most money each quarter rather than caring for the customers! I learned a lot on leadership among other tellers  but I also learned that Wells Fargo has gone down with many lawsuits YET not giving attention to the branches...where discrimination and unprofessional things happen everyday yet gets ignored ! Welcome to the TRUTH Wells Fargo

review_title: Equality isn't what you will find here
pros:
PTO and benefits
Stock purchase plan
401 K Matching
cons:
schedules
managers like to pick and choose their favorites
if your manager doesn't like you don't expect to ever move up in the company

review_title: Previous Full Time - disappointed.  Financial Crimes Specialist is a misnomer.    It should not be in job title.
job_title: Financial Crimes Specialist II in Charlotte, NC
pros: High attention to employee relations.  Inclusive work site with many amenities.
cons: Very high pressure, high demand, quota driven, inbound call center.

review_title: Starting pay is low, incentives suck now
pros: Fun environment, learn alot about banking, and helpful when trying to financially get ahead and can help with other career paths outside of Wells.
cons:
Starting pay is weak compared to other competitors. 
"Bonuses" are a joke. In the year I was there, they lowered the amounts every single quarter because they got caught with sketchy sales practices
Bonuses are also based on how everyone performs so you can bust your butt and everyone else gets payed even when they didnt do their part. High school projects all over again. 
If your district plays favorites, good luck trying to move up. Nothing is performance based, all about who likes who.

job_title: Market Research Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: work life balance, friendly, collegial work environment; people generally respect one another and listen to other's opinions. Advancement within the company is prized. Company rarely lays off employees and when does, tries hard to find people something else internally. In most divisions, there is also the chance to take on business initiatives, learn new skills sets, and interface with senior management. Training is valued with loads of opps to participate in financial services, leadership, or other kinds of courses. Many people you'll work with have been with WF for long tenure - probably the biggest proof of a solid, caring company.
cons: over value consensus, very slow-moving in decision-making - and thus people who like risk or want to do something new or outside the box are not successful

review_title: Wells Fargo is a good place to work.
job_title: Project Management Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: There is a very strong corporate culture and name recognition.  Accomplishments are publicly recognized and everyone is expected to work hard.  It may seem very  "rah-rah" but having now worked at a company with no corporate culture, I can appreciate the Wells environment.
cons: Long hours are expected and the line between work and personal time is often blurred.   Feedback to management is often not recognized or used for improvements.  It is difficult to complete a long term project because the tenure of the sponsor (senior management) is usually only about a year, so priorities shift often.

review_title: Welcome to the world of volume banking. Make sure you offer fries with that checking account.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Huntsville, AL
pros: Work/life balance is pretty good with the exception of having to work the occassional Saturday.  Decent benefits package, As a legacy Wachovia team member, pay is very good compared to the same position at other banks. Can't say the same if you are a new hire.
cons: The incentive plan is not very equitable. Same goals for all bankers regardless of whether you work in low volume or high volume store. If you care about relationship banking, this is not the place for you. It's all about how many products you can sell in one sitting. If the business is not coming in, then be prepared to get out and harass others at their place of business to try to get checking accounts.

review_title: I hated it. First worked for Wachovia but after the Wells take over everything went down hill.
pros: There is really not many pros for working at wells fargo. They had good health benefits, I loved my branch manager.
cons: There is Intense pressure to meet some urealistic goals. There is also (atleast in my area ) some favortisim where promotion is concered to family members.

review_title: Great Company, tough sales goals, advancement upon management approval.
job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: Strong brand. Great company values. Good amount of vacation and holidays off. Retirement and health benefits. Lots of diversity in products sold to customers.
cons: Strong sales culture. Some members violate ethics to meet sales goals. Leadership won't allow you to advance promotions unless they approve first, so you miss great opportunities to advance. Management isn't always qualified to make fair decisions. You're only great if you meet your sales goals and make the management look great... when you're lacking, they don't recognize you at all. Stressful environment, because management only cares about your sales goals and pushes all the time.

review_title: The best company I ever worked for!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mendota Heights, Optional[MN]
pros: I have nothing but wonderful things to say about Wells Fargo.  I worked for Wells for nearly 5 years.  I went through many significant changes during my time with Wells; not only were the changes relevant professionally, but there were major personal struggles and growth during that time as well.  I was able to utilize many different benefits Wells Fargo offers: the tuition reimbursement program, short-term disability, singing in the choir in Minneapolis, the volunteer program-Junior Achievement Finance Park, several different employee recognition programs, and many other programs which provided a fulfilling work environment.
cons: As with any work environment, there can be tension and issues that arise between employees.  I found that my particular department was a breeding ground for negative issues and cliques.  These problems, however, are common everywhere.

review_title: Cares more about sales than customers and employees
job_title: Phone Banker III Premier in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Staff is extremely friendly and will ing to help each other
cons: Low pay compared to other Banks,  Constantly changing bonus structure making it harder and giving out less.  Constant threats of write ups dismissal if sales and profit per call goals aren't met.  Low moral.  Highest turnover I have seen on any job.  Managment has even left due to unfavorable bonus structures.  Dispitewhat they saw they do not promote from within,  and forget trying to move to another department for career growth.  If and when you do it typically comes with a pay cut.

job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros: They give you information on job opportunities, expected salaries for those positions, and HR actually will respond to your submissions.
cons:
-Before a job is posted, the candidate has already been chosen most of the time.
-If you are in retail banking, your only real way to move up is to be come a branch manager first, then you can move into other areas.
-If you aren't interested in branch management, or are not a good manager, you don't move up in the company.

review_title: Don't You Know? Everyone Needs a Fifth Checking Account.
pros: Highly professional, corporate atmosphere, great benefits including medical, dental, vision, and corporate discounts. Good amount of paid vacation days with number of days accruing the longer you work for them.
cons: Intense pressure for sales. Very profit driven atmosphere where the pressure comes down from senior management to the retail level. If you are a personal banker at a retail branch, you are the one "in the trenches" so to speak with management setting increasingly higher expectations and goals every year. Goal tracking is evaluated not on the monthly or even weekly, but daily and you will get talked to if you did not meet the quota for the day. They encourage you to open accounts for everyone you know and is most often times inconsistent with what the customer actually needs.

review_title: Love the people I work with
pros: Great people surrounding you. Professional environment. The pay isn't too bad. I started at 13.68 your first raise come quickly and its a dollar plus. You're able to work morning or night shift. With a shift differential which is nice! You aren't doing customer service. Even though that's your job title. You're a salesman.
cons: The turnover rate here seems to be fairly high. Mostly because people really don't care to come to work or to be there in time. But when people quit I would say it's usualh because they are constantly getting ridden for not performing or reaching sales goals. Which is the main focus here. Sales sales sales. You dont get a commission per sale. But if you keep all your stats up you can qualify for a monthly bonus.

pros: When I started at Wells, I was part of the new team responsible for opening the new location.  For almost 3 years in Wholesale operations, our team exceeded expectations by reaching monthly goals, having the most superior audits and receiving many kudos company wide.  It was a wonderful work atmosphere and I would be there to this day if our department remained in Wholesale operations.
cons: After almost 3 years in Wholesale operations, our department was realligned to Loss Mitigation.  As a department, our entire team struggled.  There were not any formal policies or procedures in place.  We operated on a 'see-if-it-works' type of process.  We relied on e-mails and word-of-mouth for guidelines.  This resulted in a decline of our quality as well as our spirit.

job_title: Securities Operations Service Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Nice benefits, incentives, charitable and diversity initiatives. Self-contained community including fitness center, cafeterias, coffee shop and gift shop.
cons: Many departments in Operations leave little to no room for advancement. Leaving Operations can be challenging. Many coworkers have been stuck in the same position and rank for over 10 years. Third party vendors mentioned above charge high dollar for cheap materials.

pros: great training, stability if you can meet goals on retail end, better on non retail or back office side get to go out to events, but you must pay your own event tickets, memberships, lunch dinner, wf is on a budget.
cons: micro management is just the start, from how to shake hands they want the whole conversation scripted with the client, actually WF does not, but thats how mgrs interpret and it is read the script or else very strange they really want employees to focus on doing the correct activities, but mgr only cares about numbers, 4 appointments every day including a new checking account that you must produce for or else. yikes!

job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great people to work with. Many opportunities for growth. Lots of trainings outside of the branch. You don't feel like you work for a corporate, it really feels like everyone is your family. If you like sales, you can really succeed in Wells Fargo.
cons: Sales goals can get stressful, however, once you make it, payout is reward full. Management is trying to be less pushy on sales goals, however, you won't have much chance to grow in retail unless you're motivated to sell everyday.

pros: The reason where all trying to vote for Bernie Sanders
cons:
Extreme Cronyism

Scale back on promotions to lower costs.  Consequently an institutionalized Peter principle now exists.

Secret mandate to lay off all people in older generations of technology and processes, for newer generation.

Change from Bachelors to Masters/Phd for technology promotions.  Which will exclude a lot of superior people.  i.e. Linus couldn't get a job at Wells Fargo he would be too inexperienced in Linux.

20+k below median market rates in salaries.

They will burn out technical people because the average technical person even at the most advanced level,   is more marketing than ability.

pros: The benefits are outstanding, and the bonuses come at the perfect times a year. If you have a great RBC manager, it makes the job worthwhile.
cons: The job is mind numbingly boring. You can't leave your desk area, and the review courses are way too much work. Frankly, they're not even necessary, and barely even apply to the job at hand.

review_title: Average company - heavily focused on cost and compliance
pros: Competitive compensation with what used to be generous benefits.  With relocation assumed, opportunities for career advancement are many.
cons: Disconnected upper management allows for overtly cautious, and "compliance"-centric policies and procedures that are extreme and beyond common sense.  Too profit and cost conscious to adequately staff branches.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA
pros: Attractive offices, nice coworkers, prestigious public perception. If you want an office job, with low wages and tremendous stress, this is the gig for you!
cons: Unrealistic sales expectations. As a Banker you are expected to track a certain number of "solutions" every quarter (also broken down by day and week). These goals have nothing to do with what the customer wants or actually needs. The pressure on the bankers is sufficating, constant threat of discipline or termination for not meeting goals. It was incredibly stressful.

job_title: Client Service Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: The pros to working with Wells Fargo was that they have benefits and career opportunities. If you like a desk job then this is good. I realized I am not a desk job type of person and I hated it.
cons: Career opportunities are based on if you have a crappy manager or not. So many of them pick favorites. Shift bids are based on tenure and performance and happen every 6 months so you don't have a truly set schedule. You have benefits but what's the point if the pay isn't enough to cover the deductibles. You end up paying for benefits you can't use.

pros: Paying attention to employees concern and trying to help with.
cons: It seems that there is a lack of sufficient vetting to hire people who are really interested in finance and would like to grow within the company. Some of the employees seem to lack the spark that drives them to their best in a genuine way.

job_title: Personal Banker II in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Good benefits. Great team players among co-workers.
cons: We are super micromanaged. Tough sales enviroment, in a tough economy. No respect for employees from middle management and above. We are treated like infants. Not enough quality time with customers, too worried about quanity. High stress. Not enough recognition. Treat Legacy Wachovia employees as if we were inferior. Overworked and under paid employees.

review_title: Challenging sales job, great branch managment
job_title: WFF Credit Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Treated fairly across the board, strong support of branch and district managers, flexible for time off in balancing family and work life, lots of opportunity to advance and move around.  Now that Wells Fargo Financial is being consolidated into Wells Fargo Bank we have been treated exceptionally in terms of plenty of working notice and management actively securing other jobs for us.  Our district and branch managers have been readily accessible in this time of transition to help with any and every question.
cons: Complicated bonus structure on a curve more or less, so either zero bonus or a huge bonus.

review_title: A company that cares about the employee
pros:
- Wells Fargo truly cares about the employee.
- Can work at home based on your need.
- Time off is given when you need it.
- Excellent Benefits with at least 6 different medical plans to choose from.
- Management is very understanding and sensitive to what is happening in your personal life.
- Everyone is cross trained on multiple jobs.
- Knowledge is shared.
- Excellent communication from the top all the way down.
- Plenty of room for advancement and professional growth.
- They find a position that meets your skills and leverage the best out of you.
cons:
- Inter-Department communication on deployment changes to employees and customers needs some work.
- Low on desk space. Some employees are using huddle rooms as offices.

review_title: Company in dire need of change before it falters further.
pros:
Recognized brand
Many locations if lateral transfer desired
Maintained company match on 401k plan
Likely to be a survivor in banking consolidation
cons:
Starts and ends with sales goals which have little connection to market and economic conditions
Systems and processes are not user-friendly and not conducive to quality customer service
Extreme micromanaging due to excessive layers of managers of managers
Incentive plans have little relationship to goals - can qualify for incentive of $0 or have everyone make incentive but miss branch goals.  Upper mgmt incentive plans do not match customer-facing employee plans.
Logs and forms for nearly everything.  Spend unnecessary time trying to document what has already happened.

pros: The people are good and the management does try and get you to where you want to be. There is an approach to moving people forward however you need to want to be there. One of the issue that are with that is that if you are comfortable they are not going to push you. If you are on the ball and working to move you can.
cons: The worst part is that they are a large company. The corporate culture is everywhere and it is tough to get some things done. The manager's vary and you can get a micromanager one time and a great manager another time.

review_title: A great place to have a financial services career. You could work in the Wells Fargo vast business lines for a lifetime.
pros: Stability, growth, good culture and promotion from within.
cons: A very large corporation.  For any considering working here, you will really have to stand out to advance with sales numbers and performance if you plan to advance.  The further down the pecking order you are, the more true this is.

review_title: Tellers get to process transactions, sell to every client and balance to the penny everyday.
pros: No late nights. Every Sunday off. Salary is okay for retail. Clean, non-greasy environment. Potential for small bonuses based on individual sales and team customer satisfaction scores. A lot of locations and opportunity to move up in retail or transfer to another department.
cons: Very high pressure to sell. Bankers actually process the sales, but Tellers have sales goals. Clients are rude, ignorant and lazy and you have to smile and be nice to them. Trying to sell can distract you and leave your cash drawer out of balance at the end of the day. You do have to work some Saturdays.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great place to work and promotes fairly.
pros: The whole banking industry is changing and Wells Fargo is positioned ahead of the curve.
cons:
Paid me a nice retention bonus when the bank I worked for was bought out by Wells Fargo. I  increased revenue in FX Corporate sales by 50% in my only year at the bank.  I was told by upper management more then once in the month before my move  I would still work with my clients & hold the same title.
 My first day at Wells Fargo, I no longer had clients & I was no longer a Corporate FX Dealer. 
     I bit the bullet and after 8 months I was promoted from FX Specialist to VP-Senior FX Trader.

job_title: Personal Banker I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great company with great benefits, such as fair amount of paid time off, paid holidays, health and life insurance coverage. Discount on any other insurance. The company culture is great.
cons: You have to work like a cow all the time. The managers are too aggrassive. They do not care about anything, but will screw you up by opening 10 different account that you do not need. The pay is low comparing the stress you carry 24/7.

review_title: Breaching the Silos to provide technical support
pros: I have a great manager, this is the 2nd great manager I have had at the Bank.  Every day is something new, something challenging (on this I depend and Thrive!).  I see opportunity all around me.  Internal sites show of thousands of other jobs I could apply to If I were interested (I'm not).  Salaried employees are treated better.
cons: I have seen other managers (mostly in LOB or SALES) that do micro manage and set unrealistic goals.  luckily I don't work for one of them.  hourly employees are treated like contractors.

review_title: They are so busy looking forward, they do not ocncentrate on the now.
job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: When working at WF you learn a lot about the banking industry, no matter what department you are in. For me specifically I was in the Credit Card Customer Service (department known as WFCC) and I learned loads about great banking opportunities for further PERSONAL sucess.
cons: They are looking to make money off of every single customer. They take priority on sales objectives and new customer products, while putting the customer needs second. When trying to service a customer they expect you to give the shortest most generic answers which almost guarantees that the customers issues wont be resolved. The company and the HR department slacks off when employee questions or concerns require attention.

review_title: Wonderful. They are very interested in your growth within the company and love to hear best practices that we use, and they give really good feedback.
pros: Salary is great. The seminars to learn how to overcome objections on products are wonderful. It is a company that invests a lot in their employees' career path. You could start off as a lead teller working 20hrs a week on 10/hr to being a store manager making 70k+ in a matter of 10 years. Maybe even less. Without a college degree.
cons: Goals are set high. You have to generate your own business through outbound calls made to customers even non customers.

review_title: Good advancement potential, lots of micro management which ruins the experience
pros: easy to move up the ranks, just do your job and be outgoing with sales pitches, also being creative in your approach helps. if you focus on one product and sell the hell out of it you will advance quickly.
cons: Lots of micromanagement and high pressure sales. You wont lose your job over it unless you absolutely refuse to sell, but they will make your life hell.

pros: Great sales experience. You will truly learn how to generate business for yourself with a strong brand name behind you. I had a great team to learn from with solid leaders as managers to assist and offer their expertise when helping our clients.
cons: Too much internal conflict in regards to who manages clients and who is allowed to approach prospects dependent on past contacts and territory. If you find a prospect who needs your help and they have spoken to someone already in Wells Fargo, you might have a few people try to get involved in your sales process and take partial credit for your work. Management will help make sure compensation is fair, but sometimes the amount of time spent determining what's fair and what has happened can be draining and counterproductive.

pros: Plenty of opportunity to move up if you're a charismatic sales person. It is easy to be recognized for any sales or service compliments you receive by direct managers.
cons: The pressure to perform well in sales is immense. Many of my direct reports, myself, and even my direct manager have ended up taking leaves of absences because of stress. The number one reason for retail employee turn over is sales pressure and stress.

pros: Great 401k plan, many opportunities of advancing, it's a great place for a career if you like sales and work well under pressure!
cons: Where do I start, super huge sales goals to meet very unrealistic, management was horrible, managers would take advantage of me for being able to work at a fast pace so unwashed stuck as a drive thru teller for 4 years! May I add I had the same goals as everyone else while there was NO new leads on drive thru hated it! They never rotated any of the other tellers and all they did was relax and have a nice conversation with customers while I was bush running 3 lanes by myself!!

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Burnsville, MN
pros: Structurally, this company is good. They have great processes in place to understand what it is they're hoping you can accomplish. As well, if you're dedicated, you can move up in this company, which is where the real money is.
cons: Base pay for a Personal Banker 1, which is what I currently am, is close to laughable 36K. Metro transit bus drivers start near 40k. 17/hr to work in a professional environment, wear a suit each day, manage people's money, and go through a 25-40 minute session with each customer is poor when compared to working at Aldi as a High School student at 13/hr. BY THE WAY: BANKER'S HOURS DO NOT EXIST. 9-5 HA! Try 8:30-6 and on call nights 8:30-7 and 9-2 on Saturdays.

pros: Great benefits, great coffee company ... Oh wait they took that away! They give you 75 dollars for branch holiday parties and the DM keeps the rest for personal gift exchanges
cons:
No growth, District Managers are very limited in sales, coaching and people skills. Area Manager very outdated and drives results with fear of losing jobs. Force to cross sell to the point of illegal activity, District Mangers reap benefits and then try to fire you. Most managers were promoted based on looks, favors or to keep them quiet. Managers are more engaged in other performing managers to sabotage them. Wells Fargo is a great company but not in Miami. The EEOC should investigate al illegal hiring and lack of equal opportunity.
Miami Wells Fargo must restructure is its sales plan, incentive plans and all executive Managment especially District Managers in Miami. 
Good luck to all new and existing employees!

review_title: Mixed feelings after a good amount of time put in
pros: Great company with benefits pays, pto, great team environment. Not to many more pros way more cons than pros
cons: Always worrying about numbers and bonuses. That is the only way management will recognize you. They won't recognize you for simple customer service experiences.

review_title: El Monte call center stay away don't get tricked! Worst job ever
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in El Monte, CA
pros: Benefits, pto, sick time, ot available other than that it's been a nightmare position try to hold out for other positions within wf but avoid call centers
cons: Commission structure is predominately customer service based 25% of you're score given by customers who reply to a Gallup survey sent by email. Anything below a 5 is a zero and you cannot tell customers that. There's 10 different other ways to get disqualified for commission. 90% of referrals have no value 5% are qualified and 5% will get declined. That's 95% of you're work day dealing with angry confused no money no credit not interested customers you shouldn't be wasting your time or theirs. Plus Wells Fargo has the worst guidelines for credit. High turnover rate and getting worse.

review_title: Stable company with lots of opportunity
pros: Huge brand recognition, and a long history  -  this company isn't going anywhere, and they take care of their employees. Great collaboration, lots of opportunity if your current role isn't your dream job. Flexible, amazing work/life balance. Lots of resources to get your job done, and to help with your career development.
cons: It's a huge corporation - you're not going to have that nimble, small company feel. There's a process for everything, and big decisions and projects can take time. You'll never be a big fish in a small pond here, and there are times you feel a little like a number or cog in the machine. Your smaller team will feel more like a community, but there's definitely that big company feel.

job_title: Head Teller in Spring Lake Township, ME
pros: Loved the coworkers and the customers. Not so much the management. Hated cold calling on mandatory evenings. Had to sell so many items before you could go home!
cons: Employees have lives outside of work. Kids have things at school they would like their parents to be there for, but can't cuz we have to stay and cross  sell.  Customers get tired of having products rammed down their throats. Mgmt.  needs to lighten up!

review_title: Great benefits, Vacation Time, Horrible work environment! Management doesnt know their own policy.
pros: You get 4 weeks vacation times from the start date. Great health and dental benefits.
cons: Sales are hell, has calmed down since scandal. Management DOES NOT KNOW THEIR OWN BANK POLICIES. Every branch does things differently so if you transfer to another branch be ready to be told you are doing EVERYTHING wrong. Employees must look up the company policy and challenge management who do not know anything! This is why as a customer if you go to one branch they will tell you one thing and you go to the other they will tell you something else. If you are an employee you know exactly what I'm talking about.

review_title: Unfair Pay Scale among team members and poor management will make day to day life miserable
pros: Banking Experience,  Virtual Training was amazing
cons: Pay, poor scheduling, consistently short staffed (at multiple branches), lack of coaching and development when transitioning from virtual training to in person training, leaving a new to role banker alone  for hours at a time or all day on a frequent basis, allowing  team members to blatantly disrespect one another without consequences (even when in the public view of customers)

review_title: Previously great culture, however this has been strained given the amt of change and new risk mgmt leadership.
job_title: Operational Risk Consultant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: History of company values and overall company culture is amazing to see for a company as large as this and that has been in existence for as long as it has.
cons: Little to no budget is dedicated for training and continued development of staff. Additionally, PTO bank for exempt staff is not competitive. This is not commensurate with other large financial organizations that I have worked for previously. Lastly, there seems to be a newer tone with some of the newer management team that has lowered morale and instilled less trust by staff.

pros: Good work life balance and good benefits. 25 days of time off after 3 years of service.
cons: Since the start of their cyber security kick about 3 years ago, my division has been in a downward trajectory and far more stressful.  Everything is harder to do and requires an “Office Space” level of redundant process to do.  Management continues to to believe that all employees, regardless of job function, are exactly the same.   They then criticize staff for not doing work due to lack of access to systems that developers no longer have access to.

pros: I have really enjoyed my time at Wells Fargo because our teller team is awesome and I enjoy going to work everyday. The pay is amazing considering what other banks in the Amarillo area pay their tellers. You have the oppertunity to earn quarterly cash bonuses up to $350 which is also nice.
cons: However we have had several full time teller leave the bank and instead of hiring me on full time they keep hiring other part time tellers. This has been very frustrating because I have a bachelors degree in finance and I'm not moving up like I would hope. I would also say that Wells Fargo doesn't really care how much school you have completed, if you have a bachelors degree then you would move up the same as someone who doesn't.

pros:
- Decent benefits.
- Average pay.
- Some people are nice.
cons:
- The WF lifers have a creepy cult mentality.
- Unless you're the very top of the food chain (i.e., Mary Mack, Titi Cole, Charlie Scharf), you have no influence or ability to make an impact on your line of business.
- They don't care about their contact center employees, which is evident in the way they are handling COVID-19. 
- Work/life balance.
- People are nice, but it's mostly fake.
- Impossible to get in touch with HR, and when you do, you're talking to someone straight out of college who is following a playbook. 
- Overly concerned about reducing attrition and don't consider the fact that some people need to go, because keeping them there is a risk.

pros: Out of three companies I worked in Financial services Industry Wells is the best. In my opinion, they treat their employees fairly in most departments. You feel that your efforts are recognized and valued. There are many opportunities to find your place and get new skills and career growth. Also they're pretty diverse company comparatively with other two I worked for. I would recommend it for my friends. It might be not an ideal company to work for the rest of your life but at least it's a good starting point.
cons: I don't see many aspects that I would complain about. Just like any other big corporations it has some bureaucracy, I guess.

pros: Pay is alright. Co-workers are fun.
cons:
Huge sales enviorment! You must sell or your screwed. Management frowns on even calling in once. Must use your own PTO time. Schedules can change spiratically and you do not have the chance to say no.

You are forced to sell things customer don't need.
Long hours.
"One on Ones" are tedious and not nessisary. The managers micro-manage you and ask you what you're going to say to the customer next time in order for your sales to go up.

pros: The best part about the job is the benefits and paid time off. As a full time employee you can get up to 4 weeks paid time off a year. This is better than any job I've ever had. Fellow co-workers were friendly and fun to be around for the most part.
cons: Sales goals were unrealistic. Management gives constant coaching on a daily basis about making sales and will never leave you alone. Even if you think it is unethical they will never admit it but they don't care about ethics.

review_title: Its more than just cashing checks and making deposits.
pros: Pays better than other jobs when you are at entry level. Management rewards you with gift cards and early days off if you do well with sales. Work with a variety of people.
cons: Way too much emphasis on sales. Management is constantly harassing you about meeting sales goals and threatening to fire you if you don't meet the minimum, which isn't easy to do. With the Wachovia merge, there are a lot of unhappy customers who don't like the changes and you have to hear about it.

review_title: Can be a really fun place to work but still a sales boiler room..
pros: If you have a good manager and good team, WF can be a very fun place to work. Seems like most managers worked their way up so good possibilties for career growth.
cons: Sales, sals, sales.  If you know this going in to this job, less shocking.  If you didn't now this, you'll be in for a surprise.  WF wants the sales to come from great customer service but with the crazy #s game, it is hard not to push products customers may not need.

review_title: The experience has given me knowledge in building relationships and managing corporate politics
pros:
Very stable company given its risk aversion and manageable business unit growth expectations.
Friendly colleagues and generally an accommodating environment that fosters good ideas to bubble to the top. 
For most of the people who work at the firm, there is a lack of ego. 
Competitive compensation package, generous ancillary compensation (i.e. paid time off, 401k matching contributions, medical, dental insurance, etc.)
cons:
Risk aversion may be a tad too much given we are in a post credit crisis era, and companies are stronger financially. 
Resistant to changing too quickly the old ways of process and procedures, especially in regards to analyzing customers/clients who require credit. 
Resistant to very profitable ventures that is industry proven, however, the business unit is not familiar with.

review_title: Fun at first, then a real drag.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Irvine, CA
pros: Financially solid company. They will hold on to even the most incompetent employee as long as they are liked by management. If you want the prestige of being a 'banker' without knowing much of anything about it, Wells Fargo is perfect for you.
cons: Office politics dominate everything. The favorites are the ones who get the promotions, perks, rewards, and recognition. If you are not a brown-noser, you will not promote anytime soon. They expect every single Personal Banker to be a robotic salesperson, not taking customers' feelings or priorities into consideration. If you underperform, you WILL hear about it very quickly.

job_title: Vice President Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Vision and Values are consistent and well known throughout organization.
Leadership is talented at setting a winning strategy and executing it.
Overwhelming majority of managers support live/work balance.
Genuine appreciation for diversity in the workplace. 
Employees seem to genuinely care about their work and workplace environment.
Strong record of community giving and volunteerism.
cons:
Current economy and regulatory outlook for financial services companies is squeezing profits.  
Budget for merit increases and promotions has been declining for the past 5 years and is nearing 1%.  Company stock price is lower than it was in 1998.

job_title: Personal Banker in Westlake Village, CA
pros: You can advance quickly if you drink the company kool-aid and are willing to do some very unscrupulous things in the constant chase for solutions.
cons:
Everything. The sales pressure is insurmountable, the daily (yes daily) sales goals are unrealistically high and the attitude is "do whatever it takes to get your solutions". The majority of employees are unhappy and the majority of bankers come in to work everyday worried about their job security. And lastly, the incentive compensation program with Wells is a joke, the absolute worst in the industry.

Please, if you listen to anything I say i strongly advise that you look elsewhere if you are looking for a career in banking. There are other companies with much more sensible sales goals, less sales pressure, much better and more frequent payouts in regards to bonus, and most importantly they incentivize the RIGHT things which result in clean sales and actual banking.

pros:
Employment, which is a good thing in the current economy.  

The company name looks good on a resume.
cons:
High stress due to tyrannical micro-managers, roadblocks, red-tape, politics, finger-pointing, and CONSTANT fire drills.

Long hours, unplanned weekend and holiday work (which is unpaid) getting dropped on us frequently on Friday afternoons.  

No opportunity to transition out of narrowly defined job roles.  You are basically stuck in what is called a "silo" until that technology or job is retired, at which point you are put into what is called "star" status (which is internal lingo meaning "laid off").

Numerous internal processes and formalities that are often in conflict with one another.

Employee turnover, which in my group is increasing.   We've lost 4 good engineers in the past 6 months, and others in my group are looking.

review_title: Entry level customer service opportunities are good.
pros: Pay rate is excellent with base + bonuses for people having no experience to be hired straight off the street.
cons: Expectations are set very high, perform or get out. The more you learn, the more that is expected from you and the harder it becomes to make target goals. Eventually promotions that came quickly in the beginning start to work against the employee and feeling set up to fail is common place.

review_title: Life is tough for a new financial advisor anywhere, but Wells Fargo had a good support system.
job_title: Financial Advisor in West Melbourne, FL
pros: Wells Fargo Advisors provided very good entry training to new advisors, including test preparation, sales training and industry-specific knowledge. The branch manager was supportive and available, the tech support was good, and the back-office research was excellent. At the time I was there, there were no proprietary products that I can recall, so brokers were free to choose their offerings.
cons: In any brokerage, everyone is a competitor, so office politics exists. Seniority and production drive the boat, and it's all about the money coming in. New brokers are expected to do a lot of cold calling, and the hours are long. Be ready to give up evenings and Saturdays for cold calling and client appointments.

pros: The best thing about working here as a teller is that they work around your schedule. So if you have school or anything come up they work around that, another good thing is the bonus checks from making sales goals. At my branch, my coworkers turned into some of my best friends so that was also a pro. But if you're on the banker side, it's pretty competitive.
cons: SALES GOALS! All Wells Fargo cares about is there sales goals and if you made them. Also, the pay is low. Every other bank starts you off higher than Wells Fargo.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Austin, TX
pros: Good training and they do seem to care about your job satisfaction.  They conduct surveys to check your job satisfaction and ask what they can do to make it better.
cons: Sales goals are too high and they push calling people in the evening to set up appts.  You are tied to one position and not allowed to move forward if you don't meet their unrealistic goal number for sales and appts.  Care more about one more checking/savings account or CC/loan that whats best for the customer.  Way too much micro-managing.

job_title: Financial Crimes Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Decent benefits, not a normal phone job.
cons: They make it believe that you are mitigating fraud when really it's more like a factory production line going through as many alerts as possible.  They do not give you time to investigate what really is happening, you are basically required to work through as many alerts as physically possible, 40 to 50 a day which gives you less then 4 min an alert.  The heaviest weighted item on your review is production.  Management says to be yourself and honest in your work, but people work through lunches, breaks, come in early, just to pad their numbers, and management turns a blind eye.  The amount of production changes month by month and you are compared to those who cheat so you really don't know where you stand.

review_title: You'd better have great sales techniques for this job...
pros: I don't think there is even a pro, really. You can have a job with them and get paid. Basically it.
cons: For every little mistake you do, your manager will like you less and less. I wasn't being trained correctly and I really didn't feel like I was a part of this branch's "clique", which I didn't want to be a part of. They even made it known that I wasn't part of their clique. It was hard to try to keep up with responsibilities when they really didn't show an interest in helping you.

review_title: Not the best place if you are looking for a dynamic place
pros: more stable work environment than average, provides options to apply internal jobs, large size if you like to work for long years to come, opportunity to meet many colleagues
cons: not the best place to work for if  you are looking for exciting, dynamic work environment. Upper management is mostly into politics and relationship management than focusing on true performance for the company. Even though company has large size, you will still go through lay offs, firings, reorgs not expected at large size corporate levels

pros: Great job as long as you understand that you have to basically BS your way through it, and make up fake appointments to satisfy upper management. Uppers always want production so if you can fake production you'll keep your job, and possibly move up.
cons: All of the pros I just stated are also the cons...simply because of the fact that a company should not put themselves in a place where their employees feel the need to have to lie about their productivity. This job is heavily sales oriented, and thus puts pressure on all of its employees to meet sales goals. (which can lead to un-ethical selling of products, manipulation, etc).

review_title: Work experience as a young banker
job_title: Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good 401(k) matching of 6%, standard medical benefits that included a company sponsored MRA if you do not get health insurance, and higher base comp compared to other banks for similar positions. Great team mates who are well-trained by company to meet high sales and service standards.
cons: Competitive corporate strategy puts too much pressure on employees to meet unreasonably high goals. Sales goals test employees' ethics. Company expects perfect customer service survey results in order to pass a survey. Company is stingy in terms of holiday parties and rewards. Compensation structure is not very good.

pros: They have an exceptional training program. Upon finishing training you are prepared to tackle the majority of expected tasks. There are many good people as long as you are lucky enough to get placed in a good work environment.
cons: It is a what have you done for me lately atmosphere. Regardless of past success, you get come down on hard if your numbers slip. The bonuses also suck, even when you hit big numbers. Some managers suck and only view the people under them as pawns or stepping stones.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Beverly Hills, CA
pros: Great benefits, easy scheduling, great coworkers (sometimes)
cons: Goodness where do I start?! The sales aspect!!! Wells Fargo goes on and on about "customer experience" but they could honestly care less. Great customer experience isn't great when you're shoving products a clients doesn't need down their throats! And God forbid your sales pitch falls on deaf ears for a clients that has every products they need, you're the failure. And in my district if your aren't apart of a certain ethnic background that speaks a specific language (rhymes with marsi) then you can kiss any equal treatment goodbye. In a nutshell desperate and most of the time unethical sales practices, ill trained management, and a disgusting penchant for favoritism based on what language you speak make the Beverly Hills district the ugly spoiled stepchild of Wells Fargo.

pros: Great pay, bonuses and flexible work locations (can work from home in some departments); endless training opportunities both technical and non-technical.
cons: There are a few major issues with funding and management.  The bank likes employees who enjoy learning new skills/tools, but it does not have the funds to purchase these tools.  Senior management is slow to approve funding for contractors, new software and/or licenses.  Focus has shifted to improving company reputation and 'righting' the wrongs for customers after the news of fraud, so good luck on your career aspirations.  Hard to trust and work for a bank with such a bad reputation.

pros: You will work alongside some of the most intelligent people you will ever encounter.  Work life balance is generally good compared to other financial institutions as is compensation.
cons: There is a complete disregard for current risk management practices.  When you walk in the door be prepared to work with a management structure that does not believe in the concept of controls or proactively monitoring risky behavior as most management has been in the same company for 10+ years so they know no better.   Any kind of change either positive or negative is glacial, simple changes can take 6 months to a year to even begin implementation.

job_title: Phone Banker I in Birmingham, AL
pros: Good benefits, very relaxed environment, dress code allows tattoos and piercings, no drug test
cons: Constant fear of lay offs due to reckless overstaffing, any promises regarding procedures remaining the same or promotions are empty, ethically, the company is horrific, they have learned NOTHING from the 2016 scandal and have merely removed sales goals from their call centers.  Mark my words, the next scandal will be over their secured credit cards: branch associates promise customers they will be upgraded to unsecured within 6 months, in truth this is based on credit and MAY NEVER HAPPEN.  Customers are shocked when they find out.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Chesterfield, MO
pros: Wells Fargo provided excellent training for the Home Mortgage Consultant position.  I learned a lot within the one year time that I was at the company.  The management team was interested into me succeeding.
cons: Wells Fargo Mortgage company in Missouri did not have any down payment assistant programs for people with lower income and people who had credit issues.  This limited opportunity to expand into those markets forcing employees to target people in a higher income bracket. The simply didn't care about the little people who's household income was between $50,000 and $100,000 thousand.

pros:
*Awesome coworkers  
*401k with matching 
*Medical 
*PTO
*MANY additional benefits 
*One hour lunch breaks (retail)
*Business attire (pro for me)
*All holidays off 
*Tuition Reimbursement (See cons)
cons:
*Management was hit or miss (i.e. I was treated extremely poorly by a direct supervisor; managers were sometimes very lazy forcing other to make up for their slack)
*Commissions were barely worth the existence of any monetary incentive being established at all
*Bonuses: See above description 
*"Social Rules": The procedures for handling customer relations were intense and militant, inevitably stirring anxiety in both the employees and their clients 
*Tuition Reimbursement: they were shady about this but that wasn't surprising 
*Music: ....
*Getting the breaks I needed for school were more challenenging than they should have been; WF is not fully accommodating to students like they present themselves to be

pros: Atmosphere is Energetic and Fun while still being professional. Lots of room for growth. Top pay in industry. Tenured teammates are invaluable resources and feels like a family. Comparable benefits for industry.
cons: None. The rumors were true. But it’s prejudice to think all teammates are the same. Having worked at many banks I know the fraud happened at each one of the banks. Some people don’t know how to be a personal banker and resort to cheating to keep their jobs. Some managers didn’t know how to teach the bankers to help clients reach financial success and they taught unethical practices. Just like some people can have their skin a certain color and Be or Not be a thug.

job_title: Phone Banker I in Charlotte, NC
pros:
10x4 shifts 
Working for a bank
Casual dress code
cons: Micromanage to its finest! At the time i was there, we had numbers to meet. Out of every 4 calls, you had to refer a product or service. Out of every 10 calls, you had to have one warm transfer to sales dept. if you’re not meeting your numbers by the hour, they will have someone sit with you and listen how you’re taking calls. This can be very uncomfortable and adds a lot of pressure. At the time it was their way of coaching. But the PBII always seems agitated when they have to do this. Some perform well with this type of environment. Unfortunately i didn’t last 5 months cause i dreaded going in everyday. I did not look forward going to work everyday.

pros: The pay was good.  Health Insurance was decent.
cons: It's extremely difficult to get promoted. People are promoted based on favoritism. If the District Manager doesn't like you, it doesn't matter if you meet all of the requirements to get the promotion, YOU WILL NOT GET PROMOTED. I've known people who have worked in the same position for years and they never get promoted because they did not want to be the District Manager's pet. Management treated employees poorly.  We were told by our manager that we were not allowed to speak our native language to each other or we would get a write-up, only because she was insecure and thought we were talking about her,  SO IMMATURE and very much illegal. Very disgusting character from Management.

review_title: Was a good company. Now behaving like a service based company. If you are a high techy, go for it. If not, avoid.
pros:
1) Facilities like free cab, excellent gym.
2) Team engagement activities.
3) Vast opportunities if you wish to explore new cutting edge technologies. Wells has a T-hub (technology hub) dedicated for this.
4) Majority of the US counter parts are good and supportive. 
5) Shifts available to choose. But again if you fall under responsible persons category like team lead and above, then even if you work in the morning shift 8.30 to 5.30, you need to login back after reaching home to attend the daily status calls. 
6) Good compared to Service based companies.
7) seminars similar to Ted X are conducted at Wells level.
8) Hackathons are conducted and team members are heavily encouraged to particilate.
9) Wells has a Runners and Riders club which sponsor few employees to participate in the city marathons. Even they have their own 10K walk once in a year.
cons:
1) Over past few years, middle and higher level managers have changed and the new managers are implementing cost cutting methods. As a result, employees lost many privilages like hikes limited to once in a year, hike percentage reduced,  few of the recognition awards are removed, you have to choose either between parking or free cab. 
2) Also, each team member is expected to show money saved at their level in one form or the other. This effects performance rating and hike percentage.
3) Even though we have lot of Pros here, when your manager suffocates you to show some money saved, I don't think we can showcase our full capability or enjoy the pros.
4) Frequent organisation level changes are happening. Again, this is a result of the management changes happened over last 2 years.
5) Work from home facility is limited to 5 days now. And you shouldn't take laptop to outside city.
6) Management is very strict with LOP. They try all their rules to not approve the loss of pay. HR is supportive to management. I have seen many female employees who had to return from ML after getting their LOP rejected. 
7) Job security has lessened.

review_title: Great place to work...but not for an extended period
pros: Great place to get a technical backgorund/knowledge of the field. the learning curve is steep and much support is given during the first few months with a transition to more independent work occuring 8 months to a year after start. the best part of this is that the work can be complex so a feeling of satisfaction develops once job competency emerges. Also, management does take an interest in allowing employees to develop skills and encourages this development on a monthly basis. In the currwent market, it is nice to work dfor a bank that is not in the news for its problems.
cons: Promotions are slow in coming, so your current role may become tiring quickly.

job_title: Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Fair overall. Ethical. Balanced. Good place to spend some time in a career. Acknowledges need for work-life balance and makes a lot of effort to retain solid folks over the longer haul when possible. Good benefits and training offered throughout the company.
cons: Some challenges in moving around once you get beyond 5 years or so for most. Some promotions can be very biased. Tendency to tolerate less-capable people managers in some areas. In corp jobs, analysts and consultants masquerade as leaders. Finance is a power function. Sales versus marketing-driven. Technology is uneven - some divisions have better tools than others. Behind the times in computerized systems for retail branch use.

review_title: Well run big company but political
job_title: Senior Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: world beats a path to your door since it's one of the biggest banks in existence; great training ground and place to learn how a big company works; very capable executive team; good bay area location; some highly talented people throughout the ranks (but a lot of deadwood as well).
cons: political; very fragmented with warring fiefdoms; cutthroat;  weak middle management; too hard to get things done; very weak technology organization (especially in internet group); too much bureaucracy; incremental thinking instead of innovation; need to build a lot of consensus among warring stakeholders in order to get any project moving forward.

review_title: Good place to start a career
pros: Good advancement opportunities, good benefits, good pay, performance based promotions and pay.  A lot of incentives, contests, etc., and management is pretty structured.  They will do a great job of training you and give you the skills you need to do your job and do it well.  They give you a lot of tools to make sales, such as a good prospecting system.
cons: It is apparent that they care little about you as an employee.  Supervisors and management tend to be very conniving, and they can see you as just a set of numbers.. your sales numbers.  Sometimes sales expectations can be a bit unrealistic because so many people cheat the system.  If you're honest, it is hard to exceed sales goals.

pros: Name recognition, products and services.
cons: Lack of forward thinking and inability to change.  Product pushing is not "selling".  In my short time with this company, It became apparent that they know nothing about sales.
