Wachovia employees were trained to "create" customers by establishing a need and then filling it.  Referrals were common place and appreciated (both external and internal).  Talent was recognized and rewarded.  This company had no sales tracking or proftibility tools before the merger!  How can you say you are a sales organization without the basics sales tools.

review_title: Life in a Wells Fargo Store...
pros: Upper management recognized that my direct manager was doing a poor job and he was 'encouraged' to find other employment. Sales culture is implemented very well in some locations and that inspires success and enthusiasm. As a manager I was granted what I thought to be an appropriate level of autonomy. Great benefits.
cons: It can be difficult to maneuver through the HR process to shed poor performers. When a manager is held to the high standards of aggressive sales goals this can be a drag on efficiency.

review_title: Good company to work for given big bank environment
pros: Wells Fargo is a huge company so there is a lot of room for growth if you want to stay in the financial services industry. Benefits are decent though with the merger, there has been a shift and it feels like the benefits are taking a hit.
cons: Depending on which line of business/business you work in, it can be hard to get a promotion or advance. With the merger integration, there is a lot of politics and fighting. Not having enough resources is also an issue. Lack of communication is definitely an issue.

pros:
*Large reputable company w/more potential customers after Wachovia transition
*Many Financial Products and Services for employees
*Your success rate is what you make of it
*401K Matching (Trad and Roth available)
*Planned Time Off
*Insurance Benefits
cons:
*This sector of Supervisors are picky with the days you request off, even though the days you accrue for time off are yours to use, they may still be declined after requests are forwarded well in advance. 
*Much is left to be desired after you complete training, once you are out on the floor, you realize many scenarios that you weren't prepared for....you must ask a lot of questions!
*No Home Office program

review_title: Wells Fargo has been a decent place to work, and has opened doors for me professionally.
job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist I in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great bennifits, lots of room for advancement. Some what friendly worrk environment. Wells Fargo does a good job of pretending you matter to them.
cons: You don't really matter to them, they'll throw you under a bus the first time they see a bennifit in doing so. They don't pay as much as other companies for similar jobs. No communication between the people calling the shots and the people carrying out those orders

review_title: A good place to start in finance.
job_title: Communications Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: For a huge organization, Wells Fargo is surprisingly nimble. It's gone through a lot of changes in a few years and stayed healthy. Some of the smartest people I have ever met work for Wells, and their skills are not limited to finance: they excel in all kinds of things. In addition, management support for everything from time off to editorial standards could not be better.
cons: Many projects lack a strategic approach: the company sometimes just "throws bodies" at a project until it achieves a desired result. If your manager is in another time zone, or is a full-time telecommuter, it can be difficult to figure out what you're supposed to be doing.

review_title: Large company has room for advancement
pros:
Room for advancement
Decent training
Pay not the worse
cons:
Benefits suck they only offer HSA/HRA plans and are quite costly when compared to the actual salary you receive.
They have you do more work then actual tellers in the branch but you make the same pay as them. 
Training should last longer its a wealth of information for a short period of time in the classroom.
Can never find a manager when you need one, but when you aren't referring they are right in your face.
You have to refer on every call even though when you are hired they tell you 1 out of 4 calls.

review_title: Sometimes performance is valued more than long term employees who consistantly contribute.
job_title: Lead Teller in Fort Collins, CO
pros: The retirement plan is excellent with a six percent match rate, the free and discounted banking services are awesome, there's tons of opportunities to move up if you work hard- and experience is often seen as more important than education. Employees are recognized for their achievements frequently.
cons: Working in bank branches can be stressful sometimes because of high sales expectations and some employees might feel border-line mirco managed. On occassion, promotions can be made for political reasons or given to people who have lots of sales but less practical knowledge and experience.

review_title: Seems like a great place to work
pros: I have been thru 3 Banks and 2 mergers.  I have only been with the company for about a month, so i havent been in my branch yet i have only been thru training.  The other institutions I have worked for always say they move people up but I rarely see it.  In my training class, out of 19 people 5 are people that have been promoted from teller.  They all have said AS LONG AS YOUR DOING YOUR JOB you will get promoted and that you will get noticed for the work that you do.
cons: The training is good depending on who you get.  My first trainer was great but my 3rd is horrible.  She doesnt know what she is teaching.

pros: Wells Fargo has a lot of great products, co workers are really nice  and you get full benefits
cons: The push for acquisition and numbers is very stressful. I have even noticed some people telling clients that the NEED certain products just to make their numbers which I do not agree with.

pros: I get a paycheck that doesn't bounce
cons: Bad place to work, they have driven away our clients and business and then point the figure when goals aren't met.  They only care about the big accounts and their money and couldn't care less about anything else.  You are no more than a number here. The banking people have take over and are like Marley and Scrooge...  Used to be a great place to work before Laura Schupach and her bean counters took full control and fired everyone that knows anything about insurance. Just a sickening regime of money mongers.  Can't wait to get out of here.  With any luck they will let me go in their next round of layoffs.  That's coming again since they are sending business out the door at lightening speed.  Too bad we weren't one of the offices they just sold off..

job_title: Store Manager III in Lehigh Valley, PA
pros: 401k match 6%, brown nosers will advance, partial medical benefits, ongoing training, security and insurance licenses paid for, recognition events.
cons: Overbearing sales culture with micro management. High stress levels. No work/life balance...Work 6 says per week, often 65 to 70 hours as a branch/store manager.  Verbal and mental abuse daily from management. Ask any policy/ethic questions aka whistle blowers, you will be fired along with anyone taking approved FMLA leave.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Tucson, AZ
pros: Wells Fargo trains all of its employees and really ensures that you provide the same customer experience every time. There is definitely room to grow if you are able to sell the products and services. There are amazing benefits such as PTO, holiday pay, bonuses, and perks with the company. Reputable brand that ensures that most customers will be completely ecstatic to come in and see you
cons: Tough for non sales oriented, high pressure environment to hit numbers and be competive in the workplace. Decent wages, but should be more for the 5 - star level service that is forced to provide to every customer.

review_title: Great company overall. Good work life balance if in the right team.
job_title: Implementation Consultant II in Portland, OR
pros: Long term career opportunity, lots of positions always available.
cons: Get all the money you can upfront as managers are held to a tight budget for raises and rarely give more than a meeting expectations review, so your annual review with a merit increase are minimal to say the least.  More you get upfront the better you are in the long run, as the raises are always well below cost of living.

pros: Good benefits, a large platform offering means many tools to service customers in the marketplace and opportunities to get deals done even though traditional credit channels may prove daunting.  The SBA and Practic Finamce Channels are a competitive advantage in the marketplace.  Which is nice when the traditional credit approval process is restrictive.
cons: The credit culture is too restrictive and limited for community banking to truly win over customers with established commercial banking relationships.  It limits a bankers ability to disrupt established relationships

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist III in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Nothing. Have to write five words
cons: This was the absolute worst company I have worked for and the worst position I have ever held.  i was hired with 5 other people and was immediately given mortgage files to process even before training was completed. This consisted of talking to people on the phone helping them going to the refinance process, and I would consistently get yelled at by customers due to lack of training. This is a company in which their internal ratings are biased and are rigged since the managers urge there subordinates to rate them a certain way. I would not recommend this job to even my worst enemy, in fact I have already told people with standing job offers for this position to pass. By month number 8, me and the 5 other people whom I started with had quit.

pros: The enviroment is lovely! The coworkers and managers all were very pleasant to me. They definitely care about community service as well as joining and supporting causes that are very near and dear to my heart.
cons: They care more about sales than actual customer service. Very metrics driven, and they rarely discipline those who use less than ethical practices to achieve set goals. They do sometimes show favoritism to those who kiss up over those who actually work hard. They do promote people who are not qualified for certain positions and don't take the training necessary to function in their assigned role.

review_title: Bankers Hours During Upper Level Schooling
pros: I worked for Wells Fargo throughout my graduate and undergraduate studies. I was tracking in a field the bank endorsed and as a result I was able to get tuition reimbursement. Additionally, the hours worked well to maintain a job and a school schedule. Paid time off was another great benefit
cons: Sometimes because of the nature of smaller employee pools in retail banking it could be difficult to  get days off requested especially around holidays, however at least the bank is closed on most holidays. Sales goals were aggressive, so you have to be aggressive if you want to be at the top.

pros: At a busier location, or if you are working at a location that is short staffed there is plenty of opportunity for overtime. The pay is pretty decent. My Service Manager was way too awesome!
cons: There is room for advancement but at my specific location it took people many years, and when I met with people from other branches they were able to move up with just a few years, and some within 6 months. A lot of gaming going on to receive solutions and whatnot, very unethical considering how much they emphasize being ethical in training. Always had customers complain of how they were duped into getting into something that hurt them financially, especially the elderly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent work life balance,company is larger enough to offer opportunities to get experience across the company. Its easy to stay within the company for years if you want to.
cons: People do well or not based on networking and participation in committees. little emphasis is placed on how well you do your actual job. skill set is often not relevant to promotions. Never admit the emperor has no clothes.  Salaries and benefits are not competitive for the area, even "good" raises o not even keep up with increases in the cost of living.

job_title: Financial Advisor in North East, PA
pros: A wide variety of investment options.  Great support from the help desks in St. Louis MO and Richmond VA
cons: Wells can't seem to shake the bank scandals, this significantly impacts new business. Recruiters paint a wonderful picture that does not always play out.  Service associates are typically at regional centers which can make it difficult to develop a good rapport. Regional managers have a big stake in bringing on new FA's; that can create a strong incentive to paint that wonderful picture.

pros: The company culture is mostly shaped by the managers of the team. I am very fortunate and extremely lucky to be under my manager who is genuinely caring to all of his employees personally and professionally. He is very straightforward with us and all of his expectations and always so supportive in achieving our goals. His attitude transferred over to my supervisor who also adopts the transparency, honest, supportive, and caring approach. The atmosphere is friendly and very supportive amongst everyone. We are allowed some leeway but work always get done and is the highest priority.
cons: Getting time approved can be tricky, but that's when communication is key.  As long as the work gets done on time, then should be no problem in getting PTO approved.

pros: full health, dental, and vision coverage. 401k matching. Great PTO offers in combination with banking holidays.
cons: location matters. You could end up in my position where it is high-volume and mostly low-income which could lead to large portions of your time dealing with upset customers who don't understand basic finance: not a good combo. Or you could have a branch that is in an affluent  area that leads to prolonged relationships under management that demands full flexing of personal finance knowledge. Advancement seems to be as of lately been based on seniority or nepotism. For sure lack in real merit base metrics for advancement.

review_title: This isn't a job....it's a career. And an awesome one, at that!
pros: The management is really good at coaching rather than just telling you to do better. We truly do care for the customer and are trying to add value to their transactions and experiences by asking questions and/or making suggestions. The PTO is quite generous, especially considering it's on top of the 11 days of paid holiday time off.
cons: Be prepared to be on your feet for several hours at a time.

job_title: Business Initiatives Consultant III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Paycheck always clears. Benefits are nice.
cons: There is an insidious and pervasive culture at WF that promotes and rewards crony-ism, misogyny, and a general complete lack of concern for human beings. Never in my life have I worked with a group that was so devoid of culture that no one cared when blatant sexism, lying, mismanagement, and sexual harassment would take place -all on a regular basis. Complaints - via formal complaint channels - were quietly hushed up and dismissed while my female coworkers and I were subject to rape attempts (by multiple men towards multiple women), as well as many other less overt, more insidious harassment such as being talked over in meetings and flat-out ignored until a man suggested the same thing I or another female coworker said.

pros:
- better pay
- no cold calls
cons:
- micro manage like crazy!!
- District Manager walks around like she is to be worshipped.
- no work life balance
- people who are cool with the service manager gets off whenever they want to

review_title: No bad teams, only bad leaders.
pros: Benefits and pay are above average.  Excellent environment for those who thrive in toxic unstable conditions.
cons: Lack of servant leadership, work-life balance, minimal training and development due to poor work-life balance.  Severe dissonance between professed code of ethics, vision and values compared to actions.  Management not open to counter views, innovation, or logical reasoning to process improvement.  Management quick to remind subordinates who is in charge.

review_title: Needing support with processing to be able to go to the 'Next Stage'
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Dallas, TX
pros: It is a very well known company...known for their integrity, customer service and attention to detail. As an industry leader, it is good to have the name of Wells Fargo to back you up in this time of chaos in the industry.
cons: The fact that after the loans are closed...the customer has to deal with a 1(800) number and a person not local. But that is what a major corporation deals with.

review_title: What they say vs. what they do
pros: It has great benfits and room to grow.
cons: Their producet are not only inferior compared to the compitation but are also much more expensive.  They also have a segment of the consumer population they not only do not care about, but do not want to do business with.  Their business practices sometimes exploit less savvy costumers and they charge fee's that are not only excessive but in my opinion are near criminal!

pros: The company offers a very comprehensive benefit package. Work/life balance is encouraged by management-Time off is encouraged.  The company is constantly growing and offers opportunity for rapid advancement.  The company encourages community involvement and volunteer activities.  Pay is competitive in regards to the industry.
cons: The culture as a whole is quite conservative.  New ideas are pushed to the side and traditional business decisions are followed.  Strategic initiatives change rapidly and often revert back to what the plan was 12 months ago.  Some managers are promoted quickly without the experience of managing others.  This slows down the development of their direct reports.

job_title: Assistant Controlloer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Culture
The people were extremely down-to-earth and not cut-throat at all.  Almost everyone around me was a lifer with the intention of staying long-term.  

Work Life Balance
It's an extremely friendly place for families and my co-workers were not ashamed to show that life was not all about work.  There is an emphasis on community involvement as well.

Pay
I was very satisfied with the pay, but I heard that it's not always the case.  I worked in Corporate, though.  The pay may not be as good in the branches.
cons: The culture is not very young and it's a very large company.  If you prefer a dynamic, young environment where things move very quickly, this may not be the place for you.

pros: nice benefits and pto time
cons: The sales pressure is so brutal in the retail bank that it has resulted in employees becoming physically ill from the stress at work.  Many legacy Wachovia employees have experienced a drop in incentive payouts of 75% since Wells took over.  Between the unattainable goals, being micro managed, and financial stress, employees are finding it hard to find happiness in their jobs.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a good place to work as long as your in good with the managers, it's not what you know it's who you know.
pros: I'm like working with Wells Fargo because the pay is decent from what other companies are paying, the benefits are good and overall it's a stable company.
cons: I've learned over the years, if you want to grow with the company and move up you have to get in good with the managers and supersivors.  It seems to be more of a personal thing as appose to them going by individuals work ethics and whose more professioanl capable of taking on the promotion and job description.  Also, I wouldn't say they're concerned with what's better for the customer, it's what's going to bring in their next dollar.

review_title: Like the stagecoach ran me over!
job_title: Assistant Branch Manager in Naples, FL
pros: The technology is advanced.  You can learn about many diverse areas of banking.  They have many different product lines banking, brokerage, insurance, loans.  Easy to get in if seeking entry level or second career.
cons: This company will suck the life out of you!  They expect you to act like a physician always on call, not matter what.  However, the compensation in no way warrants the demands.  You are never, ever, going to be able to deliver enough for this company.  If you do well, they simply short staff your branch and expect more.  They talk a good game about career development, work life balance, etc. Do not be fooled this is the WalMart of banks.

pros: Wells Fargo has a great training program for all positions and generally preaches about hiring from within the company. Met a lot of great people working at Wells Fargo.
cons: Product pushers, many that succeed do so on some level of unethical sales practices. Trying to convince people that they need three checking accounts just so your branch reaches over set sales goals is ridiculous. Pay is definitely not worth the micromanaging that they will put you through.

review_title: Great for experience but not for a career
pros: benefits are great, pay is decent, vacation time is really good. The computer systems are fairly easy to learn. Most co workers are friendly and easy to get along with
cons: too much focus on sales, promotion based only on sales and who you are friends with, too much stress. Power struggles seem to take place on a regular basis between tellers, lead tellers, and service managers. Tend to only hire part time tellers with no benefits

review_title: The people are great but the company is hard on the employees
pros: It's decent pay for just a job. Anyone can do it although you have to have thick skin and work well under pressure. You pretty much do the same things everyday and it isn't exciting unless you get robber or someone steals money. If everything goes smooth you have easy days.
cons: The managers think they have to be mean to do their job. They constantly threaten the employees with write ups for small things. If you don't get a minimum of 80 solutions per quarter they write you up. You have to get 120 for pay out of 100 bucks only!

job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Westlake, TX
pros: They do what they can to work around a mutually beneficial schedule for all parties.  I genuinely enjoyed the people I worked with and the area.  Great perks with good pay and able to pick up overtime if approved system needs, which generally required and needed additional people.
cons: Very strict adherence to schedule, deviating even a little over the course of the day could hurt your performance.  Not a place for those who can't be monitored or adhere to a rigid schedule.  Very strict grading system on what can and can not be said over the phone... this in addition to other factors made it very difficult to qualify for bonuses.

review_title: Too much politics, too few rewards
pros: The customer interaction was great and they do pay pretty well if you are qualified. There is a lot of turn over so moving up in the company is pretty easy.
cons: They don't care about your schedule. I was scheduled to get married and my boss wouldn't let me have the time off without docking me for not being at work. It was all about who you knew in office, you'd better not get on anyone's bad side because rumors start flying and someone's head ends up on the chopping block.

job_title: Service Manager II in Reno, NV
pros: The hours are great, the pay is comparable to other financial institutions, the people you meet, they allow you to challenge yourself, the personal and professional growth, training is adequate.
cons: High sales goals that lead to others selling things that a customer doesn't need ("gaming"), endless meetings, calls all day long explaining why you did/ didn't do something, other Service Managers being like a clique, staying very late if a TM is out of balance, or going to work on your day off when a TM calls in.

pros: The benefits are some of the best
cons: No opportunity for advancement in administrative

review_title: Jealous people all over the company.
pros: They promote people quick you can go from pt teller to manager in less than a year
cons:
No job security. If your supervisor dislikes you he or she will do everything in their power to get you out the company. And HR or DMs won't do anything to help you even if you have never done anything bad before.,
 You have many employees from bankers to managers attacking other team members around the district( the ones they dislike and the ones who are top producers). You get push around to do unethical things to meet your goals. It's very ridiculous and the only one to lose their job would be the banker who committed the crime.ah And if you lose your job from Wells Fargo be ready to be unemployed for a very long time.

review_title: The job was great at first. But the quality declined fast.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Chandler, AZ
pros: There are plenty of great benefits. 401k matching is great pto which increases the longer you're there.
cons: Management does not listen to their employees. I worked at three different retail branches and it was all the same. Managers are pressured by district managers to do whatever it takes to put up numbers and in turn they pressure employees to engage in unethical practices. Employees constantly open accounts that customers don't ask for and don't need, then when the customer comes back and asks why they have fees on an account they didn't ask for, the managers say too bad and send them on their way. This company has very little respect for it customers and lower level employees

review_title: Not the best, just a job.
job_title: Loan Document Specialist in West Des Moines, IA
pros: The name (reputable company).  Everybody knows it, so if you say you've been there for a year or so, people know you haven't been bumming around that whole time.
cons: Very static, not enjoyable to work there.  You can tell everyone is only there because they have to be.  Seems very unlikely that a promotion will ever come.  Very little direction as well, at least in the data entry sector.  "There's your computer, you'll be staring at that for the entire day from now on - here's some quick directions that you'll have memorized after you do 100 of these on the first day."

review_title: “Cross Sell, Wells Fargo Only Wants Employees To Sell Customers ”
job_title: Store Manager II in Richmond, VA
pros: Benefits (but cost creeping up and coverage creeping down each year), Good Morale Both Management and Coworkers, and Honestly a Great Company.
cons: Cross Selling is the only focus now, firing employees who are great at their job in every area that should matter but if the cross selling results are not meeting the ever ridiculous quota (which continues to rise) than you may not have a job next month. Expectation for customers to say yes to cross selling, leaving you with no real control of your job security. Stress!

job_title: Home Preservation Spec I in Des Moines, IA
pros: Time off is good, most co workers are nice, company keeps you busy. Learn useful skills.
cons: Pension was suspended in 2009 and then taken away as a benefit all together. I was a 5 year employee with a great record and let go over one small incident. Annual raises are smaller than cost of living increases. Healthcare coverage got more expensive and got a higher deductible and now covers 80 percent after deductible rather than 90 percent like last year.

review_title: Ok, could work for worse in finance. Must love sales and competition.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Texarkana, TX
pros: Flexible hours, friendly coworkers, active environment, chance to help customers with financial needs, potential for growth, felt like immediate management cared about their employees, many good memories from my experiences.
cons: Constant push for sales & points toward quarterly goals, not customer oriented-business model is product oriented, corporate practices encouraged dishonest practices, high pressure to perform, public shaming for failing to meet goals, nasty severance practices

pros: I enjoyed some of the work and the clients I had. My manager was pretty laid back and treated me like an adult - I could pretty much come and go as I pleased as long as I did my work and did it well.
cons: The upper management showed obvious favoritism. Not only did they treat certain people better than others, but it was an ongoing joke that you weren't going to get a raise or a promotion unless you were getting married, having a baby, or some other life event that obviously made you "better" than those around you who were doing better work.

pros: Wells Fargo has top tier Brand recognition.  However, Wells Fargo Advisors has less Brand recognition than the Company as a whole.  It derived from the former A.G. Edwards.
cons: The Financial Advisor in Training (FAIT) goals are ever shifting.  They say that they want to do what is best for the client but make no mistake this is all about the commission or Gross Dealer Concession.

review_title: Hypocritical and abuses employees with at will employment
pros: Good benefits, pay is mid scale, internal advertised culture sounds ideal
cons: work-life balance is non existent. to avoid paying overtime workers are asked to "volunteer" and work flex hours regardless of being nonexempt classified. us workers are replaced with outsourced workers as a priority and existing us workers are expected to pick up the slack. lower level managers are not educated enough on how to advise their workers on career management within the WF family.

pros: Many opportunities for advancement in retail banking, 401k matching at 6%, excellent training.  Decent bonuses.
cons:
Keep in mind I maximized my bonuses and hit top tier for every sales goal...

Sales pressure leads to unethical practices, upper management thinks everyone is doing what is right for the customer but they're in their own world.  Sales goals reward ripping off customers.  Low salaries compared to other banks.

pros: cant think of anything positive unfortunately.
cons:
Unethical practice are not only known but encouraged by senior leadership at all levels of the retail side of the business. 
4 times a day calls are introduced where leaders are asked by their senior leadership why they deserve to sit in their seat if they haven't open the necessary amount of checking accounts. Every January it is still expected that you 'jump into January' where you're expected to double your daily numbers of new accounts. 
Negative culture where there is no sense of putting the client first. Fosters an environment where good people are pressured to do unethical things to keep their roles. However no actions are taken when knowing unethical practices are taking place, rather they are celebrated for achieving the un realistic expectations.

pros: Having worked both on the bank side and brokerage side of Wells Fargo (Wells Fargo Bank and Wells Fargo Advisors), I have different perspectives depending upon which organization you are researching.  Overall, the company was a great place to work: comprehensive healthcare, a generous 401K, and a plethora of miscellaneous benefits from child care to education.  The pay was competitive with the industry.
cons: Both Wells Fargo Bank and Wells Fargo Advisors are going through transitions.  The bank has had to change their sales goals due to the lawsuit in California.  The brokerage side is realizing that the old way of hiring Financial Advisors no longer works.  Hopefully, as they adapt to these changes, they will make it much easier for their employees to be successful.

review_title: Why do I need a title?
pros: Great Benefits like 401K match (up to 6% once you've been here a year), partners benefits like health insurance, standard "bankers hours",
cons: You'd better negotiate your way into a good position when you're hired in regards to compensation. Management is only "allowed" to give out 1-1.5%  (max 2% but you always have to hold back .5%) raises per year and it's a closed system on a team level basis. That means if one of my team members deserves a 2%, someone has to get a 1%. If you want more than that, you usually have to change jobs and then you're usually capped at a 10% raise for a promotion unless that brings you short of the minimum on the pay band.

review_title: My experience has been good for the most part.
pros: Wells Fargo has really Good benefits. Also, You can move up, and around in the company, the 401k is good., and the pay is pretty good. There are so many entities of Wells Fargo, you can choose your area of expertise.
cons: Sneaky upper management, a lot of favoritism. Sometimes, it’s not what you know, but who you know. Also, Wells has apparently stopped compensating employees additionally for being bilingual.

pros: Good exposure; good training, good compenstion, i like that they really give you good training and look out for you and want you to succeed and want to you do to well
cons: It is really a big, i mean super duper, big company which is perhaps not for everyone although I did really feel like part of a team there although sometimes you do indeed feel like a bit of a number or whatever

review_title: Good benefits but pay is low and don’t expect to move up in the company.
pros: Benefits besides the pay was good.
cons: You are there YEARS and still can’t move up because you’re competing with those who have been there 15+ years and are trying to move up. Pay is low too even with their bump in pay to a min of $15.00 an hour. Long hours are a must there and management doesn’t care except the big picture. You bring up anything like the Site Safety issues and they close you down. This is people’s lives on the line!

pros: Professional work environment, solid compensation and incentive program, great medical and 401K benefits, and awesome paid time off
cons: People in positions of power sometimes abuse that power. You can have a really great and fulfilling experience or absolutely miserable depending on your branch and management team. "Sales" went away but sales pressure did not.

review_title: Great benefits, but be prepared to sell your soul.
pros: Great benefits, good salary, great training.
cons: You essentially are a car salesman. Wells Fargo implements goals for bankers to attain bonuses so high that you have to offer financial products that the customer might not need or want. You basically convince customers that they need the products. Bankers at Wells are not true lenders but order takers. Wells Fargo pushes community banking but it really is not. Loan decisions are made in Neveda, phoniex, or Texas. Bankers have to "sell" 8 solutions to each customer. And some management has the philosophy "just do it" regardless if the customer needs the service.

job_title: Senior Credit Manager in Norfolk, VA
pros: Rewards those who have done well. It really pays to perform and stay ahead of the game. They value individual recognition and reward sales efforts very well. I was promoted 3 months on the job purely based off of individual performance. I am proud to work for such a conservative company that doesnt end up on the 6 o'clock news for doing bad loans or putting clients in harms way...
cons: You have to come in and hit the ground running. No time for babysitting or hand-holding...Also more immediate and timely feedback would be appreciated. The base pay isnt very competitive either in my opinion.

pros: great advancement opportunities and they have a really good way of showing appreciation for their hard working employees. the incentive pay and recognition trips are amazing ways that the company shows they are proud of their employees hard work. they also have a really good 401k program and a great health care program as well.
cons: the market i work in can play favorites very easily, and by doing that the wrong people get promoted over the right people. sometimes the feedback on how to improve at your position is to vague to actually make improvements. i also feel that some management cares too much about their personal lives than the professional lives of their employees

review_title: Great Job for top sales performers!
job_title: Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you are good or superior in Sales, this a good job for you. The job is 80% salary and 20% incentive compensation(commission), so the day to day pressure is off as far as income. Wells Fargo does hold you to daily, weekly and quarterly goals, but if you are a  top performer, this should be no problem. The company thrives on integrity, compliance, conservative practices
cons: Average sales performers will have a hard time or struggle with meeting their minimums. The entry level positions make the employees use scripts when greeting clients which at times becomes difficult to do.

review_title: Don't expect to rocket up the ladder unless you are a member of the "boys club"
job_title: Risk Manager in Des Moines, IA
pros: great benefits, great focus on work life balance.  if you are looking for a secure 9-5 job and get a 3% raise every year this is the place for you!!
cons: you have to aggressively manage your own career.  you won't get promoted unless you threaten to leave with another offer or if you transfer to another position.  management is inconsistent in terms of their standards for performance.  there is some favoritism, a "boys club" mentality exists among the top execs so getting to that level means joining the club...

review_title: Everyone is taken advantage of here.
pros:
9-6 hrs mon-sat
Market level benefits
Fellow employees are a pleasure to work with for the most part
Technologically advanced, teller software intuitive and easy to use
Benefits include discounts and employee assistance
cons:
Too sales drivin, Wf doesn't care about it's customers or what financial position their aggressive sales leave them in
The only way to get promoted is to be a favorite of management
Tellers get surveyed based on ridiculous criteria which is extremely difficult to achieve
Low wage
Extended hours plus many holidays taken away
Can't be paid out pto and it doesn't roll over
Incentives are not what they seem you don't get much

review_title: Not a good place to work....at least in Georgia
pros: The benefits such as bonuses and incentive before Wells took over Wachovia were great.  Especially if you sold investments.  Quality choices were available in your 401(k) and you could get a 6% match.
cons: Terrible upper management, clueless and not trustworthy...at least that was the standard in Georgia.   A lot of backroom deals were made for certain people to get promotions when they were clearly not qualified to be the fry cook at McDonalds.  When that happens you have leadership that has no business showing employees what to do or how to do it because they don't know what to do or how to do it....it was a nightmare.  It felt like working for Mr. Magoo, no direction what-so-ever.

review_title: I had a very good experience but I was displaced due to closure of department.
pros: I feel Wells Fargo is a good company to work for. They have good benefits, career advancement, many locations and is a strong and stable company. In may ways they are better then some of the other larger banks.
cons: This is not really a complaint, but I wish they would have tried to place the better employees within the company when being displaced. I really feel this would save the company some dollars,

review_title: Very heavy workload; sink or swim environment
pros:
-Pay was good considering the job responsibilities (basically customer service and time management)
-Bonuses for site performance
-A lot of opportunity to get to know your co-workers if you put forth the effort
-Good if you have non experience and looking to delve into the mortgage industry- you learn a lot about mortgages
-Direct management was supportive
cons:
-For some people, too heavy a workload too soon
-It's sink or swim - figure it out and manage a lot of files right away or hit the door
-Upper management probably didn't have enough loan processors hired; it was clear they didn't care 
much about customer service - processors were left to take the heat (and heat from practically every borrower) for the ridiculous time it took to process even the most simple loan

review_title: Potentially a Great Place to Work
job_title: Bank Lead Teller in San Antonio, TX
pros: Company has been in business for over 150 years and shows stability in most practices.  Health and employees benefits are pretty good including paid time off right off the bat.
cons: High degree of turnover/low retention.  Been through a series of different branch managers and most don't seem to have the basic skills to manage effectively to help ensure retention of talent.  Due to lack of adequate staffing, scheduling is a challenge. Went from working a five-day-a-week schedule to working a six-day-a-week schedule without notice from upper management. Not much work/life balance as a result.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great benefits. Whether you're full time or part time, you have access to a wie variety of health and life related benefits, paid vacation time, tuition assistance, and even counselling. I believe the pay is fair depending on the position you do, and the retail team members have the opportunity to ear bonuses evey quarter.
cons: Your experience at Wells Fargo is likely to be very depedant upon what store you work at on the retail spectrum. If you have a store with a strong team and decent traffic, the work isn't too bad. However, if you work at a location with little to no traffic and unreasonable goals, you could find yourself working six days a week with excessive overtime and little to no consideration for the work/life balance.

review_title: Young Professional given alot of opportunity at this company
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Excellent expierence and resume builder for early college grad , ton of room to move up I started as a teller august 2011 moved to customer service and sales then personal banker and now and a licensed personal banker 2 , very driven company that pushes employees to achieve the highest results
cons: sales pressure , numbers to reach gold incentives are sometimes outrageous, micro-management depending on branch , bankers held to same sales goals at slow light traffic branches as ones that get tons of walk in business

review_title: Be ready to put in a lot of hours!
pros: Because it is a large corporation, there is plenty of room for upward movement.  The pay is decent (about average for the banking industry) and bonuses can be large but you have to work extremely hard to get them.
cons: There is no work/life balance; my family has to come second and that is it.  As a Store Manager, I am expected to meet all of the sales goals (through coaching my bankers) and will be written up if I don't meet those expectations.  Because I am salary, I work 6 days/60 hours per week and it doesn't matter to upper management.

pros: Some of the best training in the industry, if not the best.  No matter your position, an emphasis will be placed on sales and they're going to show you how to sell.  There are so many career paths to choose from with this company, everyone can find something for them.
cons: Compensation is limited, better if sales numbers are met, but still limited.  Compensation and customer-satisfaction surveys are flawed.  Skewed toward the company, and not the employee.  Management structure is designed as such that the lower-tiered employees must have some luck or be a favorite of a boss to succeed.

review_title: If you like large companies, this one is great.
pros: Overall, a solid place to work. I had the pleasure to work with a variety of talented people from across the company. Given the size and scope of the company, there are multiple areas to explore as you advance your career.
cons: It is a VERY large place and decisions take a long time. If you are looking for autonomy, this is not the place for you. While the scope of the company offers opportunities for advancement, it is a very silo driven organization so skill in one area may not be appreciated elsewhere.

pros: Good benefits. Ok bonuses if you can reach extremely high sales goals.
cons:
Where do I start.. Bad pay. Micromanaging. The store manager is pressured for sales so much that the bankers get threatened for their jobs. We place outbound calls, sadly most of them are cold calls which is not on the job restriction. If you can't get accounts from customers that walk in then you do "feet on the street". Basically who're yourself on the street to different businesses and SOLICIT them and their customers to open accounts with us. Technology is outdated, any updates to the software come with a ton of glitches. Managers don't care much about helping current customers unless we are being able to sell products to them. 
I'm not a banker. IM A RETAIL SALES PERSON.

pros: Salary, orientation and training were good. Management was sensitive to personal needs to some extent. The opportunity to grow exists pending layoffs don't occur.
cons: Mandatory overtime without regard to work/life balance, employee ideas and suggestions don't matter, stability is not possible. Many upper management personnel have no concept of the job and run their departments from a spreadsheet. Insurance is not very good. Many employees that were laid off had transferred from other parts of the country just weeks before they were laid off.

review_title: A mixed experience in Wholesale Banking
pros:
Wholesale U. has programs for career development. Not many banks offer formal credit training anymore.

Good benefits and work/life balance
cons:
You would think promotions are based on achievements. However, in the division I was in, promotions were based on politics.

Middle level management has their own agenda and is not good at communication

5 years after the merger there still exists the Wachovia/Wells Fargo- us vs. them culture

review_title: Treats Employees Good! Bank Teller/Personal Banker
pros: depends which branch you land in can really make or break your sales goals. Busier branches get way more sales, can reach sales easier and faster, and are rewarded more often because of the constant meeting or exceeding of sales goals. If you start as a Teller, you could work your way to personal banker if you exceed your sales goals and customer service and get an OK from your manager.
cons: Micromanaged, if someone comes in and wants a credit card, and you direct them to a banker to complete the application, it's not qualified to count as a "Sale" since the customer walked in and wanted it, instead of you offering and trying to "close the sale"

review_title: I had a great time there and gained valuable experience, it was challenging but I am glad I did it.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Dallas, TX
pros: I had the opportunity to work with great people who helped me develop and grow with the company. There are many opportunities to grow. The technology is up to date and activity updates very quickly. There are multiple ways to get assistance whether it be one of the many 1800 number or just by asking someone at your branch or another one.
cons: The goals and objectives are a little out of reach sometimes. You have to have a great management team to understand that and help you out otherwise you will suffer greatly. Goals seem more important than everything else.

review_title: Like any large company Wells has good departments and bad departments.
job_title: Loan Administration Manager IV in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They try to be fair in pay.  Conservative credit culture is great because the bank tends to shy away from risky products.  If you can understand the way things are done in a large company and play by the rules, this is a good place.  Standard benefits.
cons: In recent years management has gotten away from valuing team members.  When laying off people they do make an effort to retain, but it is largely a token effort; managers will hire who they want regardless of whether a qualified candidate is being laid off due to downsizing (or whatever other reason).

review_title: Not the job for me. I was looking for a career not a job.
job_title: Phone Banker I in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
- offer health insurance after first full month of employment 
- casual dress code
cons:
If you're a phone banker one, you're basically a robot 
- on the phone 100% of the time 
- calls are expected to be under 4 minutes
- Quality Assurance is very subjective
- your bonuses depend on the clients emotions
- very large organization so to fix one problem you need to speak with 10 people in 10 different departments
- things can change at the drop of a hat
- all about sales and making money

review_title: Work wise , Wells is a good place. You should be lucky to have a manager who is technical enough to understand
job_title: SQA ANALYST IV in Charlotte, NC
pros:
- Compensation is acceptable.
- Work life balance is excellent.
- Used to have good benefits
- Depending upon the group you join, you will have a good KT sessions as a part of on boarding.
cons:
- Benefits now are so so, I guess after affordable care act, its gotten worse.
-  Salary is not up to industry standards in IT sector.
-  Many managers have very low technical abilities, some don't even know how to use outlook. These are the people as  TM3's and  software projects seems to them like a black hole.

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist in Des Moines, IA
pros: No pros besides coworkers are sometimes fun.
cons:
Working for Wells Fargo was the worst experience I've had. 

I worked here for a year and a half when my fiance suddenly died.  I was granted ZERO bereavement time (since he wasn't technically related to me) and had to use all of my vacation days to attend his funeral.  I was fired shortly after for performance after speaking with my manager about what a hard time I was going through dealing with his death.  I asked my manager if I could switch departments or do lighter tasks for awhile since I could not focus or concentrate on anything due to the shock of what had happened, and he gave me absolutely no options, and instead, fired me shortly after.

review_title: Good when growing, bad when stagnant
job_title: Consumer Loan Underwriter III in West Des Moines, IA
pros: When department was growing, advancement opportunities and salary growth were exceptional -  constantly attempting to achieve better technological for all areas - minimal cost for banking services if any
cons: Once department slowed down, no promotions and salary increases reduced to annual 1% (effective cuts when considering COLA) - management was ill-trained, ineffective and far too busy protecting their own position - leadership is exceptionally reactive instead of being progressive and industry leader - conservative to a fault - diversity is not a focus despite corporate claims

job_title: Customer Service Representative IV Business Team Lead in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: nice PTO set up gives you access to all PTO for the year after 90 days of employment. after three years you get another 40 hrs of PTO. then 10 and 30. okay health care nice dental and other benifiets.
cons: some poor managment styles. alot of managment will not take feed back. after moving into the lower managment office politics and bias plays too much of a role. the company claims to be pro Veteran but in the salt lake office it appears they are farr from the vision of the company. for new agents call volume can be over whelming and sales pressue can cause a negitive experance if not managed correctly

review_title: Like any job, you get what you put into it.
pros: Team members are the competitive advantage. Very focused on diversity and inclusion. No matter what the background Wells Fargo does its best to help everyone fit in. You will know in the interview what is expected.
cons: Not many cons. Yes I really like this company. I would say that there are a few relics still hanging around from Wachovia. Legacy Wachovia needs to keep up with change jobs. Also, like any other job, you get back what you put into. If your manager doesn't provide the support you think you need, there are others that will. Start networking immediately after you are hired. Friendships last a long time in this bank.

job_title: CSR2 in Salt Lake City, UT

review_title: Excellent Work Experience, No Promotional Opportunities, Weak Middle Management, Risk Averse Lawyers  "Ride it Out"
pros: The law department is run differently from a line of business so there is insulation from a "bad quarter." If you're motivated, you will never be bored because there is always something new to learn. The business clients you have are always trying to make banking faster, better, easier, and as their lawyer you get to be part of new initiatives that are exciting. Wells Fargo is highly respected  within its industry as well as outside it. You will be proud to work here even if it seem stodgy. Many people would consider this to be a "dream job" because of the company's stability.  There are lots of competent attorneys.  People want to do the right thing intellectually. The company has lots of inter-lawyer training by way of free unlimited PLI courses, working groups, legal education, and some informal mentoring.
cons:
Senior Management in the law department breathes rarefied air and is rarely dealt with, while middle management runs amok. Quite a few middle managers are incompetent (e.g. don't know much about the area they are managing, and are not leaders who advocate for their direct reports) and consequently they feel threatened by their competent staff.  Managers' reviews and workloads are not scrutinized.  Middle managers are not trained and hence are awful at managing or serving as advocates for their team.  They tend to be good at managing up. WF doesn't routinely do 360 reviews, and places an inordinate emphasis on the direct manager's review, which lends itself to abuse. People are rarely given advancement opportunities internally. Nearly all promotions are given to outsiders. Many of the middle managers are hired from other companies.  

The mindset of most successful lawyers here is "risk averse" so most lawyers have a certain CYA factor in them.  It is not uncommon to hear lawyers now say "that  decision is above my pay grade" whereas the phrase used to be "run it like you own it."  There is a lot of emphasis on process and asking questions, less emphasis on being productive. If you do make risk conscious productive decisions that help your clients move forward, your clients will love you but you won't be rewarded for it most of the time in the law department because no one pays attention to productivity here.

My observation is that most lawyers after working at WF could not work in a more risk embracing company. 

Many lawyers work with their doors closed all day, even working through lunch, and then they go home to families.  It is like the civil service. People who come here "ride it out through retirement."  The offices are dull and morgue like.  No one really talks, except on the phone with other people on conference calls, or when you run into them in the kitchen or bathroom, or the occasional diversity lunch (which is usually run by secretaries and paralegals) or at the holiday lunch.  If you're young or young at heart, have ambitions, are animated, or extroverted, and full of life, don't come here, unless of course you want to use it as a stepping stone for something better for you.  But this place has a vortex, and could suck you in for life in its complacency, so be careful.
