cons: Didn't really screen employees. Most people hired didn't have experience and told me they lied on their resume. Company doesn't seem to see how employees are doing during lay off season, your name is just pulled from a hat regardless of how well you perform. Company states they want to keep you and will provide short term assignment, but each position, including my old position I was then deemed unqualified for.

review_title: Unrealistic sales quotas force employees to badger customersand give them unneeded products and services.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Philadelphia, PA
pros: HR worked quickly in getting me in, training seemed decent and the base was higher than where I came from.
cons: super dead branch where the only customers are old folks who don't bank online. Sales quotas for tellers and bankers are completely unrealistic. Management is lazy, angry and not well skilled. Mine has no interest in getting to know customers, let alone helping them. District management browbeats them into submission and thus the pattern rolls downhill. Hostile work environment and crap morale throughout. Angry customers actually use branches less conveniently located because of the cancer of incompentence that engulfs the place.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Riverside, CA
pros: You meet good friends, great PTO time, benefits. I have met many interesting customers as well being a banker and some also become friends. They want you to build "relationships" with customers so that is also good. The company is almost in every state so it it easier to move to another city or state even.
cons: Very sales aggressive which stresses the team out. High sales goals and upper management pressures the bankers and tellers.. You can be MICRO managed at some branches. Getting promoted is not about "what you know" its all about "who you know"

pros: You get wonderful perks and great benefits. Tuition reimbursement and the employee EAP is a great asset to the company. They also have financial assistance for employees facing difficult times.
cons: The only way to advance in this company you have to either know someone or be a spy, telling anything and everything that you see going on around you. This is especially in the corporate office.

pros: Great supervisor, relaxed atmosphere, casual dress code.
cons: Horrible Training for 6 weeks, adherence is way overkill I have to document every moment away from my desk off the phone out of Que which is extremely annoying.

pros: Easily move around company after a year in a position (after applying and interviewing).  Extremely flexible in my area, in terms of work times, working from home, scheduling PTO, etc.  Coworkers are high caliber. Projects are numerous.  Technologies span a wide array.  Depending on your role, you can do a ton.  Very socially responsible company, especially in the diversity and LGBT space.  I am very proud of the great work this company does for the community, and for openly taking a progressive stand on these issues.  There is a real desire to be innovative and serving external and internal customers.  It would have to be an extraordinary opportunity to get me to leave.
cons: Career path is B.S.  There are reorgs every 18 months, a constant shuffling, so it would be hard for any manager to actually know you.  I have had over a dozen managers in ten years.  I have never had a development plan in my ten years here.   They have a stupid regional "midpoint" compensation system and odd HR job categories that do not match market.  I went a few years without a raise because I was over the midpoint, and since I was reorg'd so often, I could not find a manager able to move me up, and there are very openings above my level.  It is too hard to get promoted in certain HR categories like Database Analyst 6 and Systems Architect 6, Analytics Manager 5, etc.  Bonuses are not that great either.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Frisco, TX
pros: You cannot beat banking hours. For the most part you would get 2 weekends off a month. Out the door by 6 unless your branch closes at 7. Good medical benefits and 401 K.
cons: They almost put no consideration into the traffic of the branch. You could have 2 people walk in all day but they will still expect you to hit all of your sales numbers. Customer Service & Sales Rep (CSSR) does all the grunt work of a teller but has, for the most part, all the sales goals of a personal banker. Do not get paid as well as a banker.

job_title: Consumer Loan Underwriter III in Orlando, FL
pros: Structured, significant additional income from overtime, good team members, career opportunities, good benefits.
cons: Inflexible corporate environment, metric driven, quality is verbally encouraged but production is rewarded/overvalued, sweatshop mentality, insufficient support for additional time needed to review high risk loans, no work life balance, weak management team, distracting work environment, cube farm.lack of leadership.

job_title: Consumer Loan Underwriter III in Lombard, IL
pros: Large company with seemingly endless opportunities for advancement and career growth.  Even if you work in a smaller office or a city in which Wells does not have a large presence you could possibly relocate with the company or to move into a higher role across the huge nationwide footprint.  Publicly traded company creates a competitive atmosphere in which Wells Fargo wants to pay for and retain top talent.  A comprehensive benefit package with affordable costs to employees at all levels.  Even in the wake of recent media coverage I personally have no doubts on the integrity or vision of the board, the CEO and executive leadership.
cons:
The office I am in is very understaffed.  We have mandatory overtime which has been going on for years and working the long hours, early morning, late nights + traffic commuting is draining and eats up free time.  I know they are trying to hire more but not a lot of qualified applicants for the specific work we do here.  Not a con, but in spite of this I feel the pay here in our region is VERY competitive.  
Technology can be a problem.  Wells has its own IT group developing most of the proprietary internal applications we use (which is mostly a good thing) however there can be pesky work-arounds for issues and new version rollouts are always a pain.  It just requires more work for us front end employees when we are already overloaded.

pros:
People WERE their competitive advantage
Vision and Values USED to be true
Most employees are good people
cons:
Culture changed over the past 10 years to very sales driven
No consideration to past performance - produce or you're out
Execs always cooking up schemes to get more business - some more ethical than others
Middle management now just henchmen for the execs - displaced many good people
High pressure sales culture is evident throughout the bank, not just at the branch level
Many more employees affected than the 5,300 fired for unethical tactics

pros: Nice benefits, pay is decent, team members are usually amazing people to work with. If you get into a great team where everyone follows the rules and cares then it would be 5/5 across the board. But there is always that one corrupt manager somewhere.
cons: Managers can be very corrupt. They will give you a list of policies that you're not allowed to do then break it themselves then blame it on you. My manager was stealing money but fired me instead for calling him out on internal ethicsline. The company says they value their team members but push comes to shove where they have to take ownership of their mistake they will drop you in a heartbeat and blame you.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Wells Fargo has a great culture. Majority of employees are driven and willing to help others realize their career goals when help or advice is sought. There are endless opportunities across various lines of business to advance one's career.
cons: The general perception is that the bank is extremely conservative. I would not necessarily view this as a negative but that perception can impact how other banks or companies perceive your experience if you are looking to make a change later in your career. For example, if you want to move into cash flow lending, the general conservative attitude results in Wells passing on many cash flow deals which can limit this type of transaction experience.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Vacation Time is good.   The health insurance is great.    Company give a partial match with 401K
cons: Wells Fargo never learns it's lessons.  We want to earn the trust of the customer and earn their loyalty, but we place extremely stringent guidelines on the customer for loans, we continue to push the cross-selling features and we still find ways to extort fees.    Management is constantly micromanaging and pushing staff to unreasonable goals.

pros:
- Great pay (I am receiving nearly 10k more than the other starting analyst)
- Big 4 bank name recognition
cons:
- Liars (they lied about what the job entails--this is suppose to be rotational program but it was not; plus the work isn't very quantitative.)
- Bad Hours (this is all dependent on the team and my team have hours similar to IB during a slow deal/transaction period).
- Stupid Managers (micromanaging managers in this department.

review_title: Great company, not so great leadership
pros: Wells Fargo Bank vision and values are great ad the company truly cares for their customers but the message is distorted as it trickles down the upper leadership vine. Good benefits for employees but the pay is not great when you are in lets say mid-state of your career.
cons: annual pay increases are about 1%, incentive packages do not align with what you can control, at least in my role. Favoritism is played. Not really a lot of help when you need career advice; have websites to visit but maybe an actual person to talk to would be more beneficial. My manager is not to savvy at giving career advice

pros: The pay is great for the area - and the benefits are excellent.
cons: Constant badgering from customers - this is a given considering it's a call center - but you also get hammered each day on your stats from your supervisor, and their manager - and it's never good enough.  Favoritism is alive and well here.  If your supervisor likes you, you can get away with murder, but if they don't, or you do one thing to make them upset, they hold a grudge and will find a way to fire you.  I've seen it happen way too many times.

review_title: Wells Fargo Bangalore : Pathetic Policies for Employees : Poor Work Culture
pros:
Would try to be as true as I can. 

# Infrastructure (Facility, Cafeteria and Other Infrastructure) - The best you would have ever come across.
# Transport Facilities
# Flexibility. Good work-life balance.
cons:
# Poor HR policies. 
# No support to the employee who is leaving the organization and time taking full and final settlement process.
# Lethargic Work Culture
# First level managers are like figurines. Senior Management is making the place a hell to work.
# Work Culture. People have less work to do. Hence they spend time doing politics and spoiling the atmosphere for hard workers.

review_title: FinTech is for a bank trying to catch up to popular tech trends in the industry
job_title: App Systems Engineer in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great Coworkers, Flexible schedules, Engaging work, Solid Company. Room for personal growth. Managers that want to help you become the best employee possible.
cons: Process oriented. Many processes are undocumented or have outdated documentation leading to being getting fresh with you when you fill out the wrong form or fill out a field incorrectly. not being addressed, accountability of shared services groups (if you don't have a good relationship with your assigned support team member, good luck trying to get anything done in a reasonable amount of time and effort).

pros:
Excellent training.  The company is known in the industry for solid sales training.  There are few companies in the country that expect such a drive from their employee and still give the resources and training to accomplish what they ask.

In addition, typically the work schedule will be accomodating to your life.  Many people attend school or have family functions that they work around.  This typically is not much of a hinderance.
cons: Moving out of the retail sector is difficult.  There are many different arms of the corporation and moving within one or the other is relatively easy, but if you want to make a move between divisions it typically will mean a paycut which may be untenable.

review_title: Constant changes in IT bode well for contractors
job_title: Business Systems Consultant in Chandler, AZ
pros: Some skills can not be outsourced, so those lucky enough to be in management support positions, key technical and development areas and/or work in the Scottsdale location are "safe".  Constant realignment, system upgrades and mergers also help to keep the body count of contractors high.
cons: Maintenance skills can easily be outsourced to India.  They are trying, but haven't quite been successful in using off-shore talent for the bulk of project staff.   FTEs are like tenured professors in that even if they are incompetent, you still need to work (& sometimes be supervised) by those less knowledgeable.

review_title: A Lot of Responsibility, but Not Too Much Respect
job_title: Business Relationship Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Tons of responsibility.  Ability to multi-task and run your own business.  You get to meet business owners in every imaginable industry, learn about their businesses and what makes them successful, and then help them out as their banker.
cons: Tough to get promoted.  It's a customer focused job, but we're treated like salespeople by management, and our customer service and credit underwriting skills - which are essential for this job - are often ignored by management that are typically only interested in whether or not we achieve our sales goals each quarter.

job_title: Technical Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
1. Working remotely, VPN was good.
2. Helpdesk were not outsourced, but rather located in USA
cons:
1. Lack of formal processes and procedures
2. Lack of adequate planning 
3. Lack of communication and testing when rolling out new internal tools
4. Banking industry I.T. departments value is not recognized as is Silicon Valley I.T. departments. A bank is not a technology company so I.T. is viewed, treated, and funded differently. However, without I.T. the back would not be competitive and go out of business.  
NOTE: My review is on Banking I.T. only. Just reading reviews suggest Banking retail positions in Wells Fargo are good, and that the company is doing well.

pros:
health insurance is great
work/home balance fairly decent
cons: its all about the metrics, yes its a business that needs to make money but it doesn't matter how well you respond to customer inquires if you don't offer a "solution" on every call you arecoached", if you miss the sales goals even by 1 sale or miss the handle time goal even by 1 second not only do you not bonus but you are but on escalating warnings until fired.  Everyone is so concerned and stressed about meeting goals to keep their jobs that the customers are forgotten.

pros:
Flexible hours, good for college students. 
Helping people solve their financial problems daily can be rewarding. 
Benefits are great (healthcare,paid time off, 401K)
cons: As a teller your number one priority is to make sales. If you are making and exceeding your districts sales goals who will be treated great. There is very little emphasis and recognition for individuals' strengths and positive attributes, the deciding factor in promotions is your numbers. Often times goals seem unattainable (you would think the higher ups would take it as a signal if large amounts  of tellers in a district aren't making sales goals). Despite the high sales goals, management continues to raise goals every year. Pressure from management leads to tellers becoming high pressure salesmen, and the customers notice.

review_title: Used car salesman is the approach Wells Fargo has to doing business.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Arlington, VA
pros: Direct management does a good job of communicating changes that there getting from the top. Employs work hard and for the most part look out for one another.
cons: Quantity VS quality business model. Micromanagement to the point of hourly phone calls that take  10 minutes and all the employs away from helping out customers other than tellers. Wells Fargo does not value it's customers or employs. It is a business but a very cold one with Wells Fargo taking over Wachovia.

pros:
Good benefit (health insurance, dental insurance, vision, 401K)
Paid time off increased after 3 years working with the company
cons:
Unreasonable sale goals (increase every year with no additional payout)
Unrealistic customer service level (some customers will get a call to rate our service about their visit at the bank, 1 as the lowest and 5 as the highest, each customers will rated our service from waited time to making them feel welcome. If we get anything less than 5 then it is automatically consider to negative score on us which we will get write up for it.)

review_title: Your experience will depend on your branch and team. What you make of it is what you get out of it.
pros: WF is great at moving up its team members. This is definitely the place to be if you want to grow.
cons: Sales goals are ridiculous. The amount of pressure from top to bottom gets old very fast.

review_title: Overall its not too bad.  The people are friendly but it is kind of a challenge to move up.
job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist in Coon Rapids, MN
pros: Decent pay, friendly work environment, steady work, the managers are not super strict.  You also get to work on your own without having to report every single thing to managers and they're not always looking over you back.
cons: The work can be a bit tedious, there is constant changes to processes, it can be challenging to move up, sometimes the work is super slow (makes the day go by slow).  Also when it is slow there is a feeling you could be let go at any time.

pros: good benefits, typical of most large corporations--health, dental, life insurance, generous personal time off, flexible spending accounts, tuition reimbursement, and" they say they have" work-life balance
cons: Production-driven environment in all 3 positions that I have held. If production is easily attainable, they raise it (as one manager said, "too many people were getting high performance reviews/bonuses, so they had to raise the production quota"). Quantity over quality and family.  Promotions based on who you know, not what you know.

pros: The benefits were great. There can be flexible if you need a day off. But beware that the management trumps you as far as that goes. Of course they always approve their days off and you can pick what is left
cons: You get two reviews per day.  Basically, you are under a microscope and have someone breathing down your neck all day. I was unable to take my break, even though their favorites had already taken a break and lunch. You never doing a great job. They always have something negative to say about your performance. They say there is a big turn over because people are being promoted. I found out from the person that was there the longest, that the big turnover was due to the management there. I would not recommend this job to my worst enemy.

review_title: Great part-time job as a college student
pros: It looks great on your resume as a college student, very fun environment, and pays much better than minimum wage jobs waiting tables. Customers really respect you when they come in.
cons: Not much room for advancement if you are only working part time, and the retail employees aren't paid very much...even a store manager is probably paid no more than $50-60k a year, even though their job is incredibly stressful and they shoulder a lot of responsibility. Also, quite a bureaucratic environment, sales are definitely pushed for...I felt a lot of the time that team members were pushing for sales even if it was something that wasn't beneficial to the customer.

review_title: Overlays and underwriting make it impossible to succeed
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Annandale, VA
pros: Upper management wants to micromanage the LO's; however, local managers are more relaxed. People at the office are great people to work with.
cons:
Overlays make our loan programs inferior to our competitors. 
Loan processors are probably the worst in the industry. They just don't process the files at all but also  manage to screw things up. LO's are expected to process about 90% of the files. 
It takes 6-10 days to get a rate extension approved, and even if it's the bank's fault they still force the borrower to pay for it. 
Bad reputation makes it difficult to build new relationships.  Over 50% of the LO's have quit within the past 6 months.

job_title: Loan Document Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: One of the best reasons for working here is name value. Wells Fargo Home Mortgage is the leader in the industry.
cons:
Underwriters seem under trained and extremely nit-picky. Expect to work overtime--for no pay. Management knew we were working hours over our designated time; but you couldn't list that time on your time sheet because it wasn't approved. Totally unrealistic expectations from Regional Management regarding turn time. Loans took 60 to 120 days to close. No lie. 

Training Highlight: Company flies new employees out to other states for one week training on AS400 (DOS) mortgage origination software that is antiquated and archaic. The one week is insufficient; as one wrong keystroke will derail anything you've attempted to enter.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Vienna, VA
pros: This was a good first job coming out of college. It is a steady pay and I met some of the greatest people there. You will also learn a lot about finance and the banking industry as a whole. This also has a good career path should you chose to go that avenue.
cons: Turn over is high. You should realize that this is a sales job. If you do not like sales, this is not the place for you. Also managers put a lot of pressure on you to make your daily sales quotas.

review_title: Allows for promising growth, but with small recognition.
job_title: Loan Document Specialist V/Team Lead in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: I was able to grow within the company to a leadership position. This only took me 2 years and the training was vast. They have wonderful team members who work there and it makes for a sort of "family" feeling. The benefits package is extensive and one of the best that I have seen.
cons: Recognition is a little hard to come by, unless it is formally done. The leadership within my group in particular was almost "forced" (for lack of a better word) to hand out recognition on w weekly basis.

review_title: It's all about meeting your numbers! Sales, sales, and service!
pros: Decent benefit, the company matches the 401K. Room for growth because people quit left and right! If you stay with the company, you will move up. Pay is okay. That being said, it's not enough for the amount of pressure the company puts on you. We need more money!
cons: Lot of pressure. You have to meet your goals. It's all about sales. Plus you have to deal with angry people who like to yell at you from time to time. Plus incompetent managers.

pros: Challenging, good benefits, high potential for promotion (due to high turnover.)
cons: You're expected to be a product pusher.  Customer relationships go out the window and your sole and primary focus is on how many "cores" you can push on a single client.  Work-Life balance was terrible,  there were plenty of times that I did not even leave the branch until 7 PM because I was trying to finish up my "service" work that I had to brush off to concentrate on my "sales" work.  Management is not concerned with the employee, only the employee's numbers.

job_title: Bank Teller in White Plains, NY
pros: Good job to start with .  This company offers good training and great benefits.  Professional environment at all times.
cons: Management is not the best.  If you are a mother or a college student with a really demanding career this might not be the job for you.  This job requires flexibility, your work schedule may change within a 24 hour notice.  For a full time you should know that the bank will need you there 6 days of the week.. You might be entitle to some flex time but at the end of the week you might end up a little stressed out.

pros:
paid time off and access to human resources.
ability to see your pay stubs early in the week you are  due your paycheck
ability to see if you are on task to retire comfortably with your 401k account
cons:
human resource complaint policy is not always confidential if you have an issue with senior management and want to report it anonymously.
pay does not match performance level as well as there is a cap on the amount of your raise when you transfer departments

job_title: Lead Teller in Newport Beach, CA
pros: I enjoyed working at WF for 6 years. The customer interactions were great and I made life long friends from my coworkers.
cons: Branch managers turn around so quickly that it was hard to set up career goals/paths. Also, because of the constant turn around our yearly reviews were generally done by strangers. This resulted in very low pay raises year after year. During my 6 year period there my pay barely increased by $2 and I had received a promotion during my third year.

pros: Most customers were very nice as well as many employees. I liked the program that they used for the most part. The hours were ok. If you are good at selling, you will probably go far.
cons: The program was alright, but you had to go back and forth between 3 screens (not horrible but time is short). There was a constant push for sales, never ending push. All we could do as the Teller was try to tell someone about a product (credit card, checking account, savings, etc), then the customer would go to the banker and hear more. Also a big push for credit cards and I can't push credit cards on people that I see struggling with their bills already. Working here went against my morals, I didn't like it, couldn't do it, had to leave.

review_title: Lots of Work with Little Training
pros: Learned a lot here that helped to fast-forward my career by 3-4 years. Their balance sheet is massive which provides a lot of opportunity in the leveraged finance space.
cons: I only learned by being thrown to the lions and making mistakes. They always said "Ask questions in the beginning, but not too many", which led to analysts being very careful about asking questions and trying to learn more. Also, there was quite a bit of bureaucracy.

review_title: It's Great If You're Good at Sales and Enjoy Being Micro-managed
pros: Wells Fargo offers health insurance and paid VSP time even if you only work part-time. They are generally ok with switching shifts and are accommodating if you need to take time off.
cons: Wells Fargo is a retail bank, meaning you have to "sell" checking accounts, credit cards, etc. You have a quartet quota to make on these "sales," and if you aren't hitting your numbers, managers will hover over you and evaluate you and then sit down with you and go into detail about every portion of the review. They micro-manage to the extreme. On my last day of work, they made me do an exit interview on a conference call with corporate. They even micro-managed me quitting.

review_title: Wells Fargo India - The Big Flop Show
pros:
EUS Managers are approachable. Contact them directly for any issues.
Glassdoor prompted for writing at least 20 words for Pros. What to write, when there are no pros ?
cons:
1. No latest technology 
2. Concept of Skill Centre is disgusting
3. HR are puppets under the Managers
4. Dirty politics to the height
5. Less Salary and Hike of 1%
6. Managers bad mouth about the Team in front of other Teams
7. Cost cutting-No Lunch, No Outing
8. Work from Home available for the people who are expertise in buttering their Managers
8. Everyday evening calls with EUS
9. EUS Team and Managers are far more better than Indian Team and Manager
10. Wrong feedback is provided to EUS by the Indian Manager
11. Favouritism is observed 
12. Micro management-Each swipe in and swipe out detail is analysed

review_title: Lot of pros and some very serious cons.
pros: Flexible work hours. Very knowledgeable partners. Good work life balance. Technology perks are on par with industry leaders; if not better.
cons: Using a market reference price for each level and using that as a basis for performance hikes. Because of that even if somebody gets a good performance rating; the hike is sub-par even when compared to the organizational average.

review_title: A very good company to grow with
pros:
Excellent pay!
Encouraged to move up and grow with the company. 
No sales goals.
Benefits & 3 weeks paid time off for part-time and new employees.
Recognition at work via email and in person. 
Easy to understand policy & procedure. 
Resources always accessible when needed.  
Feel like a valuable part of the team. 
You get to meet all kinds of people, and get to know your regular clients.
Supportive management ( in my experience )
cons:
Repetitive daily tasks ( not really a con )
Encountering difficult customers who don't always know what is best and/or ethical. 
Encountering customers who don't understand the limitations of a teller's role within this bank.

review_title: Old tech and red tape, but really chill
job_title: Applications SYSTEMS ENGINEER in Charlotte, NC
pros: Wells Fargo is a giant company and experiences vary greatly. The work life balance I experienced there was fantastic.  You could work from home occasionally, there wasn't much pressure to stay late or work through the weekends. Everyone was super happy to be there. The bureaucracy (some people don't like the red tape) did function to ensure that employees were treated fairly.
cons: It's not a technology company. The main applications that the bank depends on were patchwork assembled and maintained by team after team of contractors trying to maintain what had become a rats nest.  There was a decent amount red tape that prevented people doing anything new or innovative.

review_title: Some benefits are generous; not ideal for working parents; don't plan on working your entire career here.
job_title: E-Business Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: PTO is generous - 25 days for new hires, 30 days after 10 years, 35 days after 15 years.  Compensation is respectable - obviously, you would always like more, but realistically, I believe it's fair.  We've also saved a lot of money by taking advantage of discounts on bank products.
cons: Often touted as one of the best places for working mothers, many divisions do not provide the flexibility needed for a proper work/life balance for any parents.  Individuals with years of experience in one field are not respected - they would rather see you move into different departments after a year or two of service rather than dedicate yourself to something you love.

review_title: If you don't mind sales and cold calling, Wells Fargo is a great place to work.
pros: Good Hours and a decent salary. The call centers are open 24 hours and I heard that they can pay a little more than in stores due to the weird hours. The job does require a lot of responsibility and you must also be very meticulous, both as a teller and as a personal banker. Bonuses are given, but only if you meet your sales goals for the quarter.
cons: Too much sales pressure. Sales meetings every week and the pressure never lets up; it seemed to be more important than helping customers. You will also get your fair share of angry customers.

pros: Benefits.  Very attractive benefit package.  Currently working 25 hours yet I'm still receiving benefits.  I've been retired, but with the cost of health benefits this is a great place to work part time and still have benefits.  I have been thinking about moving to washinton mutual because I've been told they have really good benefits there too.  If you've heard that let me know.  I would also say that Wells Fargo has the really good computer programs they are easy to use and unlike other banks i've worked at these systems are easy to learn.
cons: Sales ... sales ... sales.   If your geared toward sales than this is the place for you.

pros: They hire smart, respectful, responsible people.  Managers are very approachable and willing to share information.   They are very flexible with work/life balance issues and the benefits are outstanding.   There is room for mobility, both in terms of promotions and lateral moves to cross-train.  Employee morale at Wells is substantially better than many other companies.  There is (or was for me) flexibility to telecommute as needed; as long as the work is done, everyone is happy.
cons: Pay is on the low side of average.  Parking in San Francisco costs a lot of money and isn't subsidized as it is with my current company.

pros: Good benefits, good amount of vacation time, some flexibility with working hours. Can be a good position if you like sales or work in the back office.
cons: High pressure sales position. If you do not meet your sales goals, you will be staying at night making phone calls. You need to report about three times a day to let management know where you stand on meeting your sales for the day.

review_title: nice people, but 10 years behind everyone else
job_title: Middle Office Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: The firm retains everyone...I mean everyone...So there is little risk of getting fired.  People are VERY nice and like to look for the better solutions.  The firms is strong but not as strong as everyone thinks. Perfect place for family life and simplicity
cons: VERY behind in terms of technolgy, and even in common business practice.  Company does not like to take risk, thus hinders growth.  Very old school in culture and cannot maximize the true potential of its employees.  Merger will take another 4 years to fully complete

review_title: it's a sales job. In most situations that's not a good thing.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Sacramento, CA
pros: the pay is okay, the benefits are good and you get paid time off or vacation time. When you are hitting your numbers the job is bearable.
cons: the sales pressure can be hard to deal with, and it is at all levels. If you do move up the sales pressure follows you. Selling checking accounts to people with checking accounts is a big part of the job. You are expected to do a financial questionaire for every customer you sit with which can be a annoyance for both you and the customer.

review_title: The worst employee experience I've had in my career.
pros: Health Benefits are a plus
cons: Direct Management has no regard to employees. They expect you to work after hours without no prior notice. District Managers and Store Managers make a very unhealthy environment emotionally to work in. If they want to fire you, they will make up any excuse and new rules to officially fire you without regard to explain to employees if they can help them in their situation to provide a better environment. They have little to no respect for their employees and there is a high turnover rate with Wells Fargo because of it but no one wants to point fingers and resolve the real problem.

review_title: The group was great, but the manager I had was out to get me fired without helping me succeed from the date of hire.
job_title: Marketing Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: The people that work there are generally nice and helpful.
cons: If you get on the wrong side of people you work with they will do what it takes to get rid of you.  I was there for only 4 months because of the people I worked directly with.  My boss could not help me do my job and quickly made me an enemy.  I think my situation would have been different had I worked with another group.

review_title: Don't get stuck in a bad division/group you will be there forever!
job_title: Internal Wholesaler in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Generally the bank is supportive of all minorities and that goes a long way with me.
cons:
There are some very unscrupulous managers/VPs in groups that do not have clear profit centers and support the branches.  They run through bodies like water and care little for honesty or employee retention.  Very poor reflection on this organization.

Also they send their tellers out in short skirts or tight clothes (manager requested) to bring in new business at a car wash or mall.  They should not have to denegrate themselves for the minimal wages they earn.  They have gotten in trouble for this and still it occurs.

review_title: Extreme amount of sales pressure to meet your daily goals and it is never good enough. All they care about is sales!
pros: Good benefits, easy to move up with no education needed, money can be good if your good at sales and are a shark and not afraid to sell your soul.
cons: The pressure they put on you for sales makes it to where you start screwing people over to just to meet your daily sales goals even when you know that the people your doing this to don't really need all these extra accounts. The sales are so crazy that you start to lie to people about what they are signing up for and you take advantage of their negligence and naiveness.

review_title: Ethical company, not a place for young people
pros:
I was in the Financial Analyst Program within commercial lending.

-Great work to life balance, decent compensation, nice people, very ethical
cons:
-Not a lot of young and there's isn't much of a corporate culture. 

-The central FAP training is called Credit Camp....it is about as fun as it sounds. Very structured, has a test at the end that ranks you against your peers and you have to discuss the test with your manager. You are required to take two online accounting courses which consume your life outside of work

review_title: Working at the bottom of a huge company.
pros: Compensation was overall not bad. Friendly co-workers, very easygoing branch.
cons: Numbers game at a branch that overall sucked at the numbers game. Because of that, employees who couldn't reach numbers were on the shortlist to be fired because of it. Became a revolving door of people and customers notice when a whole new batch of people show up. Could be different at other branches with better leadership and more incoming traffic.

review_title: Great Opportunity if you are in the right city with a Sr. Partner that wants a partner and not an assistant
job_title: FAIT- Financial Advisor In Training Program
pros: It is an awesome thing to be paid a salary while dedicating time solely to earning career changing licenses. The FAIT program model is great when executed correctly. The program is set up to develop you into a true practitioner with unlimited earning potential over the long haul and windfall bonus potential within the first 2 years. Partnering with the community bank is a no brainer for an aspiring Financial Advisor. The ability to hone your partnering skills opposed to spending time giving seminars is an absolute draw for me. My schedule is flexible although this might not be the case for every FAIT but I would think that most of the FAIT talent across the country is given autonomy when it comes to time management.
cons: You can feel less in control of your career progression as you don't have much leverage as a Junior Partner without a trail of revenue. You tend to have "0" political capital with peers and bank partners as you are viewed as a Trainee due to corporate titling requirements and the need to service almost all clients segments while scrambling to acquire assets in the beginning. Senior partners can view you either as a workhorse to drive revenue for them or a partner to help increase capacity. Make sure you are the latter or you will be entering into a black hole that can potentially ruin your career. The brokerage culture can seem a little stuffy at times. Your peers will each have gigantic egos as if they are the only person to ever make 150k a year. "Attention all Ego Maniac Financial Advisors, there is some 18 year kid coming up with an iPhone app right not that will be a millionaire by year end. Make sure your Sr. Partner has a concrete plan to transfer a substantial amount of his AUM into your rep code before the launch of your production period. If not you will be fighting and scrapping for revenue the same as your independent channel peers that take home double the revenue for the same production. .

review_title: Call Centers are not for most
job_title: Call Center Financial Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Stable company.  Very nice co-workers. Ability to get your foot in the door without having your series 7 before you start.  They do pay you salary while you're studying, so that's very nice.  Plus they pay for all study materials and the licensing itself.
cons: Call Center environment.  I would say 95% of the people in the call center are trying as fast as they can to somehow get out.  In my case, I left the company for another opportunity.

pros: Good benefits, large company usually means more job security. My branch is a great branch, everyone feels like family. Somewhat flexible schedule- start early & end early because you work market hours. And you can't take work home with you, yay!
cons: Large company also means you're ultimately just a number. When wells Fargo advisors used to be Wachovia securities, it used to be all about the clients and doing right by them. Now, it has become too impersonal and bureaucratic. Industry wise...base pay for Client Associates is very low with small increases every year. These firms  expect the Financial Advisors you support to compensate you, but you have to get lucky and get a generous one to make a substantial difference in pay

review_title: Life as a Bank Teller, CSSR and Personal Banker 1
pros: People you work with at Wells are usually very good people. These are the people you can make life long friendships with. If you excel at your job, you will be promoted pretty easily.
cons: Sales pressure is always high. It doesn't matter how well you did yesterday. They want you to become a selling machine even though the products they push are mediocre. Once you hit Branch Manager, it becomes extremely hard to get promoted. Career growth is stale at that point (if you survive that long in banking)

review_title: WFBI low morale and high turnover of staff
pros: City Centre location near several transport options.... ummm... that's about it.
cons:
I worked in the operations dept of WFBI , which is characterised by low morale and high turnover of staff, despite the low volume of trades executed each day. Management seem to be engaged in performance managing full time, well paid staff, out of the company and replacing them with contract staff. Consequently the atmosphere is poisonous and fearful.

Due to the "strong" management in the back office/middle areas, these teams should be avoided if you are applying for a job in WFBI. 

An ex-employee who left on grounds of stress is taking a case against the company in the Labour Court.

All round, not a company you want to work for, particularly in the operations dept.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Ban Phoe Pha
pros: Great company. They really do care about the employees and rather your a young teller or senior banker Wells Fargo will teach the employee a multitude of life lessons for his or her career, or at their next place of business.
cons: Wells Fargo has what some may call a nasty sales culture. Get ready to sell no matter what position you are in and be ready to hit quarterly quotas. Even though I always hit my quotas and my branch always did well, at times I felt stressed and overwhelmed from management to hit sales goals.

review_title: Depends on what you are looking for
pros:
Great coaching and training program
great opportunity to improve customer service skills
cons:
the way the incentive program is set up, it is near impossible to earn a payout for tellers.
half of the support staff you work with i.e. bankers, branch managers, mortgage reps only care about numbers at the end of the day.
It's not about customer service or satisfaction it is all about meeting quota and staying on top so the bankers and branch managers can get their pay out at the end of each quarter.

pros:

pros:

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT

review_title: Working at Wells Fargo is very rewarding and I feel valued and appreciated.
job_title: Account Resolution Specialist I in Roanoke, VA

job_title: Information Security Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros:
I think the pros and cons depend on what team your in , whose your manager, and other factors.
- Flexibility
- telecommute 
- Good benefits and programs
- Good for graduates getting their career started
- Decent pay 
- Decent pto
cons: The growth is very limiting based on what team your in , thats why many leave the company.Most who stay is either because they cant afford to leave, too  close to retirement or have been in a team so long that their skillset is only in one exactly area. Bad managers make people leave companies and sadly there is nothing much you can do but either leave or manage it.

review_title: Easy job, good place to work

cons: Pointless policies, cumbersome management style, lack of sufficient incentives, upward mobility leaves more to be desired

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA

they need appropriate training in human relations and  how to really be a manager ! Most are just someone  who moved up by cross selling lots of products!

review_title: Not a good job for recent college grad, bad structure and training
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Newnan, GA
pros: I liked the people I worked with.....that is the only Pro
cons: You make $12/hour guaranteed for your first 3 months then you are fully commission so you get that same $12/hour as a draw against whatever you make, so essentially you better make at least 2 grand a month in commission or you will be in the infamous "hole" and you will never get out. This is not a good job or career for a young college grad with no sales experience or mortgage experience. Also, real estate agents and other related professional services absolutely hate Wells Fargo and other big banks.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Frederick, MD
pros: Great benefits including health insurance ($60ish biweekly for me + children with a $6500 deductible, no copays for regular visits), dental insurance ($15 biweekly), plus other options to include 401(k), life insurance (up to 10x salary), plus you start out with 18 days PTO and after two years you get to 23 days PTO plus 8 paid holidays including 2 personal holidays. Also PAID leaves of absences that don't come out of your PTO balance - critical caregivers leave (up to 5 days), primary caregiver parental leave (16 weeks), secondary caregiver parental leave (4 weeks), short term disability (6 weeks), long term disability, etc etc. The benefits are why I haven't switched to a job closer to home.
cons: Boring repetitive work. No challenge.

review_title: Good benefits, pay and room to grow
pros: Company does care about employees and offers a competitive pay, PTO, 401k etc. They come through in times of needs such as a natural disasters.
cons: Busy days such as the first of the month can be hectic. Lots of work and a lot of room for error as a teller. You need to know how to focus on keeping your cashbox in balance and minimizing risk for you and the customer.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Charleston, SC
pros: The name recognition, the benfits are AWESOME and the job provides so much flexibilty to grow at your own pace. T recognitionhere is always potential to capture more business and the sky is the limit. The support of the management is good and they are always willing to go along to help you out when necessary. The name recognition is a large part of why my job is so easy to sell to everyone. The name is a security blanket in a field that is very unstable right now and cutomers and builders alike are more comfortable than ever coming to Wells Fargo!
cons: Commission can be scary at times

review_title: Great benefits and hours, but the politics can be frustrating.
pros: Wonderful benefits package, even if you're only working part time.  To start, you receive 20 paid vacation days per year, plus 6 federal holidays off.  Great hours to work--sometimes half a day on Saturday, but never evenings or Sundays.
cons: Because Wells Fargo is such a huge organization, it can be very political.  By the time communication reaches a branch level, you sometimes feel as if corporate has no idea what's going on in the retail stores.  Numbers are HUGELY important, and sales are often more important than what's best for the customer.

pros: Wells Fargo has fantastic benefits, with a great 401(k), numerous medical plans, a lot of vacation time, good banking benefits, friendly work environment.  All of the time off is lumped into Paid Time Off instead of having separate sick days and vacation days.  Well managed company, overall.
cons: Wells Fargo has the same downsides of working for any large corporation.  Sometimes you get lost in a numbers game.  Individuals don't often have much feedback.  Management is highly paid, while "regular" workers are sometimes underpaid and under-appreciated.  Again, I believe these are issues that every big company has, though, so I don't solely blame Wells Fargo for this.

review_title: Wells Fargo Private Mortg. is a great place to work!!

review_title: Like many jobs, it all depends on what team you're part of.

review_title: When I was there, management made a great impression on me... they are the only company ever to do so.

review_title: Promotion and progress a little random, great work life balance is  eroding, broad range of opportunities a plus.

review_title: Good experience if you are looking for an OK job

review_title: Loved the people, not the job.

job_title: Customer Saleas and Service Representative in Fort Pierce, FL

review_title: good company to start a career with

Forget about family and a life out of welfargo. Once u r there THEY DONT CARE ABOUT U AS A HUMAN BEING.

job_title: Project Manager in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Great employees but too many inexperienced managers throughout the company

job_title: Financial Analyst in Palo Alto, CA

cons: WF is BIG! No, HUGE. You can easily get lost in the sea of people and when it comes down to it, unless you are a top performer (talking 1-5%) you are really a small fish in a big pond (more like an ocean).

review_title: extremely stressful as sales are more important than customer service

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Broken Arrow, OK

pros: Decent health benefits and they do give you a lot of vacation if you don't need to use it because you're sick.

pros: Clear expectations of what is expected in your job assignment.  Abundance of tools to make the job as easy as possible.

pros: Working as a teller is a comfortable, decent environment for those new to customer interactions and sales work. I enjoy telling people about new opportunities for their accounts and where they can succeed financially. My branch expects you to do more than just cash checks and run deposits and I'm glad, as it prepares you to excel and move forward with the company.
cons: Certain wells fargo policies that are fairly redundant or bothersome get in the way at work, and customers occasionally get frustrated/agitated with you over store/company rules you're not responsible for or able to change.

review_title: I have learned a lot working at Wells Fargo and gain a lot of experience that will help me in my future
job_title: Loan Verification Analyst II in San Antonio, TX
pros: Wells Fargo has great benefits and opportunity for growth and that is also a company that hones in divercity and inclusion

pros:
Pto, paid holidays, 401k, tuition reimbursement. Paternal and maternal leave.

job_title: Marketing Consultant in Des Moines, IA

pros:
Great healthcare and wellness program. You can earn up to $800 for HSA
Decent PTO

I only made $15 an hour, even though I have a masters degree. In my interview, the two managers interviewing me kept saying you can move up really fast.
