Miscommunication among managements due to limited English skills.
Ignorance managers reluctant to learn their co-workers' daily processing.
Strong favoritism in the team.
The more capable you are, the more work for you, but those who just swing their days still get better salary.

review_title: Used to be a decent place to work
pros: Loved the people on the team I worked with, and most of the customers we supported. Some very good people work here. Compensation is fair.
cons: Bureaucracy, constant re-organization, restriction of access/tools without corresponding restriction of responsibilities, lip service regard for personal well-being and time management, little attention paid to advice/recommendations, unrealistic work loads with irrelevant timelines, excessive and superfluous fixation on corporate training unrelated to job function. Changed managers 4 times in 6 years.

review_title: Fake only doing what they need to do to keep the bank out of the media
pros: None to report at this time, currently looking for a new job after all these years of service. such a waste
cons: overcompensating for their past mistakes, also in the past to get promoted you had to sell the customer 101 products. In order to get a promotion, you have to be mgrs favorite or you are stuck. Absolutely no work life balance

pros: worked with some great people in a great atmospher
cons:
Pay was 100% commission but you received a draw that you had to pay back out of your commission checks. Once you get behind after a bad month or 2 in a row it is almost impossible to catch up. Any deal that you do get you are going to be fighting tooth and nail to get it approved by underwriting.  you will spend more time trying to close current deal than finding new clients.

But part of it was I just wasn't ready for that kind of job at that time in my life. I was fresh out of college and did not put in the work and effort it takes to be successful in that business.

review_title: Do not work for Wells Fargo
pros: Recognition is okay but noithing else is really worth mentioning.
cons: Wells Fargo does too much product-pushing. It no longers focuses on the need of the custoemrs. As a result, sales pressure gets out of hand sometimes. Also, compared to similar positions at other companies, pay from wells fargo is also subpar when it comes to salaried positions. With the amount of hours they expect you to work, the hourly pay turns out to be really low.

review_title: Choose wells fargo only if you are desperate for health insurance.
pros: Simply for the health insurance benefits
cons: Extremely low pay....commission or "incentive compensation" is structured in a way so that it is next to impossible to achieve a respectable bonus.  Bonuses, if any, average no more than a thousand dollars per quarter (that is three months).  There is really no incentive to work hard.  It is ridiculous.

review_title: Looking for the very top originators only.  Watch your wallet.
pros: Great marketing programs for Loan Officers. Good training program. Flexible hours. Very little supervision.  The benefits were very good and if you originate a really high number of mortgages you are treated very well.  They are after only the top 5% of loan officers.
cons: Pricing needlessly complicated.  Errors always favor the company.  Not really intetested in you unless you are a superstar performer.  Sink or swim attitude of management. Their processing has to be one of the worse in the industry. Don't even think about sending in FHA or VA loans to their processing center.  They will remain there for eternity.

review_title: In general Wells Fargo is a good employer
pros: Wells Fargo is a big employer so you get chance to work with different business lines such as credit card, auto lending and home equity within one company. You do not need to leave Wells Fargo while still having chance to move to different business lines.
cons: It is too big. Sometimes left hand does not talk to right hand

review_title: Overall, a decent joint to work at.
job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Dallas, TX
pros:
Benefits are outstading at Wells Fargo. Four weeks of paid vacation for starters is awesome. 401K offers a 6% dollar per dollar match, which is not very common nowadays. Salary is adequate when compared to other banks.
There seems to be less of a pushy sales culture at WF when compared to the other big banks-Chase, Bank Of America etc.
cons:
Product pushing to the moon and back. Bankers are told to sell to whomever and wherever they can, whether that person needs to product or not.
Branches are overstaffed with Personal Bankers, some having as many as 6 or 7 for a branch that isnt very busy.

review_title: Always doing what is right does not always make the numbers
pros:
-401k benefits (when the market recovers i suppose)
-vacation days 25+ per year
-my customers, yeah super cheese i know but i genuinely like helping people
-somewhat job security if you can make sales goals
cons:
-inconsistent business practices from branch to branch even though they say we are one wells fargo
-sales goals that are completely out of touch with the current economy
-improperly trained coworkers that are not always looking out for the customers best interest
-the constant threat of losing your job due to sales performance not actual job performance

pros: Benefits are awesome!  You start off with 20 days of vacation!  Awesome culture.  Want their employees to succeed and pride themselves in working in an ethical workplace.  They train you very well and will do anything they can to help you succeed in your position.
cons: Very structured.  You need to be careful of certain employees stealing, they could make it out to seem like you did it!!!  Never go to a brand new store to help open it, they will get no business and it will be very boring!!

review_title: Great place to work if you're a WASP
pros: Lots of great internal learning programs w/in the bank to help you advance. Completing the CMTP (credit management training program) is a rite of passage to reach senior levels of WF.
cons: No transparency, constant change w/ no notification. Although the Wachovia merger has looked good on the books the actual integration from the employee standpoint has been terrible so far. Pay is poor compared to other institutions. Hard to move up if you're in operations, a minority or don't have a masters degree.

pros: It's a good place as any to get your feet wet if you want to get into the financial institutions.
cons: It takes such a long time to get anything done for the customers. it feels as though you are supposed to operate with one hand tied behind your back. Management like to keep you and not help with advancement because there is such a high turnover, they are afraid to lose you.

review_title: Wells Fargo was not a good experience.
pros: The benefits are good and Wells Fargo stock is doing well. The benefits are comparable to similar positions with other banks in the area.
cons: I had been in banking through 3 mergers. Wells Fargo's merger with Wachovia Bank resulted in a lot of incompetency. People that were moved into middle level management had limited experience, and employees with experience were let go. Wachovia was known for caring for its customers and employees. Wells Fargo doesn't care about turn over of employees or customers. Employees are so afraid of being the next one fired, that they come in early and often had to stay till 7 p.m. to call customers. There is no consideration for life outside of the bank.

review_title: great place to work, but very, very conservative
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Atlanta, GA
pros: name brand recognition, excellent training which makes you more knowledgable than the competition.  good work place environment with support from all of your peers
cons: company is very conservative, and so do to the changes in the lending industry, wells fargo has gone over board on their underwriting guidelines.  the compensation package for sales people has been changed for the worse compared to a year ago.  takes a long time to submit, close and fund a loan, which is very frustrating for the consumer and real estate agents

review_title: Horrible place to work, they treat their employees like dirt
pros: 401k match up to 6% is nice. Opportunities for advancement. Competitive salaries. Excellent benefits package offering medical, dental, vision, etc.
cons: The management is absolutely horrible. They only care about how many checking accounts they can get opened. They give you 21+ days of vacation but you can't take it in January, May, or June. They treat their employees like crap. I don't know 1 person that actually likes their job or is proud to work for this company. The commission structure has changed 3 times in the last 2 years and a person making $30,000 in commission before now makes $10,000. They are losing top sales people left and right and replacing them with people with no experience whatsoever

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A large, stable company which is a leader in the field.  It's not going anywhere.
cons: A lot of layoffs and cost cutting measures going on which has most people worrying about whether they will have a job or if they will be doing the job of 3 people if they do keep their job.

job_title: Applications Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I worked in the Internet Services Group of Wells Fargo and it was a terrific place to work.  
The hours were reasonable, good benefits, and an enjoyable group of employees.  
Good budget for software tools so you usually get what you need to get your work done.
Mostly, I really appreciated that Wells Fargo truly seems to want to provide value to employees, customers, and the community as much as they do for investors.
cons:
It's a huge behemoth so things can happen very slowly which can get, perhaps, a bit boring sometimes.  
They are eliminating the San Francisco offices and I sense a degradation in work environment since I left.

review_title: Great benefits and company to get your foot in the door
job_title: Customer Sales and Service Representative in Walnut, CA
pros:
Benefits (health, dental vision, 401k with matching, PTO, other discounts and benefits)
Nice environment for students and young professionals to get experience or make a career.
Professional and straight forward expectations.
cons: Very very very competitive for sales. Sales hungry.

pros: There are a lot of resources to help people, and succeed in this business. Investments, credit, business services: you name it they have it.
cons:
By means of extremely high sales goals, this company pushes its people to give unnecessary products to it's customers. The end goal, I think, is to give it's customers fees to increase the bank's bottom line towards giving it's shareholders a nice dividend.

Forgot about work-life balance. Call nights, saturdays are common and you will come home stressed by repeated threats.

review_title: Conservative company, needs more supervision at branch locations
pros: I work very autonomously, and enjoy a few people I work with. If your lucky you may get FA's who compensate you.
cons: Company is VERY concerned about their reputation, but does not do enough to ensure their reputation with employees and clients at the branch level. If their is poor management (and it is flagrantly know) nothing is done to correct the problem. Manager misuses the resources to benefit only his team. Little to no training offered at the branch level. Very, very little room for growth.

review_title: Good Big Company to work for
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Diversity, great people to work for and with. Growth opportunities are plentiful.
cons: Bonus structure is not the "One" Wells Fargo that upper Management likes to speak to in their language in being in this together.  Like any corporation it's really all about the bottom line and the stock holders.

job_title: Left As Phone Banker II in Westlake, TX
pros: only one bad Supervisor, whom no longer works there. Really was pleased at time I was there many bonuses, and challenges. Hit a base pay, last 5 years no raises
cons: Now heard they took away from employee many referral options, got too strict on points for 1 minute late. Many employees did work hard. After too much time, they too could not get raises. Could not get into higher position, because made them a lot of money in  cross sales and not many new the ins and outs of the system like I did. Worked over 10 years for them

pros: This is a great place to work.  Wells Fargo as a whole really takes good care of it's employees.  6% 401k match and 2% annual bonus contribution is hard to beat as well.
cons: Management for my group is very slow to change and often unwilling to take advice from people who actually have interactions with clients.  This makes it extremely difficult to accomplishment goals that the company sets.  That is disappointing..

review_title: Banking is a great job to have
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Eatontown, NJ
pros: Hours, People, Management, Opportunity to move up, and also a great way to learn about your own banking habits, and also a great way to network with business and consumers.
cons: quota that is not disclosed during hiring procedure, and low pay for the amount of metrics that we have to meet in order to get the payout on advertised commission.  Falsified numbers by opening and closing accounts.  "ADVISED" by management  to convince customers to change their account numbers in order to meet goals.

review_title: Handle A Lot of Cash Without Earning Much
pros: Wells Fargo provides a great training program. The focus on customer service is a great way to develop interpersonal skills. You will quickly learn how to not take things personally.
cons: Income is no were near what is necessary for living in Southern California. There is too much focus on getting solutions. You can only get a decent bonus if you get people to get more accounts, credit cards, and loans/lines. Constantly reading about how much the company is earning is not helpful when an employee can barely make their minimum payments on bills.

job_title: FHA/VA Home Preservation Specialist I in San Antonio, TX
pros: Bonuses were good when obtained, fun environment
cons:
impossible to move up, departments would keep you there if you were of value or higher performer, bonuses are almost impossible, you need to exceeded so many number and metrics. 
Never worked in a job where you can be employed for 3 years there, but feel like every day can be your last. 
The annual employee survey was a joke, they would politic for a month leading up, pretty much brain washing us to ensure we would leave a perfect score, people who didn't, seemed to lose their job in the following quarter

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant Junior in San Francisco, CA
pros: Training, Senior Management, Resources, Ethical Values & Strong Business Processes are the major key factors to making Wells Fargo...Wells Fargo. There are tons of opportunities for people without college degrees, and it's a place where you can succeed if you really work hard, put your head down and invest many years into creating a book of business.
cons: Old Culture, Federal regulations impeding business processes, uber professional working environment (not comfortable/casual), tough commission structure to jump into, and long-term growth.

job_title: Senior Web Developer in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Wells Fargo has great friendly environment with good benefits. I enjoy working in Wells Fargo. I strongly recommend Wells Fargo to others.
cons: There are some people in Wells Fargo who promote people based not on the criteria but because of race and relations. Also because of the race & relations criteria deprive US citizens from competing with the foreign workers. For example the fresh graduate from foreign countries they have better probability to get job in Wells Fargo as compared to fresh graduates from our local Universities. This is the same case with all the other major US companies.

job_title: Digital Marketing Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: They are located in SF downtown... It is the only thing I can think of
cons:
This company is stuck in time. Very obsolete way to work, and very obsolete way to do business. They way to do marketing is 10 years behind.... You won't learn a single thing.... A lot of dinosaurs
Full-time employees are more worried abut titles and offices than work....They treat contractors really bad...Really bad!  At the time I worked there we were 3 contractors, we all left before contract ended... It is a very toxic place to work, with silly arguments, weak managers, people talking behind your back and this silly things... They have nothing better going on! 

Avoid this place! This is the Bay Area, there are thousands of better places to work around you! I actually went to interviews where they knew about how traditional and obsolete is WF so it won't even look good in your resume....

review_title: Been employee with the company for 15 years.
pros: Competitive salaries and benefits; ability to relocate to other positions in different areas of the company (i.e. Mortgage, Brokerage Services, Auto Finance, etc.) and in most cases the company will provide/reimburse for training.
cons: While the job opportunities within the company are plentiful, it is often "who you know" that will get you past the phone interview with HR Recruiter and into a face-to-face meeting, rather than your résumé.

pros: Benefit medical and dental 401k is good.
cons:
To many law suit aganst Wells Fargo. Very bad Bank to work for. 
Wells Fargo Fined $185 Million for Phony Accounts - The Atlantic
Wells Fargo Opened a Couple Million Fake Accounts - Bloomberg View
CEO John Stump resign due to force Branch employee to open 2.5 Millions fraud account.
Justice Department now file law suite against to Wells Fargo for ID theft. All the executive at Wells should go to jail.

review_title: It pays the bills but they have taken so much away
pros: You have the ability to move up with good hard work, determination and networking.  Good PTO times.
cons: Been here going on 13 years.  In that time so many of the things that made this a great place to work is gone.  The place has turned from a booming, hearing everyone on the phone getting things done to a place where you can hear a pin drop.  It is very apparent the discontent among employees.  Raises are yearly and not much if anything.  Profit sharing also has been downgraded considerably.  BUT pays the bills.

job_title: Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lifestyle hours; this is not a company where many people at HQ work after 5pm.
cons:
Senior management (i.e., the CEO and CFO) are "tone deaf at the top." They've blamed the ranks explicitly (on CNBC) and implicitly (issuing a code of conduct to the ranks) when the malfeasance can be traced to the executive suite and perpetrators are moved rather than fired.  

The bank is contracting in business and employees; a terrible time for all.

Mediocrity reins in the ranks as loyalty is valued over performance. That makes this a frustrating company for high performers.

review_title: Where a career goes to perish
job_title: Operational Risk Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: NONE, since I need 5 character words how about NIL, ZILCH
cons:
Legacy culture of a criminal enterprise.  
Risk is taken out of context; to make red's green, make the bank look like they know what they are doing.  
Taxonomies are derived to keep regulators off track but do not help to determine root causes, the regulators are not doing their jobs. 
Bank is moving thousands of jobs to India and the Philippines, yes your american job is being moved to locations where labor is cheaper by up to 2/3rds

review_title: A lot of changes for the sake of change
pros: Pay is competitive, benefits are above or at average levels, large corporation with lots of areas to transfer internally,
cons: Slow moving org., teams all over the map  (limited interactions) in all sorts of clusters (small/medium/large), “same as always” thinking by long-tenured employees, leadership is poor in concentrated pockets of the organization and they somehow thrive under the radar, Top-Heavy in management, changes from a customer-centric “do the right thing” approach (when Tim Sloan was CEO) to “be direct” rhetoric pushed by new CEO. The bank can’t grow because of an asset cap, and ironically you have CITI/BOA/Chase careerists now flooding the executive ranks and working towards “improving” Wells Fargo.

pros: Excellent Benefits, They normally hire from within, so you can grow your career in the retail bank. They will train you really well if you want it.  They have great intentions as a company. They say all the right things all the time. They have great technology.
cons: Large company with lots of politics. You can't move your line of business to easily, so whatever you start at is where you will stay.  they make up coaching and try to fabricate effectiveness through quick and baseless observation. In the past, they used fear as a huge technique.  Most of the managers and personnel are there in some capacity. HR is robost, Change comes only from the top down.

review_title: I love working for Wells Fargo
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The benefits are great, working for Wells Fargo has helped me to realize a dream of owning my own home and has helped me to start saving for my retirement.  Wells has now begun working with the boomers - offering us seminars on how to retire, how to network within the company, how to stay employed after retirement, balancing work and personal life etc.  I only wish I had started working for them earlier in my life.
cons: Sometimes communication of new policies and procedures is not well done, being a big company it is hard to make policies that work for everyone. However that is getting somewhat better.

review_title: An excellent place to expand ones career.
job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Growth Opportunities and excellent training.  The amount of training says a lot about what the company will invest in it's employees.  They strive to have a very diverse and cohesive work place and it shows.  I have worked in a number of large corporations with training programs, and Well Fargo has great follow through which shows in the various levels of management.  Another great trait of Wells Fargo is it looks to promote from within the company first.
cons: Very young workforce in retail positions.

review_title: good opportunity if you like stressful sales
pros: Good opportunity to advance quickly if you enjoy sales. Fair promotions based on your numbers and a good place to start out if you're right out of college and willing to work hard. There's money to be made if you have the ability to earn it.
cons: You continuously fight an uphill battle to bring in customers and sell sub-prime loans. Expect to have a lot of pressure put on you continuously to meet sales quotas. If you can excell here you can sell anywhere. Compensation program was recently changed and will make large bonuses near impossible.

pros: Sound leadership, strong customer-centric culture, discipline in credit standards, and a meritocracy.
cons: The larger a company gets the more it inevitably needs some bureaucracy.  Now that Wells Fargo acquired Wachovia, it must be careful to maintain speed to market without the many layers that come with its larger size.

review_title: Wells Fargo Bank, GOOD BRAND....Too much sales pressure :(
job_title: Personal Banker I in Vacaville, CA
pros: Good Brand, great selection of products and services, lots of branches, salary, 401K and benefits are good!
cons: Constant sales pressure, micro managed, people are forced to game in order to meet daily sales goals.  A lot of stress and tension at work.

pros: We have the opportunity to learn how to communicate affectively with team members and customers. You learn to understand understand how to cross sell and become the "voice" of Wells Fargo. You learn the foundation of banking as a Phone Banker so that you may move forward in any retail banking position.
cons: It's too busy. Those are three words that I say out loud almost every single day. You take an average of 100 calls per day with questions that can easily be answered through other mediums.

pros:
compensation competitive with area firms
ok benefits package
plenty of smart people to learn from
aside from entry level positions, mgmt promotes professional development
cons:
work can become hectic, mostly due to lack of communication
knowledge transfer is low
most top management don't seem to know how to manage their human resource
e.g., as a consultant, we're only brought into meetings at the end of a project or when something doesn't go right
inclusion may be difficult
cultural divide (seems to be the same way with other large companies i worked at)

pros:
Generous PTO
Attractive 401k 
Great place to learn new technologies and develop new skills that will last a lifetime
People that work there are great to work with
Telecommute option in some areas
cons:
Lack of any sort of promotion after 6 years of performing well above my level and getting outstanding reviews. I understand there is a freeze going on and the economy is junk, but I need something more than just a 2% raise and a pat on the back to keep me motivated. Time to move on to a more competitive company. 

Wells Fargo is still going through some major restructuring with the Wachovia merger, so there are massive changes going on. Not the same company I started with 6 years ago.

job_title: Telephone Sales Banker in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-Great pay, national bank, branches in 49 or all 50 states, I believe. 
-Good benefits, dental, vision, health.
-Many banking services, it really can be a one-stop shop for customers.
cons:
-Frontline telephone bankers just transfer customers to sales department for the stupidest reasons, and you're supposed to get a sale out of them. If the person has $4.50 in their account, there is NOTHING that I can offer them.
- Hours. Was given a 12-9 schedule. Made it horrible for work/life balance. 
- "coaching" sessions, you'd listen to your mistakes with manager and would get no feedback on how to improve.

review_title: Cares nothing about the customers, only sales
job_title: Phone Banker I in Charlotte, NC
pros: pay was decent, cafeteria and a food court, decent benefits
cons: Hard to schedule PTO. Better off the calling out. All about sales that really didn't benefit the customer. Management will harass you every hour on the hour if your referral/warm transfer rate was not up to par. You could be on the phone trying to listen to a callers concern and they are steadily trying to talk to you about sales. Please wait until the banker gets off the phone with a caller and then we can discuss whatever. Callers come first.

pros: Generally the people and the culture make Wells Fargo a great place to work.
cons: The company atmosphere was much better when Dick Kovacevich was CEO. Noticed a change when the new CEO came in. I am sure he is primarily there to increase profitability. And of course, the bottom of the pyramid is impacted the most. Dick Kovacevich's influence is probably what still makes Wells Fargo a decent place to work. Also, diversity is heavily preached to the Wells Fargo 'team members', however, to the extent that it is emphasized, it doesn't appear to have impacted the list of executive officers.

review_title: I sure miss the Wachovia days
pros: The pay is decent - the bonuses are very nice.  I got plenty of time off and vacation, but sometimes it's difficult to get it scheduled.  Benefits are good - although healthcare deductible is very high.  In my particular department, my manager was indeed a working manager.  I don;'t know how she did it - when there was a problem she'd be on it all the time.
cons: Depending on which department you work on or which product you support, you can have a great experience or an extremely poor experience.  When you find yourself in a group with a poor experience, you're stuck.  Too many meetings - feel like I'm being micro-managed

review_title: Responsible for collecting necessary docs for successful on time loan closing
job_title: Loan Doc Specialist in Princeton, NJ
pros:
I liked the office atmosphere, as well as the ability to work unsupervised. I completed many tasks that were
not in my job description, and was able to do so. I also learned new computer programs for loan processing
cons: The lack of training in the work environment was taxing. Being a self motivated individual, I sought the answers to my questions.

review_title: WFA is a nice place to work, but I'm not paid what I'm worth.
pros: Co-workers are friendly and there is a focus on team work.  Love the holidays we get off.
cons: Salary.  They expect the FA's to comp you so the base pay is not what it should be, but not all of the FA's comp.  Annual raises are only ~1%-1.5%.  Health insurance premiums that come out of your paycheck are close to the same as before, but now additional out of pocket expenses associated with it have really gone up.  It costs a lot more in the long run to keep your family healthy.  We ended up going on my husband's plan.

review_title: I worked for Wells Fargo for 3.5 years. Great company
job_title: Personal Banker I in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Wells Fargo was extremely flexible by helping me relocate to another state and change jobs titles quickly to accommodate my schedule when taking classes. The benefits were good including insurance plans and 401k options. The hours were typical 8-5 with some Saturdays.
cons: Any position within the retail bank is sales-oriented. I placed more emphasis on customer service as that is what I loved and I was under constant stress from management to "get my numbers up." This made the job not so fun quickly.

review_title: Solid DCM Investment Bank; still trying to its place on Wall Street
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: Lots of deal exposure and broad reach of all products and industries.  Better culture than most on Wall Street.  Growing both nationally and domestically.  Lots of opportunities to transfer within the firm.  Good spot right out of college.
cons: Not a top-notch investment bank but you do get some of the IB egos.  Training is OK but I've heard and seen better.  Some groups including those in TMT and middle markets are absolute DEATH TRAPS!  I've witnessed two analyst firings for just silly reasons.  Exit opps are minimal and senior bankers don't help with outplacement in the analyst program.

pros: The working hours were good. The pay was descent for managers, as well as the benefits. Recognition for goals obtained were good. Good bonus structure. The ability to educate customers and help me gave a sense of purpose.
cons: The stress level of this job is ridiculous! The money is good but you will need to invest in meds to stop from going crazy! The goals are unrealistic and you are forced to sell unnecessary products to customers who really don't need them. Then the customers get fees and you aren't suppose to reimburse them unless its a bank error. Its almost as bad an being a cheesy used car salesman.

pros: When it snows in NJ you are able to work from home with the company equipment.  You get an hour lunch
cons: Your compensation package is salary which means if you work 80 hours one week you are only paid for 40 hours.  IT WILL NOT EVEN OUT WITH ADDITIONAL TIME OFF as they may tell you.  In terms of bonuses or additional compensation for working so many hours the owners tend to find reasons why they shouldn't pay you based on performance or profit loss the company incurred that year.   This job requires you to be on call 24/7/365 and you will work on average 60+ hours a week.

job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great local leadership as far as supervisor and manager. Fair compensation base salary and incentive structure. Cafeteria onsite to help offset the short unpaid lunch period ( 30 minutes)
cons: Procedural implementation that reduces ability to hit sales goals. Hiring of people who are under qualified and incapable of accomplishing there minimum job requirements. Upper management that are out of touch with the day to day challenges of their employees that deal directly with the customers.

job_title: App Systems Engineer in Charlotte, NC
pros: Better benefits than my previous place of employment.  Pay is better than average in the area.  Generally not stressful, if you are good at your job.  If you aren't good, the stress is extreme and you will get fired (eventually).  I consider myself very good at what I do.
cons: Dependent on other teams for various projects when they have no real incentive to deliver to you something timely or with quality.  Management gets yelled at hard for any issues then they seem to take it out on you.

review_title: Great place to learn how to sell
pros: its a great place to learn sales, relationship building, and how to influence people. I learned so much from wells fargo and they pay well, it also has great benefits.
cons: since you're working with small number of people there will be lot of politics. lot of pressure on sales. this job specifically you have to know a lot about everything since you have different partners so being able to leverage all of them is not an easy task. plus you have to know that people that come to the bank either have a problem or they don't know something so you have to fix their problem and also sell them something

review_title: Don't get stuck at this company
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great Benefits, Clear job expectations and path to advancement
cons: A very sad place to work. Had that drab, flourescent, cubicle vibe frequently mocked in movies like Fight Club and Office Space. Management was awful. Picked favorites and did not seem to care about the individual employees or their career goals. You could tell from their tone that they were under a lot of stress but there was a lack of transparency that lead to the feeling that a layoff could happen at any time. Pay was less than stellar and raises barely met the cost of inflation.

job_title: Personal Banker in Mountain View, CA
pros: There is no best thing to work for the company
cons:
Too much of favoritism. if u r favorite to ur manager then only u will grow in this company.
They send other team member for licensing and he just joined 6 months ago because he was favorite of the manager.

where as me working with the company from last 3 years ..they didn't send me for licensing.
Full of racist people in this company . Try to reach top management even they do nothing .

If u want to e favorite of ur manager ...u have to run their errands...buy them lunch ... take them for drinks.

That is probably lot of people left Wells Fargo

review_title: Even when they promote re-building,the amount of micro-management was unlike anything I have experienced.
job_title: Personal Banker II Registered in Coon Rapids, MN
pros: The co-workers I worked with. We all shared in the misery.
cons:
. Micro-managed, my manager treated me like a child. Every morning I had to check in, in the afternoon I had to check in, after we closed I had to check in. Often times I would make a suggestion about segmentation or efficiency,then just get treated like I was not human. I was asked to run a teller window when I haven’t been a teller for years.

. Working every Saturday due to always being short staffed (new hires did not last long)

.Not being able to take vacation when I wanted

review_title: Hyper sales environment, but good for a quick fix!
job_title: Business Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: For all of the faults associated with a sales position at banks, they have an excellent training program with low level advancement that can happen rapidly for even the dimmest candidate.
cons: While the stated goal of the positions in the retail environment is provide customer service and a pleasant experience for customers, the goal of middle to senior management is to push as many products onto the customer as humanly possible. Which turns your daily experience from less of a relationship management roll to a more of a hyper aggressive sales center! "Just think best buy on crack!"

review_title: Keep up the great work, Wells is doing very well as a company, especially in these turbulent times.
job_title: Technical Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The work culture here is relaxed but professional. People are focused on getting the job done but are civil toward each other. I really like the fact that our employer, Wells Fargo, is supportive of our time outside of work. Wells is a philanthropic organization.
cons: Sometimes the greater goal is lost in such a large organization. Process can often slow things down to the point that you wonder if folks understand what the collective goal is. Another area that is a negative is when departments lock horns over process rather than solving the issue. Usually such issues are resolved with senior management becoming involved.

review_title: Positive overall - but management can be cheap
job_title: Business Systems Consultant in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Good benefits - plenty of time off.  I work for Card Services and Consumer Lending, which has a much more laid back culture than the rest of the company, very nice department to work for.
cons: Current management over-values expense management.  It's hard to get much done when management isn't willing to pay for anything.  I've heard that Wells Fargo Financial is a depressing unit to work for from co-workers who have gone there and returned to my business unit later.

pros: Money is fair for the work and the employees are treated fairly by upper management.
cons: All the rah rah from overhead.  I had a serious moral impediment with what the business that this company did.  I understand the risk inherent with some of the clients but the company seemed to want to charge outrageous interest rates to clients that qualified for the best rate going at any other institution.  Further, they tried to leverage the employee's relationship with the client and the perception that the employee is a "trusted advisor" to coerce quality borrowers to make dumb borrowing decisions.  When I tried to explain to management how this doesn't make financial sense (usually with a NPV calculation) they would respond that "we need to let the customer make the decision".  This is why I left the company.

job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Wells Fargo is extremely stable in an extremely shaky financial sector. If you can engage in the scandalous practices necessary to get enough "sales" to keep your job, you will definitely continue employment.
cons: There are good sales environments: this is not one. It's dishonest, the products are inferior and often misrepresented, and overall the place discourages customer service, despite all the lipservice it is paid.

review_title: Job Experience Depends on Your Direct Manager
pros: Generous benefits, tuition reimbursement, vacation time (3 weeks), professional atmosphere.  Company is well-respected and supported with national advertising.  For such a large company, the corporate side of Wells didn't impact our local department as much as I have seen from other companies.
cons: When you do need to contact corporate Wells, there is little communication or support.  Interaction with the HR department is impersonal - through a call center.  We felt like a "drop in the bucket" to Wells after the Acordia acquisition.

review_title: Good Starter Position... Until the division was closed
pros: It is a big name company with competitive products and financial services to customers with many different types of financial needs
cons: At times, the company pushes their products on people for the simple fact of making more money.  As a team member in the Financial division that was consolidated, it was only a matter of time.  The goals they set are extremely unattainable for employees without pushing customers into unnecessary financial decisions that benefit only the company.

pros:
Generally pleasant work environment
Pay and bonuses are good
Good working environment w/ our internal clients and users
Everyone is polite
cons: After Wells took over Wachovia, they slashed salaries, froze or eliminated the pension, cut PTO days and eliminated 2 paid holidays. At the end of August they announced major changes to health insurance but will not provide details until mid-October. All indications are a major shift of health care costs onto employees. Management is all about the numbers and we workers are just serfs.

review_title: Great performance is recognized, but it's not always compensated.
pros: Benefits options are exceptional.  Benefits available to PT employees. 18 days of PTO available per year from day one. Hours are great and 9 paid holidays per year.
cons: It takes a long time for staffing decisions to be made. You may be identified as a great employee and qualified for promotions; however, current managers often won't approve job changes, because they want to keep you.

pros: Promote from with in, competitive salary, great benefits, management is solid you know who your supervisor is and who is management. Regardless of full or part time benefits are the same through out. All benefits start immediately from hire. health benefits are affordable
cons: They require sales. This is more of a sales retail job not so much of a banking and finance job. All jobs require selling there is not a position that does not have sales goals. Also most teller positions start at 20 hours and it may take quite a bit of time to get to the next position our to get a full time trekker position.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great people work here, who really do go the extra mile. Seriously. Also, it's relatively politics-free, which is unusual for such a highly-regulated business. Becuase the business is all about whether you make your numbers or don't make your numbers, there isn't room for pushing responsibility for missed deadlines or incomplete projects off onto another person or team.
cons: Salaries are well below industry average, especially on the non-sales side.  Benefit plans are not great.

review_title: High pressure sales and harassing "customer service" practices.
pros: Great benefits and exceptional training. I spent 2 weeks straight in a classroom learning about all the basics of Wells Fargo as a company and had a lot of training on bank products and sales techniques.
cons: We were required to try to sell something to EVERY SINGLE CUSTOMER that came to the teller window. If we opened their account on Monday and the came back on Tuesday we had to try to sell them something new and if they came back again on Tuesday.... well... I had a lot of irritated customers because I either had to do my job and harass them or not do my job and get written up for it.

review_title: I enjoy the people I work with. While the goals are good sometimes management seems to make very bad decisions.
pros: People and environment in general are very good. The employees across the different business lines work well together and are very friendly and helpful in assisting you pursuing projects.
cons: Decisions made by management seem to be very questionable at times. There seems to be a lack of accountability for managers and upper management. Subject matter experts are not always experts.

review_title: It all depends on what group you work for
job_title: Marketing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Work/life balance
Salary
Benefits
Lots of really smart, motivated people
Some work can be great, some mind-numbing
There are some great divisions to work with, and some awful ones. The good ones are great, and the awful ones are petty, political, and focused on keeping leadership happy instead of focusing on their work or the customer.
cons:
Politics
Too big to move quickly
Very hard to implement change
Too many excuses ("Legal won't let us" "we've always done it this way")

review_title: Great company vision however if you are in retail, forget about it
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: They have great benefits, 401k contribution, wonderful corporate regional managers with the right vision on leading team members and creating the culture of caring.
cons: Retail environment is very stressful and many district managers close their eyes to widget selling in order to make their goals.  Retail does not have the ability for work life balance especially the higher you go within the position ie managers.  All they care about is the numbers even though it's messing up people's finances.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Opportunity to work on large complex projects, good chances to gain experience in different areas of the bank.  Good opportunities to learn about all areas of financial management.  Many different locations to work out of.
cons: The environment can vary depending on which group you are in.  Going from 1 group to another can almost feel like changing companies.  IT is large providing many opportunities, but also make project work needlessly complex.  Most teams play well together, but there are those that don't.

review_title: Fun and fast paced. Partner with clients to provide value from one of the best banking institutions in the country.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Birmingham, AL
pros: Very supportive atmosphere for growth and development. Wells Fargo's success is driven by the branch employees, giving a sense of responsibility and importance to the role. Time off structure is excellent allowing for paid volunteer time as well.
cons: Policies and procedures are not flexible enough to accommodate certain unique situations for customers. Teller position sees high turnover rate.

review_title: Get desire compensation when hired. Prepare for politics!
pros: If you are able to get hired at the compensation level you deserve then you should be OK provided you are OK with raises that do not keep up with inflation and not getting promoted.  They only expect 20-30 solid hours of actual work from most employees so overtime is a minimum.
cons: Nepotism and politics thrive at Wells Fargo. The only people who advance in their career and get an increase in salary are the ones who have visible to upper levels of management.  Most managers seem to only be concerned with their own career and focus on making their manager happy rather than making their team happy.  No one truly enjoys their job, only the paychecks.

pros: Amount of Vacation time given.  Discount on mortgage origination fees.  Convenience of banking where you work.
cons: Working from a banker to a store manager, whatever you do is never good enough.  You may be the top person one day and dirt the next.  District Manager was great.  However, upper management needs to take heed and listen to their employees.  It is one thing to sell to benefit the customer.  It's worse when you have to cross the line to meet your goals.   I've seen bankers put in loan applications for customers without their knowledge and then have it reported and nothing is done.

review_title: Nice place to work, but hard to advance
pros: Decent benefits and pay; very corporate culture where expectations are clearly set and easily understood; they try to do fun things for the employees and most managers encourage a work-life balance; ability to transfer to different position after 1 year in current position
cons: Too corporatte- the people making changes and rules are sitting in their big high rise office somewhere else and aren't really in touch with the people on the front lines. Pay raises are small and as far as advancing upward, it's all about who you know usually.

job_title: Senior Visual Designer in El Cerrito, CA
pros: They put me out of my misery.
cons: CX group was just very unprofessional. Horrible onboarding—it took months to get a project. Excessive rules disguised as process. Agency model, so everyone is a bottom feeder upon arrival. Didn't follow SF rules for sick time and MRA. Defective equipment—three different computers in four months and was required to travel to Oakland for a replacement. Platitudes without substance. False starts. Overlapping hierarchies. Lack of serious communication. Lack of real work and a lot of busy work. Passive aggressive Art Directors. No reward for innovation. Adverse effects for seeking productive work. And the number one reason: no graceful exit. Very unprofessional and career damaging experience.

pros: Benefits and facilities are good. No work pressure at all. If you don't want to work and want to only enjoy fun events and other organisational events then this is the BEST place for you.
cons: Most of the people don't have work there and just doing time pass (potluck and any other events). Manager is GOD to employee. He has all the liberty to do what he wants with respect to his team. After resigning, HR discussion didn't happen at all (for me). Internal movement to other team is so difficult that there is no transparency on the open positions. Everything happens at back end.

review_title: Some nice people, not a great environment
job_title: Web Layout Specialist in Des Moines, IA
pros: PTO, college reimbursement, ergo equipment, flexibility with work hours and dress code-if you get a good manager, diversity, team member groups, LGBT acknowledgement
cons: Tiny Raises, departmental self-induced stress, disorganization, constant reorganizations which may mean lossing you job and never knowing your department name, endless rounds corporate double speak with ridiculous catch phrases they heard some other person say... And none of them knowing what even the words means

job_title: Personal Banker in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Pay, benefits, advancement, bonuses, transfer opportunity
cons: Management, Upper Management, no work/life balance, always asked to stay late & come in early.

job_title: Service Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits are great and the people that work there are nice. There is room to grow and experience different lines of business. They also provide tuition reimbursement.
cons: Pay is not great compared to other banks and credit unions. Management micromanages like crazy. There is a report for absolutely everything and your managers will "go over" your results daily as to how poorly you are meeting objectives or how you can improve if you are meeting objectives. Wells Fargo keeps restructuring so upper level management changes constantly.

pros: Steady job that will always be needed by the public, good 401(k) plan, stock options, and competitive salaries.
cons: employees are expected to meet quotas, quality, referral, and high productivity goals in order to retain their position.  Very little compassion for the employees, instead they are driven to meet predetermined percentages and numbers that the corporate executives have reached in order to meet their financial goals.  Very high pressured!

review_title: Operations is like a white collar sweatshop
pros: good benefits, above average compensation
cons: The operations area is like a factory. Associates are expected to simply do their work. There is no incentive to go above and beyond because it is simply not recognized. If you don't have a family and like overtime, this is the place for you! Departments are under-staffed, overworked and not at all appreciated. Management does not listen to, much less address, worker concerns. Good luck getting time off or plan it well in advance. Everything is micro-managed and thinking outside the box is strongly discouraged. Wells Fargo has yet to realize what may have worked well out west does not translate well back east.

pros: Great benefits (PTO, holidays, 401k, Stock purchase plan, medical & dental). You become very close to your coworkers & customers.
cons: Lots of favoritism in the branch. If you have an item in collection you cannot be promoted, Or if DM doesn’t seem you qualified they will just interview you for the sake of it knowing they are not hiring you. Hours usually consist of being there from 8am-6pm(no home life). Say they are not sales driven but still make you meet a goal but this time around we don’t get paid for it.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Bend, OR
pros: The pay is okay enough that I don’t run screaming.
cons:
Inconsistent management between branches. Everyone has their own message but no one seems to know how to get it out to the employees. You can make up to $4600 a year in bonuses as a PB1, but you’ll be lucky to ever see $1000 of it. Not only are the metrics impossible to reach (they change their minds a lot), they don’t even tell you what the criteria are so you have no idea what you need to do to get these bonuses. 
Extremely frustrating place to work.

review_title: Great team members, poor senior management
job_title: Operations Analyst in Des Moines, IA
pros:
My immediate coworkers were some of the most caring and dedicated individuals I've ever worked with. I never heard anyone say: "That's not my job." They were always open to questions and feedback. If you had a question they could not answer, they would find the answer for you. 

Wells Fargo does offer significant time off.
cons: Wells Fargo senior management has recently stumbled from one scandal to another without full disclosing or communicating decisions and issues to team members. Executive compensation continues to increase along with stock buybacks while team member wages remain stagnant at mere 1-2% annual increases.

review_title: It was great untill I lost my job
job_title: Systems Support Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great Pay, working from home, flexible hours
cons: Very demanding at times, On call rotation was overwhelming, position eliminated and had to train replacements,  Picked up all the  unwanted work to keep my job and mgmt still could not see my value and let my contract expire.

review_title: A good place to build a career in Banking, provided lots of opportunities to grow and develop
pros:
Very solid learning and development
Process are in placed and very well thought
Systems and resources are provided for every position
Work hard, show that you care and managers are always in the eye to grow the next leaders
cons:
Lots of bureaucracy
It’s a big machine that most of the time personal touch is lost. Because of that clients can be perceived just to be a number.
Working with other departments is very difficult. Some team members don’t care about quality of the job.

job_title: Financial Crimes Supervisor in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great benefits, opportunities for growth, prolific volunteerism in the community
cons: Pays slightly less than fair market value vs their competitors. Inconsistent standards for metrics and performance make it difficult for even top bankers to exceed. Still struggling to rehabilitate their reputation after repeated violations across multiple lines of businesses.

pros: The company was well run and seemed to have a good strategic plan.  The senior managers all had many years of experience with the company and were very capable.   Also, good benefits for employees including 25 PTO in first year.  A lot of training opportunities.  Almost everyone else I met at the company was very satisfied with how they were treadted
cons: Felt like there was limited upside.  The pay was ok, but not as good as other banks.  The company approach to business is very conservative, which can be frustrating.  From a business standpoint this was a good thing, but not quite so exciting when young.

pros: The best place about working at Wells Fargo was the people you worked with. For the most part they were all nice, fun, outgoing, and supportive
cons:
1. Recycled leads. People would get called at home and work up to ten times a week with employees trying to sell things. You could expect to get screamed at at least twice a day and rightfully so.
2. Revolving door. After a year of working there I was the second most senior worker in the office. People get hired an fired like crazy.
3. Micromanaging. You can expect to have your manager looking over your shoulder the entire day.
4. Bonus structure is terrible. I led my office in sales one month and received a check for $25.00. You cannot make money there

pros:
above average 401k plans, and health insurance.
provided all the tools needed to be good at you're job.
bonus's are easy to obtain.
cons:
Every job position that you have direct contact with a customer you are expected to see additional products to them.  I understand we are in business to sell financial products but Wells Fargo brings it to the extreme with what they expect out of their employee's.
Do you have a solicitation preference on you're account? No problem we have a script we can read to you to get around that.

review_title: Wells Fargo okay place to work if you don't mind drama
pros: There are bonuses, and eventually the job gets easy.  If you stay there long enough and you're competent, you're eventually going to move up.
cons: They push you to sell stuff all the time, it actually turns into a stressful environment at times.  There is also a lot of drama, and the teller job can get very boring.  Their way of customer service and what they make you do is stupid and can be stressful.

review_title: Wells Fargo a decent company to work for as a peon
pros: Great benefits, entry level job that could help you advance your career down the road. Great people to work with.
cons: Very conservative bank and doesn't have investment jobs( that I am interested in) compared to other large banks. From what I have seen, not enough employees and high turnover.

pros: Interns get to travel to attend the same week-long training sessions that the full time professionals do. depending on your intern program, you'll get lots of free lunches and dinners, get to go on trips, and meet other interesting young people
cons:
Most of the time, when you're in the office, they won't let you do anything....like not even get coffee or make copies. you will just sit at your desk, bored to tears, waiting for the day to end so you can do it all over again. 

at times its a little frustrating and an insult to your intelligence

review_title: Seems more promising than it really is
pros: The management is great about letting you know ways you can improve and they are always there to help. It is a big team environment and everyone works together to create a positive atmosphere and to promote and sell the services and products.
cons: Throughout every stage of the interview process, advancement in the company is always mentioned. However, it is a lot more difficult to move to corporate than they like to say initially. The managers may play favorites for promotions, even when not deserved. Also, the pay could use improvement as well.

review_title: The company is great, but some of the work groups are terrible
pros: Great benefits and the operating team is very good.  Our CEO and CFO really care about the customer, shareholder, and team member.
cons: Some of the senior management within the work groups are terrible.  Its like the top executives are good, but the next couple levels are burnt out and aware that they will never be promoted so they are very difficult to work with if you are eager to work hard.  Often times efforts to improve the processes on my team are stiffled for no reason.

review_title: Great direct management, but upper management is clueless.
job_title: Mortgage Loan Officce in Houston, TX
pros: Great direct management.  Very supportive and positive working environment
cons: Training was very lacking for what was needed to learn the basics.  Not a lot of connection between departments.

review_title: Benefits good, management, not so good.
pros: Nice place, coworkers are great people, supervisors awesome!
cons: Upper management terrible. Slave drivers and push to increase referrals via intimidation. Pay not great. Insulting right there in front of other employees. Always telling the phone bankers that they are not working up to par. Never have anything good to say other than a mass email that says you are not doing good enough, but thanks for all you do. Then they give you treats like candy or pizza. It is getting old really fast.

review_title: Good position if you are sales minded
job_title: Personal Banker I in Santa Rosa, CA
pros: Can be great with the right management team. Company vision and values are solid and followed most of the time. Extremely customer oriented focus. The company is focused on promoting team members that perform well.
cons: Sales pressure is more intense than any other bank. Top performers are leaned on by management to carry the team. Some management teams can try to push you into unethical behavior due to sales drive and the fact that the goals haven't moved but they have taken away credit for many different sales solutions over the past few years making the goals that much harder to hit.

job_title: Procurement for IT in Irvine, CA
pros: Potential to bring out your best if you're willing to put up with not being heard.  Pay is ok but nothing to jump ship over.
cons: Rule changes without warning because YOU are responsible to know ALL of them from the vast website internally.  Asked to do more than possible without regard for how it affects you.  No understanding of how much time tasks take to accomplish.  Will listen to others about your ability to get things accomplished even though the others never did your tasks.

review_title: you better sell, sell, sell if you want to work there
pros: I liked the people I work with and that's the only reason I gave it three stars

-office politics,  they tend to promote young kids in their early 20's that have only been there a few months over better qualified people that have been there for years.

review_title: Work experience depends entirely on your manager. Very political environment. Unstable leadership.
job_title: Learning And Development Consultant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Remote work possible.  Peers are generally pretty competent (but not all).  Some managers are decent people who know what they're doing.  Pay and benefits marginally okay.  Your next job will probably seem great after working here.

Rewards are frequent but seem random and not all that impressive--pins, coasters, small-dollar awards.  If you think working 30 days straight and then getting a $35 gift card is a great reward, and getting a 1% raise is generous, this is the company for you.

pros: Provides and opportunity to ensure you are growing in your position as long as you are willing to work hard and strive for success. Training is top notch and introduces you to a wide view of the banking industry. When doing well lots of recognition of success
cons: Sales goals continue to rise year over year and focus tends to be more on the numbers then on creating actual activities that drive success. Required to focus on opening multiple products for customers to achieve success which leaves to heavy pressure and stress which makes keeping a team together tough.

review_title: Great Benefits, but Base Pay is Uncompetitive
pros: Great benefits, Broad Range of Transfer Opportunities, Incentive Program for Collectors Can Be Rewarding, Well kept campus in Minneapolis
