job_title: Store Manager III in York, PA
pros: Systems/ Technology great! Staffing great, almost too many people! Communication pretty good between managers and district managers. Unfortunately, too much Competition drives unethical behavior!
cons: Sales pressure and leadership! Made the weak do very unethical things! Sales pressure in bearable! Legacy Wachovia employee who enjoys and lives for sales pressure, but even over the top for me! Attrition in 2011 over 40%... Finally forced upper management out, took a lot of top employees leaving to finally open their eyes!

job_title: Summer Financial Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: Several opportunities to learn and encouraging environment. One of the MDs in the office was very encouraging and supportive and really cared about the interns in and outside of the office. The brown bag lunches were really informative and engaging.
cons: None of the interns in my group were able to work on any deals, so I didn't get to learn much. My direct manager was really rude and talked about politics in the office, which put the interns in an uncomfortable position. I was also the only person of color in the entire office, and I remember hearing a couple of the MDs say very offensive remarks. I obviously couldn't say anything.

pros:
Friendly coworkers
Great opportunity to move up in the company
good pay
cons:
Managers always on your back for no reason.
Always try to find things to correct you on just so they fill out their evaluation sheets. That is, no matter what you do to be perfect in the job, they'll find something very irrelevant to say, oh that... and they probably told you it was perfectly fine a few days prior.

job_title: Mortgage Underwriter III in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great Benefits, Great Salary Competition,
cons:
It's a bank. It is highly bureaucratic and doesn't attract very good people. Retirement in place.
Lot's of people "come up thru the ranks" and are virtually unemployable anywhere else but another bank. Many management types have no outside experience and many have no degree.

pros: Great PTO and monthly/annual bonuses
cons: Where to begin... Upper management doesn't care about lower level employees.  Practically impossible to impose changes even when multiple offices across the country complain about the same problem.  This company is being ran by executives who think companies need to be ran like they did in the 80s/90s.  Zero work/life balance outside of using your PTO.  This company will be left in the dust by its competitors if they don't listen to employees and improve how they run their business.  This company also has zero culture, people came in to make money and leave as soon as they found a chance

review_title: Alright place to work. But could be bett
job_title: Bank Teller in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Co workers, and benefits, and that’s about it.
cons: Management has a lot to learn , they’re consistently coaching you and pushing you to refer to bankers, compensation sucks, won’t work with your school schedule, leadership is all politics if they like you they’ll promote you , even if you’re the best employee if they don’t like you good luck trying to get promoted.

pros: Competitive pay and benefits, current challenges present opportunities for those of monumental tolerance and patience.
cons: Wells Fargo's is an extremely challenging environment and culture. Egregious lacks of processes and controls create an environment fraught with uncertainty and a management and workforce that is generally hesitant to excel or challenge the status quo unless instructed to do so. Too many senior leaders in the company that have been in the same group or role for far too long, resulting in an elusive and defensive culture that has been extremely challenging to disrupt. I understand some of this has been improving over the last year as much of the dead weight in middle and upper management is being challenged or pushed out all together.

review_title: The job is okay if your managers are good
pros:
they train you everything you need to know.  
No sales goals required which is rare in the banking industry. Easy if you know what your doing
cons:
low pay. They don't pay per experience they pay average to everyone as a start.
WF doesn't have a budget for events so team members always have to pinch in for holiday food or any other occasion. you basically have to stand all day long doing withdraw and deposits. Taking days off is not flexible (in my experience my managers are just not approving much )

review_title: Looking to start a banking career? Wells Fargo is the way to go
job_title: Assistant Store Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Wells Fargo is definately a leader in banking industury. It's professional enviornment makes employees that they indeed work at a bank. I have to say this, Wells Fargo provideds the best sales training among its competitors that I have ever received. The sales training gets you on the road faster and easier to succeed. The sales culture in wells fargo is awesome and that's why the comapny's performance has been so well.
cons: If you are not professional enough or not a sales person in you nutcell, do not apply. Wells is a sales driven employer that alot of people arent' get used to such pushy culture.

job_title: Learning And Development Specialist in Boise, ID
pros: A good portion of managers receive training on how to support their employees more effectively; training, coaching and using resources.
cons: People are expected to work their way up from the very bottom. Having a higher educational degree is not recognized as an asset. I've read an email where a mid-level manager wrote, "a college degree only shows they know how to test well." Many mid-level managers have no secondary education and end up repeating operational mistakes; with human resource management, ethical behaviors, and appropriate risk management; over and over again.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great place to have a long and varied career
job_title: Marketing Program Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great work life balance.  Good benefits, 5 weeks of vacation.  There is lots of opportunity to move around within the company and it's encouraged.  Very fair.  Formal review process.  You always know where you stand.
cons: Large company with decision making being slow and multi-leveled.  It can take a while to get things done.  Many people who work there have worked there for years.  There seems to be a lot of dead weight.  It can be difficult for those who aspire to move from the store branches to corporate offices.

review_title: Wells Fargo develops stressful relationships with clients and customers
pros: Regular paycheck, predictable hours, decent medical care
cons:
Micromanagement, micromanagement, micromanagement
Sales goals are the same whether you work in a busy branch or out in the country
Constant pressure to 'sell' more. At least four company 'check-in' calls per day to report sales results.
Very little sick time or leave time.
First time you don't meet your sales goal, warning. Second time, on probation, Third time, you're out! Even if you are a teller, you are expected to hit the streets and sell. I felt like a door to door salesman, not a respectable professional.

review_title: Shady company that's a tax to work for
job_title: Personal Banker I in Florence, SC
pros: Steady paycheck and benefits.  Internet access.
cons: The turn around at WF is almost as bad as the restaurant business.  I can't believe some of the people that are hired.  Management is a joke.  Compensation is laughable.  I will be leaving WF in a week, doing the same job, and will receive $17k more a year. Even if you exceed your sales goals it's not good enough.  If you're looking for a dead end career this is the place for you.

pros: Got t work with a Best manager and a couple of On-Site Geeks
cons: Team mates are mean minded, jealous out of nothing, busy in self-projecting, very less diversity

job_title: Tech Development Area Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Nice and stable until now, very large Org and so you can hide in bushes without anyone noticing you (this goes for lazy people).
cons: Full of nepotism and favoritism (typical of any large org). I know an instance where a glorified secretary was promoted to my Sr. level management position, as Metallica rightfully sings - "Sad but True."

review_title: Wells is most likely the worst of the banks to work for.
pros: Compared to other banks, I would say there is only one pro. The had a lot of volume but their practices are slowly taking the one advantage away.
cons: The are a revolving door company. The entice you with numbers you will never hit. They are the worst paying of the banking industry with the lease amount of aggressive products. If they did purchase every secondary loan to refi people, they would be hurting. Which I feel will start happening

review_title: Ovearall great experience for banking industry.
pros: Solid company that sticks to its principles through good times and bad.  People in general are good people to work with and plenty of opportunities for those who are looking for it.
cons: Overly conservative on some names that have been industry namesakes for decades.  Teams tended to work in silos without much collaboration to ensure that the client experience was the best it could be.

review_title: Decent place to work, but be prepared for inflated sales goals that only get worse
pros: Decent Pay, usually your coworkers are good people and you can have fun. Bonuses don't reflect the amount of work done, but its nice to get a quarterly bonus.
cons: Even when you are a top performer, dont expect your bonus to be huge. Very political in promotions, hard to move up unless senior management knows you personally. Sales quotas make a lot of bankers unethical and then ethical bankers have to clean up their mess.

review_title: Great company to work for but internal politics rule in the Funds Management Group
job_title: Compliance Consultant in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: The corporate culture is focused on the customer. Good benefits on site (free parking, lunch in Menomonee Falls WI)
cons: Managers are inexperienced and sometimes incompetent. They hire people to lead a team. They may not be familiar with policies, procedures or the simplest tasks their teams perform on a daily basis. They believe they can use the latest greatest managerial mumbo jumbo to get by. That only leads to a lack of respect and trust from those doing the work. Managers take opportunities from their teams and horde it for their own personal advantage.

job_title: Phone Banker I in San Antonio, TX
pros: There are a lot of pros to working with them but the biggest ones are the benefits, pay, supervisors, and the pto. And plus the feed you on special holidays.
cons: There are not many cons other than it being a call center but that's what you're being paid for. Call centers in general can be a pain in the butt because you have to listen to all the customers problems, especially when they are stupid with their money (had a customer argue with me that she wouldn't pay for the things she bought because she didn't see them pending until now) but that's just the way it is.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Denver, CO
pros: The people I worked closely with, that's it! Going to miss some really good people.  I was desperately trying to get out of retail, I was three days away from finding out if I got the position I really wanted. Kind of ironic.
cons: 2 years w/ company. Top performer finishing top 1 and 2 in all of Denver consistently. I was recently terminated for a false accusation and I'm going to fight to clear my name. I had just finished training to become a business specialist. High pressure sales of awful products with NO compensation!!! Horrible culture and hiring tactics. Advancement is slow. Too many micro managers. Treat customers well to their face, then steal their money when they aren't looking. No recognition for leaders. If you get on their bad side, look out!!

pros: There is a slightly flexible schedule
cons: The production guidelines are akin to sweatshops in 3rd world countries.   They are all budget driven so don't expect to ever hit a mark.  If you like the threat of being fired hanging over your head every month and continuous stress, this might be a great place for you to work.  Large hypocritical, greedy corporation that exploits desperate employees.  They will bring unions back to banking if they keep treating their human assets the way they do.  People get jobs at banks and accept less pay for "security" but there is no security here.  2 bad months, you're fired, regardless of circumstance, even if you've been an employee 12 years.

pros: The comprehensive benefits package is a major asset.  The most paid time off I've ever heard of, cheap health insurance plans, tuition reimbursement, etc.  Also job security is a plus.
cons: There isn't an abundance of development or career advancement opportunities.  The opportunities are more tied to the time you have been there than the level one is performing at.  With how large the company is, everything is standardized and it limits innovation and creativity.

job_title: Online Customer Service Representative in Vallejo, CA
pros: Awesome people to work with. Fast-paced environment where you will never be stagnant. Great pay, benefits, and 401K plan is available. Overtime was available. You are able to choose a different shift after you have been there for 6 months. The training period is fun and professionally organized.
cons: The incoming calls are back to back, so be mindful of how much liquid you consume. Part of your job will be to sell products and up-sell them if you can. Products such as Checking, savings, bill pay accounts, etc. Your phone calls will be monitored, so you must adhere to the guidelines that you are taught during your training period.

pros: Excellent Company to work for.  Truly cares about the community and the employees.  Lots of potential to advance in many different lines of business.
cons: Some leadership roles candidates are promoted without having the proper experience which can cause friction and serious retention issues.  Immaturity in senior leadership positions can also be very prevalent when decisions are made to quickly to hire candidates that don't have enough life and industry experience.

pros: Nice facility and friendly Senior Management, most of the staff is warm and welcoming.
cons: Not a lot of diversity and a hot bed of cliques.  When they took away the company holiday party, after several groups some how managed to go to Vegas on the company dime, well you kind of see where the priority's are.  They seriously shifted away from being a good employee company and into "all about the benjamins" mentality.

pros: It's easy to advance your career if you are determined and hard-working.
cons: Sales-oriented.  They are accounts, not people.  Expect a fake smile from anyone if you are  a customer.

review_title: It all depends who you work under
pros: The best aspect is the growth opportunity and tuition reimbursement.  The company give you 5,000 if you are full-time or 2,500 if you are part-time annually. You only qualify if you have been with the company for more than a year and if you can use the degree towards your career with the company (i.e. nursing degree would not qualify)
cons: It is a sales job so there is a lot of pressure for you to meet your quota.  I have also worked under really bad management. Not good health benefits.

pros: Great fellow coworkers. The only good thing about this company is the people at your level. There are a few good branch managers but even they feel the pressure from the regional managers which push unfair and unrealistic expectations down upon the employees.
cons:
Poor business practices. Management is terrible and pressures employees to sell multiple accounts to customers even though the customers do not need them. Otherwise they threaten to fire you. 

Wells Fargo HR does nothing to help employees in need. They close cases without a solution. 

Caused multiple women at multiple locations to misscarry their unborn children due to the extreme stress they put you through. Of course this is hard to prove but just look at the numbers and you'll quickly see a pattern.

pros: This is an established company with a recognizable brand. They work hard in the community. The benefits package is great and time off is very generous.
cons: It is often hard to get internal promotions because people are picked for positions before they are even posted. There is a reorganization at least annually which means it takes effort to keep up. The culture you see in the media is not what life is really like. If you like a fast paced world and can keep up, you will be fine. If not, you will be flattened like a pancake.

review_title: Good company, excellent benefits and PTO
pros: As a whole, a good company to work for. With a company so large things can vary by office. Good professional development, flex hours, good work life balance, start with 18 days PTO and max out at 32. Benefits are good with cheap premiums, lots of places to move around and explore other career options without switching companies.
cons: Unfairness when it comes to work from home. Some people can and some can't. It's based on your title and job duties.

review_title: Unskilled micro managers who cannot add any value to your business development or growth.
pros: There is a site that teaches banking that's not advertise and its very useful and critical to education.  Www.handsonbanking.org
cons: Large bureaucracy with mini fiefdoms still with even smaller fiefdoms of individuals without leadership training, sales experience to advise, train or support their teams.  The culture is poor and management is out of touch with reality. If you want to be treated like a child by a child then great place for you.

pros: Great team based environment, perfect opportunity for recent grads to become licensed and build necessary skills. Very stable work environment, suitable for those that value structure or have kids and can’t afford to take work home.
cons: Very highly supervised position, you will not like this role if you need a high degree of autonomy. Pay may not be as competitive depending on your skills also not a great place for incredibly creative individuals as most processes are very prescriptive.

job_title: Senior QA Automation Engineer in Bangalore
pros: Lots of technical exposure in the project, at least it was in mine. Friendly colleagues, little politics, sole laptop for all FTE's, Work from home facilities. 2 floors nice Food court with all types of food dishes available. Team recognitions is there. Posh 2 - 10 floors building with lavish internal infrastructure.
cons: Hiring HR makes false salary promise, and later calls people for negotiation and try their best to cut down the offered ctc. Work from home facility depends upon the manager, my manager didn't encourage and don't approves it. Else everything is up to the mark.

review_title: Don't get trampled by the stagecoach!
pros: Stability and security.  Great incentives for top performance.
cons: sales pressure, too much emphasis on sales results.  It doesn't matter how great you are as an employee in any other way except sales.  If you are fantastic with fellow team members and customers, are reliable, are helpful with others, are creative, go above and beyond are ambitious and behave with high ethical standards...you can still get fired and pretty easily if you don't make sales goals.  Ridiculous!

review_title: Great strong bank that cares for it's team members
job_title: Operations Analyst in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Extremely conscious of balancing work and life.  There is much flexibility in roles and can find a spot to highlight your strengths.  Training is important and a constant theme.  The size allows for a person to find a role that suits them and helps their team and company.  I have enjoyed working at Wells Fargo and am proud of the organization.  This is a proud company and takes pride in it's team members.
cons: It's a large institution that can get bureaucratic.  There is a structure to Wells Fargo that keeps it strong, but also makes it somewhat rigid and slow moving.

pros: They actually have good benefits and the pay is decent. Your coworkers become your family (in good and bad ways).
cons: Too much stress on sales. I don't get paid THAT much to hound customers about little things. Hours are not flexible at current branch, were very flexible at former branch. Manager does not seem to think there is a life outside of work except for herself.

job_title: Lead Teller in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Great Volunteer and Networking Opportunities
They love to promote from within
Some managers/branches really are a place for learning and growth
cons:
Unrealistic sales requirements that are constantly changing .
Find yourself in a situation of he said/she said? Better get your numbers up, the person with the highest sales is always right.

pros: I loved saying that I work for a bank. Being that I am in college, it's the best job I can get since I am stil considered 'unskilled' is i try to apply for a respectable job....beats being a macy's slave that's for sure!! Also, your coworkers are more educated and professional compared to sleazebags at dead-end mall jobs...lastly, you get to make friends with your regular customers.
cons: managers play favorites like no other. There is very little room for growth unless you kiss the boss's a$$...

review_title: Worked for Wells Fargo for 10 years
pros: Great benefits and great customer service
cons:
I worked for Wells Fargo for 10 years and it is a lot more work today to do the same job as a banker as it was a few years ago.
Ever since Wells Fargo took over Wachovia the working environment has changed for the worse.  Were being micro managed by upper management, promotions are harder to get, and there not giving any raises.
Wells Fargo has become very aggressive in sales that were opening extra accounts that people don't need.

review_title: Smart People as a Competitive Advantage...the rest are idiots!
job_title: Senior Securities Analyst in Columbia, MD
pros:
I can pretty much come and go as I please.
Very little accountability for the quality of your work. Yup.
cons:
Long nights during certain periods of the month.
Management has no clue how to get people to do their job or train them.
Coworkers could careless and usually force you to work long hours so they can soak up OT.
They leverage the people who can do their job and let the idiots keep coasting.
No room for advancement for Senior Analysts...that's why we go elsewhere!

review_title: So far beyond the worst places I've worked
pros: Close to home and casual dress code
cons: The management is abusive and has no understanding of the mortgage industry.  They hire and fire people often, there doesn't seem to be any clear direction.  Lacking in leadership - very unstable.  Constantly changing procedures so that customers/employees can't keep up and are confused.  Unrealistic workloads, not given the proper tools or training to do your job.  Felt pressured to work overtime without pay - hostile work environment.

review_title: They treat employees well, but don't leave you with a lot of relatable experience outside of WF
pros: Lots of time off and encouragement to use it.  401k is great.  Lots of internal job postings and encouragement to advance your career within the company.  Severence package was great too.
cons: Fear of layoffs in the mortgage industry.  Typical desk job in sad cubicals.  I had some really underqualified managers due to the fact they like to hire internally.

review_title: Show them the numbers if you want to be somebody someday
pros:
Good Benefit program 
Pay is competitive compared to other financial institutions
Overall decent environment
cons: At the retail banking level you will depend on your store manager to advance within this company. My particular manager is not supportive of helping me to advance, and in some ways has been holding me back. You can be a top performer and recognized for your work and still seem to be stuck in the banker role. Your manager and District Manager are key to you moving up, but be prepared to move out.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great company and employer
pros:
Personal Time Off
Continuing education credit opportunities
Dedicated team members
Client-centric focus
Ability to have input to improve processes that affect the client
cons:
New health insurance plans
Constant restructuring (mostly due to current economic environment)
Depending on manager, recognition is hard to get

review_title: Company OK, but there are issues
job_title: Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Brand recognition
Benefits (excluding health care)
cons:
Low salary
Management will often "churn" on various projects (hopping from one Must Have ASAP, project to another as if under pressure of conflicting goals)
Hiring to backfill much needed positions takes much too long, leaving the remaining Team Members under tremendous pressure
Unrestricted parking is Very limited and usually means walking across one of two, mega lane streets that convey heavy traffic. That is brutal during a typical StL winter.

pros: The benefits and pay is all that keeps me there.
cons: You are a slave tied to a phone all day taking call after call from disgruntled customers. Your job is all about meeting sales numbers and getting customers to agree to get a bank product they don't need no matter what the cost. Someone is always breathing down your neck telling you to get sales. You are endlessly "coached" and micromanaged. Everyone in my department hates their job. You are expected to meet a million metrics to even get an incentive payout. They make it so hard to meet it that nobody gets incentive payouts. You cannot move to another job or department unless you meet your sales numbers. You will never get a feeling of accomplishment because nothing is ever good enough. Horrible place to work!

review_title: Great company if you have a good manager
pros: Wells Fargo has a lot to offer with good career paths.
cons: If you are not into hard driving sales environment, may be hard to adapt. Anything can change. My position was based in Tacoma and due to "consolidation" was moved to Seattle. This has mad it hard on my family and childcare since now I am away 12 hrs a day. Wish there was more opportunities around where I live.

pros: You get a lot of paid vacation days(4 weeks) off the bat, and of course every federal holiday
cons:
Working Saturdays, crappy benefits, low paying, the fact that they demand you annoy every single customer and ask them for a bunch of crap they don't need. Most of the management is a bunch of uneducated twits on power trips. They constantly up the quarterly goals while making them harder to attain. Raises barely ever happen because of "the economy", meanwhile the stock value sky rockets. They offer some of the worst interest rates and accounts, but rely on their numerous locations and friendliness to trick you into thinking they are a consumer friendly bank.
Employees will lie to you to get you to open accounts. That's how much pressure they get from the management.

review_title: Good place for growth for young professional
job_title: Teller, Lead Teller, Client Sales and Service Representative, Banker in Boulder, CO
pros: I worked here in college and they were very accommodating to my school schedule, offered awesome benefits and PTO. I met a lot of great coworkers who I still remain friends with today. Excellent chance to create and improve your Customer Service skills, you get to meet many different customers, great networking opportunities, very friendly work environment. Strong sense of team amongst coworkers.
cons: Hours aren't always the best, but you will always have Sundays and Holidays off. The pay wasn't super high but perfect for while you are in school and establishing yourself as a young professional. Only major con was the sales can get very competitive and you are pressured to make your numbers.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Houston, TX
pros: They did offer awesome health benefits.
cons: They work you like dogs for little pay. When I first started, they cared about their employees, but then they became extra money hungry and made it more difficult for everyone to make a decent pay. They increased goals and paid less. The District Managers only cared about their pay, so they were willing to be total jerks to employees and only focus on getting PERFECT 5's on 11 ways to wow (which is INSANE) and maintaining crazy sales goals over 3 months. Working at a bank isn't about helping a customer manage their financial portfolio, it's about selling them anything and everything possible.

pros: This was an easy job.
cons: Constant oversight, Low pay, Never ending reviews that result in failure without perfect scores, managers in states with right to work laws use that to scare employees into compliance, Must perform all duties as designed by executives (ie. there is a script for everything and deviation is frowned upon), the company exploits customers as much as possible, etc.

review_title: Good management team is vital to success
pros: Pay, benefits, and coworkers if you're lucky.
cons: Sales pressure is ridiculous. They constantly threaten to fire you if you don't meet your goals. Turn over rate is horrible. I can't even count the number of tellers and bankers we went through in the 3 years I worked there. We went through 4 store managers and at least 5-6 service managers in that time too; each expecting you to do things differently than the prior one expected. My entire management team (from the store to the district) were complete jerks except the regional manager.

review_title: Horrible Management that play favorites...TOO MUCH POLITICS
job_title: Customer Sales & Service Representative in Raleigh, NC
pros: Promotion can happen quickly if you're good at what you do, for the most part the people are great to work with, pay and benefits are pretty good.
cons: Incompetent management with little care for the employees they are suppose to encourage. If anything goes wrong they will readily throw you under the bus and then lie about their role in the incident. Many managers play the favorite game and don't want you to do better or receive more credit than they do. If you value your sanity, DO NOT WORK HERE!!!!

pros: Hired part time, been working full time since I started 4 months ago. Love the team I work with, and how Wells treats their customers.
cons: Even though I work full time, I am not offered full time benefits (because I was hired at part time) which is disappointing because I am making full time goals and have an immaculate attendance record.

job_title: Home Preservation Specialist in Chandler, AZ
pros: Extensive training, decent benefits, decent hourly pay rate (if experienced), plenty of PTO, friendly and receptive direct management, flex scheduling allowed for appointments.
cons: Monthly bonus removed and substituted with annual bonus.  For tenured employees, that eliminated a maximum of $2000 each month of income.  Internal promotions only allow a maximum of 10% in raise, which can take a salary position and make it less cost effective than your previous area of employment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Interesting job.  Something new everyday.  Absolutely great people to work with.  Great pay for what you do.  Get to help customers when they need it most.
cons: The biggest con that I have is being on the phones all day long.  If phone work is interesting to you it would be the perfect job.  Would rather do the production side of the job.

job_title: Associate Account Executive in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
My boss was great! She was super supportive and nice. She didn't micromanage. She was awesome, I'll miss the people the most. Also the coworkers are great.

The holidays were nice. We had most of the federal holidays off and once you were permanent employee they were paid.

The benefits package is great!
cons:
The work can be dull.

The pay is mediocre. I worked in a facility closely related to Mortgage backed securities. Oftentimes it was stressful.

pros: Great people.  6% match on 401k.  Great work/life balance.  I work remotely.  Others work remotely part time.  Nice to work for a large company.
cons: Raises are minimal.  It is difficult to move to other departments (instead they move you around).  I spent my own time and money for additional project management training and new IT skills; unfortunately, that did not open doors for me, when I applied for internal jobs.  Maybe that is because I work remotely?

pros: It was a great job. Good work/life balance and benefits.
cons: No longer the same Wells Fargo Risk environment. Recent layoffs in the risk organization have staff questioning their value to the organization.  The personnel were identified according to the state where they live while performing their “remote” work and not according to their performance. So some of the top performers according to 2018 reviews are now headed out the door.

pros: No "official" sales goals. Decent pay and benefits.  Good database with product information along with a "back office" that can give you extra information regarding certain situations. Bonuses are mainly determined by customer service reviews. Overall great job if your coworkers and management are as dedicated to the job as you are.
cons: Can be overwhelming at times due to specific customer situations. Quarterly/weekly meetings can become redundant. If management is bad and unwilling to improve behavior, it can create a toxic work environment.

pros:
*Great benefit options
*room for growth 
*decent pay
cons: Absolutely  HORRENDOUS management!! Wells Fargo needs to do something about some of the terrible managers they have running their branches and teller lines. Being told daily that you are worthless and a joke is UNACCEPTABLE! Verbally abusing bankers and tellers DAILY is UNACCEPTABLE! Blaming the staff for all the employees starting to quit and leave is UNACCEPTABLE!

job_title: Correspondent Operations Proceedure Specialist IV in Henderson, NV
pros: At the beginning of my time there, the culture was amazing.  While high production and quality were always expected of us, it was attainable.  We were able to take time to get to know the people that sat next to us and participate in team building activities.  They offer many great resources for employees who are looking to build a  career.
cons: The pressure to constantly perform at a higher and higher level all the time without the volume lead to burned-out employees.   WIth such pressure focused on production,  it was really hard to take advantage of any of the many programs that were offered without causing irreparable harm to our production expectations.

pros: Nice Manager, although have never met him.
cons: Internal Audit is a strange mix of very young people and some seasoned individuals.  Frowned upon if you want to work from home even though all meetings are virtual.  Been working there for over a year and have not met my manager, the people on my team, nor the business partners who are audited.  Flex cubes are a nightmare.  Parking is atrocious and expensive.  I don't recommend working here.  The young kids right out of college have no idea how a real world working environment is.  No one even says good morning.  All glued to their laptops.  Very unhealthy environment.  Other departments are not as rigid.  Just very strange atmosphere within internal audit.

review_title: Hot Mess of a Sandwich with Extra Mayo
pros: They were flexible with work schedule
cons: Incompetence, favoritism, treat lower level employees like trash

review_title: Wells, a good place to work, what you'd expect from a company this size
pros:
benefits are extensive, health, eye, dental, psych, counselling
commuter pre tax, FSA pre tax,
room to move around and gain experience up to mid level at least - many groups to move into and out of
good life work balance
cons:
pay could be potentailly lower that other similar financial institutions, lots of tenured people so can get a little stale
many of the groups are pretty flat from and org'l prespective and so there is not that much room to move within a group and this usually involves moving to another group
they put and end to stock options for rank and file

review_title: Not a bad place to start.
pros: Good place to get your feet wet within the financial industry.  Use is as a stepping stone while in college to gain valuable experience to move on to bigger and better things.  Once you learn to play the game, you can do well.  Lots of opportunities to move within the company to other fields you might enjoy.
cons: Very numbers driven.  Doesnt matter how you get them, but if you get the numbers they are looking for, you will get rewarded regardless of overall competence.  Sat around and watched many people cheating to get numbers only to be promoted later.

review_title: Great culture, good company, challenging work, keeps me interested.
pros: The culture of the company is perfect.  Unlike east cost banks that are extremley competitive within team members, Wells truly inspires members within offices to function as a unified team.  Beyond this there are many other reasons, Managers are easy to access, mentorship is available and traning is always recommended.   Giving back to the community is also valued.  Also salaries (SALARIES not total compensation) for Executive Management compared to other major banks, is reasonable and respectable.
cons: It is a large company so there is much talent to compete with for promotions.

pros: Monthly lunches paid for by account executives.  Opportunity for overtime.  Wonderful management.  Great office moral.  Random monthly insentives/prizes for high numbers.   Casual dress code.
cons: Temp employee's can only  for up to 18 months.  Then they let you go.  Overall pretty hodge podge office furnature and accessories.  You have to scrounge for a decent office chair.  This just makes me think that the higer up's really don't care.   A lot of employee's crammed into a small amount of space.

review_title: Decent Pay and Benefits, Sales Pressure Can be too much
pros:
Competitive pay
Pretty good benefits
Learn a lot about the banking business
Learn a lot about sales
Looks good on the resume for future sales jobs
A good branch manager will make things 1000x easier
cons:
Bad branch managers can make your job much tougher and less enjoyable
INTENSE sales goals make team members physically sick, the job less enjoyable, and the customers unhappy

review_title: Very unhappy working for Wells Fargo, was a former Wachovia employee.  All employees miserable.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Richmond, VA
pros:
401k, company match
dental, vision benefits good,
it's a job
there really are no other positives for working there that I could think of.
cons:
Wells is nothing like Wachovia.  Employees miserable, difference between night and day between Wachovia and Wells Fargo.
Do not appreciate hard work, good numbers, strong work ethics.
Want you to slam job products on clients all day.
no empowerment at all
managers scared to speak up on your behalf

pros: AT wells fargo bank you will have: advancement opportunities and good benefits. Also 2 weeks paid time off.
cons: a lot of challenge, high goals and a lot of reports and micro management. Branch managers have to report sales numbers 2-3 times a day, Constant pressure to staff to reach goals and do sales. Work at WF can be stressful. You have to work very hard. Cant seat while working, you have to stand on your feet the whole day while working with customers in the teller window.

review_title: Stable company with good work environment and great benefits
pros: Comfortable work environment, excellent training, plenty of opportunity for advancement, great benefits.

review_title: Wells Fargo had it all right, but went all wrong!!
job_title: Store Manager/Assistant Vice President in Dallas, TX
pros: I started off as a lead teller and worked hard, exceeded my sales.referral goals, and quickly learned the service manager role by shadowing behind an experienced service manager. I was promoted to a service manager six months after I started with WF and promoted to store manager another eight months later.  I was a store manager in an in-store location for over three years and loved my job and working for WF because of the in-depth training the provided to new employees and the sales/service recognition that they gave for our branch meeting our sales goals each quarter. I was a devoted manager and worked dilligently on coaching and developing a very strong sales/service team so everyone could meet their sales goals and participate in all the different forms of recognition that Wells Fargo did from 2002-2004.  In these years Wells Fargo gave certificates, held luncheons, breakfasts, and vacations for top sales producers and employee engagement was at it highest in years. Employees were motivated to perform, they wanted to perform and meet their goals. It wasnt the retail banking culture of today where every customer "needs" a product sold to them and employees salaries and performance reviews are almost entirely based on their sales results. Employees were Engaged!
cons: I believe there were two major issues that slowly lead to my dis-engagement with WF and ultimately was the reason why I left the bank. The first reason is they began to promote and hire people into management positions that didnt have any banking background.  These managers were college graduates with business MBA's but didnt have any banking background and the numbers started to reflect it.  Good managers have sound judgement and make good business decisions when dealing with customers on a day to day basis. Without a banking background and having that on the job training of what to look for when accepting deposits from customers or cashing large checks for non-customers the bank began to take huge losses from fraud.  Good managers have great common sense when it comes to managing risks and thats something that isnt taught in a classroom. With that in mind, because with substanial number of losses the bank was taking, managers across the board were punished.  Even if your branch didnt have losses almost all authority was taken away from the branches and it even got to the point that if a customer needed NSF fees waived in excess of $100, it had to be approved by a district manager. Experienced managers became glorified personal bankers.  Imagine this, " I understand you had fraud on your account and accrued several overdraft fees. Due to the amount it has to be approved by a district manager and you should see a credit to your account whithin a day or two." Sounds insane coming from the managers mouth and that doesnt even go into deposits, wires, or check cashing.  The second major issue was the increase in sales/referral goals.  The incentive plans were always changing and the goals kept increasing and increasing to the point that making a bonus was almost unattainable for most employees.  When I began with the bank being a "5 Star" sales employee and getting invited to the luncheons meant a teller needed to attain 120 referrals in a quarter. They counted checking, savings, loans, direct deposit, on-line banking, bill-pay, and NEW visa debit cards sold as referrals.  Personal Banker incentive plans were more complicated but although the goals were high, they were attainable.  Slowly they began taking away what counted as a qualified referral and soon all that counted was checking accounts, savings accounts, closed loans, and direct deposit that were processed through an active checking account.  After awhile employees werent receiving bonuses, getting the recognition, and all they were able to do was meet was minimum standards so they could keep their jobs.  Everyone understands that there is always a need for improvment and if you dont push yourself further you never get from "good' to 'great", I think that in always pusjing their employees for more and always striving for excellence  Wells Fargo forgot one of the biggest rules in business, their people are their competative advantage, and they are loosing their advantage everyday.

This takes away from $$s for other projects.  Opportunity for advancement depends on your "good ol' boy" skills and navigation of the political arena.

review_title: NE Florida pushes sales goals like you wouldn't believe
job_title: Personal Banker I in Palm Coast, FL
pros: Good work experience - I have gained a LOT of banking knowledge.
cons:
Absolutely too much pressure to meet your quarterly sales goals. A few weeks ago, the bankers all had to sign a agreement that if you didn't meet our sales goals then every two weeks we would have a review and the outcome is:

1st week: informal warning
3rd week: formal warning
5th week: write up
7th week: termination!!!

If you do not meet your sales goals in just under 2 months they can fire you!  What a terrible company, they absolutely do not care about their employee's and care more about harassing customers to open multiple checking accounts even if the customer doesn't need it.
