job_title: Personal Banker II in Detroit Lakes, MN
pros: I learned retail banking through rigorous standards and practices.
cons: With all the news about upper management turning a blind eye to the aggressive and persistent penetration of the market through absurd micromanagement and threatening behavior toward their retail bankers it is also important to know that even if you faithfully, loyally and honestly fulfill the goals for incentive award compensation they may never pay it to you. They took the money and took away my quarterly compensation for opening the wrong kind of savings account for a customer. It is typically that Wells Fargo would blame lower level employees for this mess. Thank God I resigned from my position prior to the public exposure. I'm still waiting to hear back from Human Resources on my grievance. ;)

review_title: Great workplace with strong community and employee focus
pros:
While some projects can bring with them a high workload, others don't. This develops a good balance between workload and time for things like training, community service, etc.

This balance is something that's hard to find with other companies. In addition, management sincerely cares about your happiness and well-being. They invest a lot of time and money into ensuring everyone has a voice around job satisfaction and your voice is not only heard, but acted upon.

Benefits are solid with average 401k, health, and incentive plan.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: I loved my Lead Teller and Teller Manager! Bonuses were nice (but at the time, based on "sales" which we have all seen how that turned out). They do have great benefits and as a company as a whole, seem very involved in their local communities.
cons: My Store Manager was a racist, sexist & anti-LGBT. He continuously made remarks about me (Hispanic Male/LGBT) & my co-worker (African-American Female) such as telling me how much "I should love bananas because well, you know" and that my co-worker had a bad attitude because of her race, which wasn't the case. EVERYONE had a bad attitude when he was around because he was vile.

pros: Amazing training procedure, best in the industry in my opinion. New benefits such as maternity/paternity leave is a game changer, awesome other benefits as well (401K, medical, dental, etc.) Taking accountability of previous errors (sales practices) and making change for a better company.
cons: Obviously working for Wells Fargo for the past 9 years I was part of the intense sales culture and that was a huge downside. Now I appreciate the big change however, current lower management doesn't know the new expectations. I know we are moving to a customer service oriented goals but are in the dark on what that entails.

pros: Name recognition and branding is a huge strength.  Good benefits.  The company strives to do what is right for the customer despite what has been shown in the media in past years.  It is a solid, well run company.
cons: The biggest con is also the biggest pro in a sense.  The company is too large and as such, it becomes almost impossible to properly staff the support for its mortgage originators.  As such, the processes suffer and the company's street reputation takes a hit when closings are missed.

pros: Pay is descent,  employees are usually cool
cons: Corporate structure doesn't serve best interest of customers,  Early arrival and late hours making calls to customers who typically don't want to be bothered over a savings account at dinner time,  branch managers pressure you to use the sales script even when a you've just seen a customer the day before

review_title: Fun selling products to angry or upset customers who call thinking they are getting customer service
pros: Extensive 6-week paid training, nice facilities, free parking, cafeteria. Lots of paid time off and you can just leave without telling anyone
cons: Huge pressure to meet sales goals, non-stop barrage of angry and sometimes psychotic customers, some of the supervisors were complete jerks if you needed help. You are constantly expected to walk the tightrope between "legal" and "illegal" as there are a billion rules and regulations you have to follow....or else, you could lose your ability to ever handle money again, or worse. They have nothing to offer customers who call with an actual problem other than, "Tell them to go to a branch."

pros: Vision and Values  admirable. Transition to new employee review platform without sales quotas. Great benefits. Great opportunity to learn about banking and to grow--personally and professionally.
cons: High attrition. Poor hiring decisions. Local micromanagement.

pros: No sales goals. Great benefits and 401k matches. Given shares when you have service the company for more than 2 years. Great PTO time.
cons: Micromanage, shorten lunch time to 1/2 hr instead of 1 hr due to the changes by our regional president. No assistance from management. High turn over. You actually do more than what your roles are. Even with great PTO, is hard to get. The management asked what / why do you need the time off. Management threatening staff members by not obeying the HR rules. They loves to threaten fellow colleagues and get fired!

review_title: Fed mandated asset cap squeezes non-production roles
pros: Decent time off if you stay long enough, growth opportunities, easy to make friends at work as the teams look out for each other
cons: Major decisions and initiatives take place at the regional or higher level leaving the local teams feeling powerless. Recent decisions to "consolidate" business channels and "streamline" operations has resulted in job eliminations and grueling working conditions for operations/compliance and non-production roles. Operation Liaison role has been eliminated. No doubt the firm trying to save money cutting costs since Wells Fargo as an enterprise is now under a fed mandated asset cap.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-  Team members are inclusive and supportive of one another
- Large company, provides ample opportunities to get to know other team members, network, learn and develop professionally
- Company is big on philanthropy and giving back to the community
- Good benefits, paid holidays, PTO, community service days
cons: - Lean company with lots of cost-cutting measures, recently impacted negatively by low interest rates and negative press

job_title: Commercial Loan Officer in Sacramento, CA
pros: Great training program. Good benefits. Opportunities to move around the country.
cons: A big corporate machine.  All numbers driven.  Once you miss your numbers, your career is over within the bank.  Very high pressure sales environment.  Senior management only konws you by way of reports.  Frontline managers are no help at all.  Promotion comes by way of who you know, not what you know.  Lots of empty promises just to keep you moving as fast as possible.  Very high turnover.

review_title: Higher paying bank, but excessively competitive, and sometimes unreachable goals
pros: High paying, and willing to train you in any areas you are willing to work.  Ie: notary certification.
cons: Unreasonable sales goals that do not adjust with economical changes.  Frequent lay offs and promotions makes it hard to connect with staff.  Managers that do well are promoted to bigger branches leaving the smaller branches with inadequate management.

job_title: Personal Banker II in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great Benefits package
Competitive Pay
Good Hours (If you work in a traditional branch)
Most of the team members are cool
Great for Tellers or someone looking for part time work with job security and benefits
cons:
Unrealistic sales goals
Micromanagers who breathe down your neck constantly hounding you for sales
Too much paperwork and written reporting to management is required
Promises are made to you that you will be promoted if you hit certain (unrealistic) sales numbers then when you hit those numbers you are not promoted. 
They do not take your tenure with the bank or current economic conditions into consideration.
If you're not blowing the unrealistic numbers out of the water then you dont get promoted, and constantly get threatened to be demoted or laid off.

pros:
First word of advice:  don't expect working at a retail branch to be easy.  It's fine for the first 6-12 months; but it's a very highly competitive place to work (in retai) and obviously very sales centered.

Outside of "Retail" there are many fabulous opportunities- but most people start their career in retail- and move on.
cons: Retail- it can be a very shady place to be.  Be prepared for anything.

review_title: It was a nightmare to get loans closed on time.
pros: Great benefits.  World renowned company that has an overall good reputation.  Many, many resources and marketing opportunities.  Lots of different products.
cons: It was a good place to work for me until the Wachovia takeover.  Then, it seemed like the company got so big that the right hand didn't know what the left hand was doing.

job_title: Market Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Time Flexibility is one of the greatest parts of working at wells fargo. There is never a feeling of being burnt out from overwork. Great leadership from those that will mentor you especially with those entry level jobs. Relaxed setting that allows you to do your best work.
cons: At wells Fargo you get very little pay as you promote from within. After a while you get the feeling that you need to leave the company even if you were happy in order to get a better salary.

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Miami, FL
pros: Insurance/ 401k / Benefits/ thats it.
cons:
This place is a horrible place to work for. If you want to be micromanaged to the 2nd power this is the place to go. They have inexperienced banker (tellers)  advising on bank products. Everybody in the branch will try and sell you something you dont need. You have to report every few hours your production even if you have a customer in front of you. There is so much more but i wont have space to complete, just know this place will break you down as a professional and as a person. Management are puppets and robots with unreasonable goals and expectations. I am not disgruntled i was successful, but this banks philosophy is as ridiculous as calling a bank product a solution. Stay away they are loosing people left and right because they are miserable. 
Miami, FL

job_title: Phone Banker II in Westlake, TX
pros: Predictable hours, consistent work, opportunities for advancement throughout far reaching company and subsidiaries, ability to gain experience to work throughout financial industry, formerly more but still employee-centric values. Generous attendance policy. Paid vacation, sick leave are competitive, insurance plans are somewhat expensive for group plan but great benefits. Tuition reimbursement 401k matching.
cons: Extreme micromanagement, high employee turnover rate, mundane work atmosphere, they will hire nearly anyone, high pressure sales atmosphere in customer service, meager bonus payout, relatively low hourly wage compared to similar institutions. 401k consistently losing value.

review_title: Heavy Sales Pressure, No Respect Given
pros: Good benefits, decent pay. Looks good on your resume, and you don't have to be smart to work here, because I've seen Wells Fargo hire some of the dumbest people I have ever met.
cons: Heavy sales pressure, de-humanizing customer service requirements, under-qualified management. Management measures employee success based solely on sales numbers; actual operational and leadership successes are not taken into account when measuring performance.

pros: Pay was competitive for the type of job, co-workers were friendly, client base was steady and so you got to know your customers.
cons: Sales (and even service) goals were set extremely high, which made for a extremely stressful environment due to managers continuing to hound everyone to SELL SELL SELL

review_title: Great company, friendly co-workers, and nice location in Boston.
job_title: Client Service Consultant II in Boston, MA
pros:
Entry level, they pay for licenses series 7 & 63 and give you tools and support to pass the test. They promote internally within a year and managers will help you succeed. 
If you make it and become a Client service consultant 2 the job is great!
401K match, PTO, holidays off, and weekends off.
cons:
Call center environment. Client service consultant 1 may take a lot of calls if short staffed.  Can be frustrating in the beginning dealing with clients, but gets easier as you learn. 
Strict quality call reviews.  2 chances to pass license tests if not your terminated. 
Tough it out a year and move up!

job_title: Loan Document Specialist IV in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I enjoyed working here because of the friendly environment and flexibility when you kept up with your work.
cons: Being in the mortgage industry there are frequent changes to policies and acceptable documentation which does not get communicated quick enough. Management needs to make corrective action to consistent under performers.

review_title: Manager and team members are deceitful
job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The company provides good benefits to its employees. Good place to improve your customer service skills.
cons: The company set high and unrealistic sales expectations reason why some managers and most of bankers meet their goals pushing customers to open unnecessary accounts so that the branch can get more bonuses. But when a customer complaints about an unrequested product, branch act like they don’t know anything about that, and even they fire their employees to cover their back.

review_title: A job that pays the bills
job_title: Phone Banker I in Salem, OR
pros:
-Flexible hours
-Get to put WF on your resume
-Casual dress code
-No physical labor
cons:
-High sales goals
-Rude "not so smart" customers
-Extensive time on the computer (bad for the eyes)
-Salary does not compensate the level of work

pros: -great benefits and great bonuses
cons: it is true what others say , it really depends on the branch , you will get a great bonuses if you work with a branch that cares about the whole team and their goals. The WOW is a team effort and if no one is on-board then you get stuck in a branch where your bonus is dependent of your sales. In the other hand if the sales are there and the customer service is also there, then wow your life is easier. Except for your balancing.

review_title: Home Mortgage division not interest in utilizing talented employees or have a development plan to encourage growth .
pros: Respectable amount of vacation days
cons: Talented individuals are a threat to less talented management team.  Watch out you can be easily stuck in a low paid minimal skill position. Please do not say you are glad to have a job. That is automatic logic. No brainer! Don't cheat yourself. Challenge the inability to have a shot at positions that fits your skill set. Management support is few and far in between. (Wisconsin)

job_title: Regional Bank Private Banker in Portland, OR
pros: Decent benefits, nice 401k match, although every year benefits are decreasing along with the rest of the industry. Good salary and plenty of career paths to choose from. Supports all kinds of diversity, very safe environment. Career training is usually pretty easy to get.
cons: Some deparents are very closed and run by old school bankers. Cronyism is rampant in some areas and as you move up, like most places it becomes about who you know, not always what you do.

job_title: CONSUMER LOAN UNDERWRITER in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Wells Fargo Dealer Services is a great place to work.  My time there was was both a joy and a tremendous opportunity for me to grow my skills in the field of credit analysis. WFDS gave me the resources and support to further my career and the atmosphere was highly conducive to teamwork, innovation and personal growth. All and all a great place to work if you are interested in credit, finance, risk management, portfolio management, contract negotiation, business development and business strategy.
cons: Have to work more weekends than I wanted too and some late nights. Wished the schedule was a little more oriented towards Monday to Friday.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in San Jose, CA
pros: The retail side is for the uneducated that just finished high school so they are easily manipulated and when its time to fire you they'll just get another uneducated low paid worker bee.
cons: The retail sales side of the bank is sketchy there is a lot a gamming allowed mangers turn a blind eye but it catches up to the grunt not the manager. The pay is terrible to the work. Bonuses are minimal

review_title: High pressure managers lead to employee frustration.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Sacramento, CA
pros: Career advancement opportunities if you can tolerate your managers(s).
cons: Daily sales goals seem to be unrealistic.  Having a decade of successful sales experience with a Fortune 100 company prior to Wells Fargo, I was extremely appalled at the lack of structure within the bank, and also how the branch manager talked to and treated employees.  Coming to work each day was interesting because one minute you are a rockstar, and 30 seconds later you're the worst employee ever.  The yoyo of emotion and disrespect is not worth the career.

review_title: Good benefits, toxic culture, zero career advancement
job_title: Sponsor Services Analyst in Roseville, MN
pros:
Solid benefits package with 401(k) match and PS contribution.
Company is very much pro-GLBT.
cons:
Department was poorly managed. People with distinct skill A were forced to also do Tasks B and C...even though there were people who were good at (and preferred to do) Tasks B and C. 
Not receptive to different corporate cultures or methods. My unit was cobbled together from three groups after mergers & acquisitions. Only the legacy Wells group had any actual clout or say over anything.
Promotions are non-existent.
Raises are an insult.

pros: Decent benefits (except coverage went down over the 5 years I worked there). Good amount of vacation days. I had some great managers, but the overall culture is sales, sales, sales. There were good opportunities for a flexible work schedule which was nice.
cons: Everything is SALES driven. The company claims that the customer comes first, but in reality the only thing they want to focus on is getting more and more sales (opening new accounts, credit cards, online banking). Sales goals constantly went up and the expectations were ridiculous, especially for the pay. They pay very little and expect you to be treated badly by customers and pitch sale after sale. Employees are often told they have to stay for "call nights" (staying late to make cold calls to get sales appointments). We also had to stay on Saturdays after business hours in order to get more sales.

review_title: Better pay than most fraud departments.
job_title: Fraud Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Better pay than Chase fraud prevention, little supervision, a lot of independent time investigating fraud queues.  People were friendly and the department was rebuilding when I was there.
cons: Much more poorly organized and supervised than some other fraud departments.  My experience at Chevron was much more about fielding and making calls.  My experience at Chase was very organized, shifting from task to task with managerial oversight.  Perhaps they've improved since, but when I was at Wells we were left alone with interminable queues, slogging away.

pros:
Company invest a lot in resources. If you put the effort and desire, you can learn more than just the duties of a teller. You learn a lot. Company has a culture of always recognizing effort and good moments. You will learn about how to operate a retail branch.

Company promotes from within. If you are successful in this role, they will offer a promotion as a banker or as a lead teller
cons:
Upper management tries to push a customer service script when sometimes isn't the best route.

Some branches are run by management that really pushes tellers to refer customers to bankers.
Expectations are much higher than the industry average. It's a lot tougher in this company relative to another bank
Salary

job_title: Branch Manager III in Union, NJ
pros: Professional environment,  cutting edge technology , excellent business related and industry training
cons: Lack of respect for work life balance, expected to work until 5pm on a Saturday when branch closes at 12 to make customer phone calls, product dumping on unsuspecting customers is expected and praised. Employees not meeting 200 % of ridiculous sales goals are threatened with losing  jobs although corporate goal is 100%. Horrible turnover. Customers are treated with take it or leave it attitude because bankers and managers have no autonomy to make relationship decisions.

pros: Good online resources, very structured escalation processes
cons: Leaders who are completely uninspiring, and often comically lacking in skills, and at odds with the stated values and culture Wells professes. In my region, punitive calls are the norm, public shaming is clearly the strategy of the regional manager, obsessive focus on activities rather than results is the norm. I never in my 25 years in this industry have experienced this kind of toxicity. It isn't directed at me, thankfully, but I still have to witness it constantly, and it makes me need a shower when I get home from work to wash off all the ikky negativity.

pros: The company for sure had their perks. They tried to make their work days fun and really interact with your clients and customers. They gave away their fair share of swag to employees and held regional and location contests.
cons: Wells Fargo is a super hard sales driven company when I was there. You were required to get 6 new accounts open a day. They wanted each customer to have a minimum of 6 accounts as well. Harder to keep up with all the accounts to get more fees I guess.

job_title: Project Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: For me the location was perfect
cons: They claim to strive for a diverse culture, but continually hire the same kinds of people over and over. They claim to strive for a work-life balance, but heaven forbid if you actually try to have a life outside of work. Poor planning and unnecessary fire drill, that lead to endless amounts of redundant work, that never goes anywhere. They tell you, they want you to take advantage of educational opportunities, but don't actually give you the time to do it. You spend days and weeks 12-15 hour days on a project, that someone, somewhere decides isn't worthwhile any longer. Leadership is more of a dictatorship, and the lack of recognition is disappointing. The culture is extremely draining and negative.

pros:
Overall great company:
- Customer Focused 100%
- Not as risky as other banks in terms of trading strategies
- My group at least is tight knit and takes care of each other
- My group again is younger and innovative to a certain extent
cons:
- Large initiatives within departments can be very unorganized at times
- Need better and more focus on feedback reviews
- Empower younger employees that are driven and innovative

job_title: Personal Banker II in Provo, UT
pros: The pay seems to be roughly competitive compared to other financial institutions. Also, you learn a lot about basic banking and personal finance.
cons: The culture can vary pretty significantly depending on who your manager is. The problem is that the hiring strategy isn't really focused on hiring excellent managers, but on promoting top performers - who may or may not be great leaders. Additionally, Wells Fargo does a bad job of allowing an employee to expand their interest or go beyond their very specific tasks. Micro management is a huge issue on the retail banking level.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Beaumont, TX
pros: Since the elimination of sales goals, we can now have a very personal and not high pressure environment that allows us to focus on our customers and to give a genuine experience in making sure that we are delivering on their financial needs. The pay is wonderful and the bonuses are also good. Health benefits, 401K plan, diversity and inclusion, involvement in the community, and  promotion opportunities are just examples of the pros that continue on.
cons: Honestly, I can't think of any real cons. The company looks after us and keeps our best interest at heart.

review_title: Leave your ethics at the door, please
pros: Good benefits. Opportunities for promotion.
cons: You must be flexible and keep and open mind when dealing with ethical issues at Wells Fargo.   It's acceptable to misrepresents facts within this culture, and you are expected to do so if it means that your department may be negatively affected by the truth.   It is a blame, blame, blame culture.  More importance is given to finding a person to blame for mistakes instead of 1) acknowledging that human beings make mistakes, 2) fixing the problem, and 3) implementing changes that improve the overall process.  Problems get covered here, not fixed.  Departments do not work well together.

pros: Dress casual, not micromanaged, flexible with time off,
cons: Barely any training, your work is audit, you get dinged for errors that were not Coworkers always complaining of who doing the most work, personal attacks, like a big war, extremely childish.  Not trained properly  so you have no idea your you don't know your making an error until your audited, then they walk you down the line to get fired due to the errors, always thinking going to loose job but were never trained properly to avoid the errors.

pros: Benefits and PTO for part time or full time employees, managers were flexible, great job while in school. Depending on management, the environment can promote growth within the company. Lucky enough to have managers who cared about me as well as my growth within the company
cons: Will depend on your management, but sometimes sales goals can be unreasonable. Some don't care about your well being on the job and won't take the time to learn why you may be struggling or what help you need. Computers/servers are slow but that can always be fixed, hopefully.

review_title: Great benefits and perks!  Tough environment if you’re not the favored.
pros: Great 401k!  PTO is nice! Growth & Development opportunities left and right!  The culture is wonderful if everyone is on board.
cons: Good bonuses and support to advance career if your manager likes you!  Too much mandated busy work on BM plate!  Difficult to motivate team due to lack of direction!  Too much accountability for what’s not being done right and too little praise for what is being done right. I often feel under appreciated for all the value and skill I bring to the table. Advancement opportunities are highly coveted so hard to get even a pre screen. Hiring/Interview process is horrible.

review_title: If I could change one thing
job_title: Bank Teller in Holly Hill, FL
pros:
Good pay
Too much vacation time
cons:
Management is Lazy
Not about the effort for a promotion, it's more of a buddy system

pros:
- Team member, family like environment. 
- Great pay 
- Benefits for part timers 
- Regular customers were lovely 
- Build finance knowledge
- Ability to move up internally
- Managers cared about professional and personal development.
cons:
- The branch I was at was understaffed so I did not get the training required.  
- Transferring to new branch requires interviewing all over again. 

Seriously no other cons.

pros: Everyone from Management on down is very nice and professional and all employees seem to be treated very well.  Management does seem to go out of its way to make sure everyone is appreciated and told when they are doing a good job on something. Everyone seems to be valued whatever their responsibilities or job title.  In my group, managers are pretty flexible and understanding when it comes to balancing work and family time.  It is a very pleasant work environment with lots of great, very talented people.  I feel very proud to be part of such a great organization.
cons: Have not found any yet.

review_title: It's a job, not a career
pros: The company has a great reputation in the community and a very sustainable way to conduct business.  Hierarchies are flat, and for the most part people are smart and very eager to share experiences and work as a team.  Great sense of community.  Benefits are competitive to generous, work-life balance is not just lip service but taken seriously.
cons: The pay ain't great - the company has a policy to keep pay as low as possible, not many chances for advancement and change.  Large bureaucracy.  Edison NJ location has been rumoured to be closing for many years now, just be aware.

review_title: Great place to work for. Needs some improvement on communication and policy. Be flexible with Telecommute option.
job_title: Senior Database Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Company and team ethics. Lot of PTO. Recognition. Advancement Opportunities.
cons: Overloaded with work. Frequent re-org and uncertainities. Lack of management oversight and support due to re-org. Lack of comminication to teams on policy changes or requirements. Each manager praciticing his/her own understanding of the policies - not standard across organization. Higher expections with fewer resources.

review_title: Bank execs can't see the big picture
job_title: Sales Credit Manager in Boise, ID
pros: The people were very knowledgeable and friendly. My peers were on rge sane team as I was. When we had to meet sales goals, I felt like their was a healthy competitive spirit, yet a feeling of co-operation because we all wanted to succeed. As a result, the company morale was very high and and the employees were respected. The benefits were good as well.
cons: The hours were very rigid and there was a lot of working in the evenings because that is the best time to catch people at home. Therefore, it was difficult to balance family and work.

review_title: sell sell sell... can you say daily excessive pressure?
pros: Brand name recognition and financially sound company. The benefit package is not bad and experience with them is good on the resume
cons: The company does not value education in any way and managers highly promote a used car salesman mentality. The pressure at the branch level is tremendous and you will be constantly asked to bring business from friends and family. Overral, more unhappy employees by far. Have another option available before signing up. Frankly you might really HATE it

review_title: It's a great place to work if you don't mind getting 2% raises.
pros: Great 401k, they match the first 6%. The benefits are pretty generous. You get a fair amount of time off to start and  you get an additional week of Paid Time Off (PTO) after three years of service. My office is in nice building and the equipment in my cubicle is new.
cons: The pay is poor and the annual raises bairly keep up with inflation. Also the cash balance (pension) plan was killed off when Wells merged with Wachovia.

review_title: Good place to learn sales and profiling.
job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Omaha, NE
pros: Great pto, 4 weeks the first year. Match 100% for the first 6% of 401k. If you can learn to sell and profile here it will serve you well in future sales jobs. Pay is good for what I do, unfortunately not a lot of growth potential for your career.
cons: Serious lack of career growth. Very very large sales plan, feel sorry for the Wachovia people when they see our sales plan. Push products on people they might not necessarily want, can be a very pushy sales environment.

job_title: Lead Teller in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Name a student job that offers:
- Professional career
- PTO
- Paid sick days
- Bonus pay
- Competitive pay
- 401k
cons:
Like all jobs, there are always some cons. Here's some for working in my position:
- Some very BAD customer experience
- Holds a risk, since it's financially involved
- Tight schedule offered (it's a bank)

pros: Job is easy to do just requires good memorization skills, there are no weekends of work required however there are some overtime work opportunities
cons: Treat you like robots where every second of your day is mapped out.  Have to meet ridiculous productivity goals. Every time a goal is met they increase the goal on a curve. Often feel like there is inadequate training and you have to learn things on your own (only after failing a quality audit do you realize things that you were never taught)

pros: Company has a lot to offer if you have a strong leadership team that is focused on the company's core values and not just there on bonus incentives.
cons: If you are a former Wachovia employee there are many differences from Wells Fargo business model that is making the transition from Wachovia to Well Fargo very difficult for both customers and employees. Many people are being promoted before they have the experience and commuincation of the transition has been very confusing.

review_title: The squeaky wheel doesn't get the grease, it is replaced.
pros:
-Fun people to work with
-Lots of Paid Time Off
-Quarterly bonuses
-Flexibility (in some locations) to work around school schedules
-6% match on 401(k)
cons:
-After acquisition of Wachovia, changes to accomodate their employees are assinine
-Horrible pay compared to peers
-HIGH stress in a sales heavy environment
-Staff cuts have left branches understaffed even when using their own models
-Fees, fees, fees
-Expensive benefits
-Mid-level managers are kept out of the loop on important changes 
-Promotions are reserved to those who kiss butt and know people, not those who are most qualified

review_title: It has been a nice experience overall.
pros:
benefits
diversity
Most of the people are really nice, and are helpful.
There is also tuition reimbursement which is a great reason to work and study.
cons:
older mgrs don't have people skills.
Promotions are difficult to come by even though you are qualified unless you are lucky to be in a dept that need you really bad.

job_title: Operational Risk Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Starting with the obvious - good compensation, looks good on the resume, good experience, and a variety of opportunities depending on your skillset and interests. In addition, the size of the bank allows you to develop other skills in many cases; having to coordinate different groups with diverse interests helps a great deal down the road.
cons: Upper management not always clear or informative, the usual pitfalls of working in a large corporate environment. Some positions can involve working with established managers you may not like working with.

pros: Exposure to clients, genuine commitment to customer service
cons: Very conservative company culture; definite "clique culture", too much focus on brand protection; lack of opportunity for advancement. review_title: A metrics-driven company who will drive hard for sales

Every day is entirely focused on how many sales you have, how many calls you've made, and what you plan to do to get to 110% of your goals.  Constantly micromanaged by different levels of management on your hourly activities.  Will work extended hours on certain days, have call nights, and be called to work on Saturdays even if scheduled off if the branch doesn't meet it's sales goals for the week.

pros: It is a Job that pays the bill.

There are more bad then good, Youtube has many videos that real people have made that show the aspects of the company, all are negative and true.

review_title: Lousy pay but easy work for SALES

job_title: Consumer Loan Underwriter II in Charlotte, NC

review_title: The company itself is okay, however the branch manager was not really a good manager.

review_title: Pb2/store manager...Horribly micromanaged, ridiculous expectations, poor commission structure for quality sales.

review_title: Great work/life balance for an Investment Bank

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist II in West Des Moines, IA

review_title: With great pay comes even greater responsibility
job_title: Personal Banker I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Regardless of what people say about Wells Fargo, they give their employees a great benefits package = 6% matching 401k, health/vision/dental and whatever else you need. Not to mention the corporate benefits you get such as a discounted phone bill, airlines tickets, etc. Customer service is a MUST, clients love Wells Fargo for its high emphasis on customer service. Pay is pretty good, about 18 or so an hour starting and if you do well you move on up or get a raise. Once in a while the company hosts some awesome event such as free bowling, or exclusive listings on bank-owned real estate so its employees can purchase them. Some managers support you better than others, just hope you have a nice one that doesn't throw a fit when things don't go their way.
cons: Overtime is almost mandatory. If it's call nights, short staff, paperwork or meetings - they don't care about what you have outside of the branch, it's all about SALES SALES SALES. Your needs are secondary. Our goals get raised to seemingly astronomical levels while pushing Code of Ethics on us making it increasingly difficult to meet quotas. Get ready to cross sell secondary or tertiary checking/savings accounts just to meet quota, even if the customer genuinely does not need them or get your ass chewed by your manager if you don't. I've had so many clients come in to close unused/unfunded/useless accounts that was opened for them it isn't even funny. Some of them didn't even understand why they had more than one account. Don't forget about January Jumpstart where they raise goals to even more astronomical levels because you're forced to resort to your friends and family to open accounts with you just to meet goal. (Almost like multi level marketing). Get used to micromanagement because if you're not meeting quota, that gives your manager every right to manage every aspect about how you're doing your job right down to how you organize your desk. Oh and the IT backshop monitors EVERY single click you make at the terminal - managers have almost unlimited access to what you do at your terminal, just to micromanage how you do your job or chew you out for a missed, pre-approved home equity. I don't get how this company stresses sales quality while having the most astronomical goals in the entire industry. Think of it this way - no matter how hard you push us, no matter how hard you try, you can't turn McDonald's into your local burger joint that the neighborhood loves. What I find disturbing is that the stress level is through the roof and the powers that be simply don't care. No wonder even the good bankers quit - it's almost a guarantee that you'd get chewed out for something and after a while you get burned out FAST.

pros: I really enjoyed the people I worked with at Wells Fargo. I thought that management was also very nice and gave a lot of feedback, both positive and negative. cons: It's a large company so most job promotions happen when someone gets fired or leaves. Also after a little while your job can become repetitive and a little mindless.

review_title: Highly competitive environment... at times ruthless.

job_title: Technology Manager IV in San Francisco, CA
pros:

The majority of people I work with take pride in what they do.

Flexability - most postions allow you to work from home often. That is a huge blessing for those of us who have a long commute.
cons:
Our new senior leader in Wholesale stated in his last meeting we are to do what is in Wells Fargo's best interest. Our old leader ALWAYS promoted to do what is best for our customer. BAD

review_title: 3 State/Region Perspective of Wells Fargo, Honest comparison to US BANK
pros:
The biggest Pro in my book:
I love love love Wells Fargo.  That being said I have had times where I have been extreemly unhappy while working for them.  Wells Fargo is a Huge company.  When managers follow the mission statement and values of the bank, all of their employee's really enjoy working at Wells.  For the most part Senior managment follow the values of the bank to the T.  But there are over a quarter million employee's so there are bound to be a few bad apples.  The Pro is, if you findyourself unhappy you can always transfer someonewhere else and you will find that the management is different, the culture is different, the sales pressure is different.  I've worked for Wells Fargo in 3 states which were in 3 different regions.  The banking was the same in each one,  The culture was totally different.  3rd time's the charm, I've found the perfect fit for me.

Benifits:
-6% matching in 401k.  That beats the industry average of 3%.  I haven't found a bank that comes close.
-Health/Dental/other benifits: On par with the best of banks out there.
-Industry high of at least 4 weeks paid vacation 5 weeks for managment

Technology:
-Some of the most upgraded/high tech/user friendly/paperless processes in the industry.  Documents are not kept in old file cabinets, they are scaned and stored online.  Account opening is not done on paper like at US BANK, it is done on the computer with a digital signiture pad.  This is all important because it makes your job easier.

Pay:
It is right on par with the industry.  Look at other Banks on this website, the pay is about the same anywhere you go.

Advancment:
If you are willing to relocate you can move up almost as fast as you want.  Wells fargo on the retail banking side almost exclusivly hires from within.
cons:
Advancement:
if you are not willing to move, you have to get in line and wait.  From what I've seen, the more urban a market the longer you have to wait.

Pay:
Bonus's are based on completing your sales plan.  If you are in the wronge store at the wrong time you won't get a good pay out.
-annual raises are 3-5%

Sales pressure:  Sales pressure varries by state and market.  If you work in Vegas or California the pressure is imense.  Iowa or Alaska and its nothing.  Utah, Colorado, idaho  middle of the road pressure.

review_title: Pleasant place to work except for sales goals.
pros: You can have a set schedule, flexible in days off. Get most holidays off and never had to work overtime.  You get to know the customers and routine.
cons: Too much emphasis on sales goals. You have to sell so many products each day/week to customers and if you don't you get scolded.

review_title: Became too large of an organization
pros: because it is so large, the benefits are good.  They have good outplacement services if you are displaced.
cons: not knowing who to call b/c of the complexity of the organization.   Due to layoffs, the current employees are doing the job of 2 people and are burnt out.   The HR department is horrendous to work with.  First you need to navigate the phone tree.  Then, if you don't get the right department, they put you back in the phone tree.  To get a situation resolved, you get passed around to several people b/c it is too large a group to work with.

review_title: Big bank, works to be personable to employees in a down economy
pros: Broad financial services firm that is fairly agile for its size and complexity of services. Works hard to train employees to be the best at their job.  Gives them encouragement.
cons: Works employees very hard and sets expectations at unrealistic levels often outside the control of the employees.  Employees know that they are part of a large organization and feel disconnected from having a say in their career often times.

review_title: One of the great American brands in the middle of a great change.
pros: Great business model that survived the crisis.  Leading businesses in almost every category.  Benefits are changing but great, with solid matching, profit sharing, bonus if you are eligible and work hard to drive revenue.  People are good to work with.
cons: Significant change in the organization.  People are protective of their turf, and tend not to share, but this is getting better.  Very large and hard to navigate if you are not familiar.

pros: Great teams of very talented people.  Culture of respect and professionalism.
cons: Focus on downsizing employees and expense reduction, leaves little management focus on fostering the talent that they have and inspiring employees to be motivated and engaged.  The result of cuts leaves a huge burden on the employees left, coupled with aggressive accomplishment goals.  After awhile, people get burned out, and sometimes the only way to cope is to become disengaged.  Wells Fargo has amazingly talented people, but they are squandering this resource.

review_title: Overall experience was fair...not too much to say here
pros: Decent work schedule.  Salary is about right for position.
cons: Service Managers who like high education believe that they control everything and they do not have any real management skills that might have been taught in higher education.  Sometimes can be very unprofessional. Relationship between employees and lead tellers, managers, and service managers definitely could use some improving.  I believe that if you have not at least obtained your Bachelors degree, any management level opportunities should be reflected on your relationship with your employees.  If you have a bad repor with a few employees you should not be granted the opportunity to interview.

review_title: Great place to get experience, but not a place for upward mobility & has a dysfunctional work environment.
job_title: Personal Banker I in College Station, TX
pros: Great training program that will introduce you into a sales environment. Health care plans are also great.
cons: The compensation structure is horrible compared to its competition, the environment appeared dysfunctional more times than not, and there is a heavy emphasis on product pushing as opposed to building relationships with your clients to help earn more of their business.

job_title: Vice President in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Large bank with with overall good opportunity for growth in your career.  Very talented people working in the organization throughout. Competitive salaries at higher level positions, employee discounts for banking services, Good place to challenge your skill set
cons: Too many fire drills or last minute assignments routinely, company believes people should work non stop, company talks work life balance but does not follow the model.  Too many emails and conference calls taking you away from doing your primary work

review_title: Quick promotions, if you work hard and network
job_title: Business Specialist in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Quick promotions if you do your job well and network with the right people. This is not the place that you want to work if you are interested in finding a secure job to stay in for years with annual pay increases.
cons: Constantly changing sales goals to make bonuses harder and harder, with less pay, each quarter. Salaries low compared to other banks.

review_title: High pressure sales with little customer service concern.
job_title: Personal Banker in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Tuition reimbursement is a good perk if you work at least 17 hours a week.  Also they had great health insurance while I was there.
cons: High pressure sales.  It's never good enough for them.  I was top in the district in sales for 4 years and it still was never good enough.

review_title: Wells Fargo has not only helped me grow professionally but also in my community.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Santa Ana, CA
pros: Wells Fargo has a lot of opportunities to grow internally, i love that they always try to keep us updated with current business news with online classes. My work environment is very family-like. Having a bonus to look forward to every 3 months is always a plus, keeps you motivated.
cons: It can be very stressful to have a sales position, you could have had an amazing day yesterday but that doesn't matter today.

review_title: Great company ethics line is a very hotline in this company in a good way !
job_title: Personal Banker I in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great opportunity to grow very fast. Customers have to be WOW by the exceptional customer service . Stable company . Great work environment to work and grow with the company . Very easy to get your foot in the door if you exceed their exceptions ! Well recommended company !
cons: I have nothing bad to say about this company very well rounded company

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Alexandria, VA
pros: Start off salary for non banking experience history is a a pro! start you off at $18 and some change!
cons:
So many...
advancement opportunities are very very little... 
they stress you out to much to reach your goals....which are impossible depending where your branch is located...
if you don't reach daily goals you stay for call nights which is an hour or two after your shift is up.... which i honestly like to call "Detention"

review_title: Awful experience my manager must of been on prosaic or Lithium.
job_title: Mortgage Collections in San Antonio, TX
pros: The employees and how we facilitate to motivate each other,
cons: If management likes you then your fine if not looked to be fired, Management is tight and covers each other backs even at the expense of the workers, Management has asked fellow coworker to work out the profitability of FMLA personnel to see which they were going to axed. Wells Fargo turn over rational in my class since there is three left out of twenty two, They say care and there for the people don't believe a word of it.

review_title: Wells Fargo is very quick to lay everybody off.
pros: They are a big bank, It takes a while for anything to change. There are a lot of people and most of them have good experience, not necessarily at what they are doing, but they seem to have a lot of old timer that are like fixtures, permanently in place just doing busy work.
cons: Most of the people have little experience doing what they do, in management, they are mostly just fiends and relatives receive special treatment, It is almost like they create jobs for these administrative type of employees.

review_title: Excellent place to work if you're good at sales!
pros: Excellent bonuses. You cap out at $600 in Sales and up to $600 for Customer Service per quarter (every three months). It's really easy to move up and get raises as long as you're consecutive with sales. Recognition events are a blast as well!
cons: The sales can be hard to get and it also depends on your location. If you don't meet your sales goals you can get written up and/or fired.

review_title: Experience overall not to bad.  They love when your sales are high, but when sales are slow, they add pressure.
pros:
Great company
Great hands on experience
Good benefitsh
cons:
Heavy micromanagement
Heavy sales pressure
Feel like a product pusher

review_title: Too many up's and down's of change for such a profitable company.
job_title: Human Resources Consultant in Dallas, TX
pros: Opportunities to advance with good performance.
cons: Commission changed dramatically for all positions over time resulting in overall pay going down. Overtime is very rare which hurts pay when commission is rare or for some people non-existent in areas where it is no longer given. Workload and expectations are too high for one person. If main focus is benefitting customers/clients then you need sufficient manpower to handle the load versus having one person do the work of 2-3.

pros: Flexible hours and had an excellent atmosphere. Friendly work environment and awesome cafeteria with great healthy foods as well. Management very friendly and direct to the point and accommodating when you needed their help.
cons: Honestly there is nothing I could find really negative. If anything maybe when you do apply for a position the process is a bit long and drawn out.

pros: Paid time off, stable company.  The only reason I i give this position two stars is the benefits and 401k plan after a year.
cons:
This job is the most stressful job I have never had, only reason i am here is hoping to get promoted to a different position as I can start applying for other positions soon,
Stay away from Collections at Wells Fargo Home Mortgage.  The training is nice but as soon as everyone hits the phones, they depart.  Calls back to back non stop with this new dialer system.
BEWARE!!

pros: Overall I found the bank to have a positive work environment.  Many employees have been at the company for a long time, which is a sign of employee satisfaction.  Employees appear to have considerable flexibility for transferring to other sites across the country.
cons: Internal technology and tools not most state of the art.  Corporate filters don't allow social media access, even those these sites have work-related value at times.  At the teller level, employees are not paid very well.

review_title: Branch Personal Banker amongst other positions
pros: Team building was great, great training program, creating awesome customer relationships and always worked full time hours when I was hired as a part time employee.
cons: If you are not a sales producer than you have no chance here, upper management views you as as number and bonuses and hourly pay should be much more for dealing with lots of products and finances that are serviced.

pros: Ethical company with an abundance of opportunities.  If you are lucky to enough to have a great manager that supports you in your career endeavors you will go far.
cons:
Middle management is heavy and often times unnecessary.  
There is a reoccurring theme of promoting people to managers when they really should never be in a management role.  Just b/c someone is good at their job it doesn't mean that they will be good at managing others.

pros: The people you meet are unforgettable and the bonds you form with co workers are real friendships and you dont feel like your at work. We are able to have fun and really be ourselves at work.
cons: Contrary to what you may think, Wells Fargo is a company that doesn't have alot of opportunities for growth. The pay is very low for a multi-billion dollar company and there are alot of lawsuits against the company for lack of ethics within the employees and customers.

job_title: Service Manager II in Provo, UT
pros: Training: you will get some of the best training on the market. You learn things that really make a difference in all interactions with people.
cons: Management: That training can be taken in many ways and is often taken in a way that you must offer products that aren't always necessary. Management twists things to get employees to do things that are sometimes unethical. But the company is SET UP to be EXTREMELY ethical.

job_title: Branch Manager III in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Lots of opportunity to grow within the company can be anywhere from starting and ending at management. Management extremely helpful with one on one coaching and development of employees able to attend school while working very flexible schedules will provide benefit for tuition reimbursement as well Great starting company to establish a career with. Have been working for them for 10 years. Just left for maternity leave defiantly will go back
cons: Stressful environment upper management drills management to drill employees it's like a chain in command overall. The pros overruled the cons you must be able to work in a stressful environment give up holidays and weekends and enjoy long hours

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Diversity, competitive, the brand sells it's self so as long as your not an idiot you can survive in the numbers game. Benefits, good insurance, most staff are great people. Fun to work and play with. Alan Bigdelou for president!
cons: Management is not dependable. Constantly losing or moving manager so it's extremely difficult to follow a career plan. Promises are made then the next manager had his /her own way of doing things so you start all over. I started over 4 times in 6 months. I was only promoted 3 times in 5 years but I was promised 6

job_title: Senior Personal Banker in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, pay and career path. Possibilities are endless as WFC is pretty much across the country, and contrary to popular believes, the corporate culture at WF is great.
cons: As you probably have heard WF used to have very aggressive sales goals. Now that they are under new management, they probably will change their way of doing things, but that may take a while and create a sense of instability if you join the company now.

pros: Great training, I liked the people i worked with.  "Selling" checking accounts and credit cards honestly is challenging but somewhat rewarding.  Customer interactions are nice for the most part.
cons: Despite how the "professional" environment and the fact that you are dealing with great amounts of money,  it is just a retail store.  Nothing to aspire to.  I feel bad for the people who want to make a career at a WF retail branch.  Some of the verbiage we are required to say to customers is puke worthy.  For example "Is there anything I can do to make sure you are 100 percent satisfied with WF?"

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: There are a lot of smart people working there.  They provide a lot of training.
cons: There are many different groups scrutinizing your work and they frequently have different priorities.  This is not uncommon in banks but it was particularly acute at Wells.  There is a great deal of talk about the strength of the company culture but they treat their employees worse than any other place I've worked during my 20+ year career.  Their metrics are arbitrary and punitive in my opinion.

job_title: Personal Banker in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: They reimburse you for your degrees if they are business or finance related which is awesome. They offer full benefits and have decent pay. I would definitely recommend people to banking that are comfortable with long hours indoors in an office setting.
cons: You have to fight for a pay that youre comfortable with, the corporate structure doesnt have enough wiggle room, theres a lot of room to move up until store management and then it becomes very difficult to move up. Tellers will be a thing of the past at all banks in another ten years.

pros: The company has made a lot of changes since all of the negative press has hit the news. It is a lot better working here, no sales pressure.
cons: the transition from the old wells fargo to the new wells fargo has been difficult for most of the middle managers I have interacted with. Some of the changes to the bonus structure have not been clear and resulted in confusion. A lot of clients have lost trust in the company so we have seen a huge drop in clientele.

job_title: Wealth Planning Strategist in Tampa, FL
pros: In the Private Bank, culture is very customer focused with hard work and employees are rewarded for doing the right thing.  Lots of opportunity if you work hard, work well within a team.  Most teammates are helpful and leadership genuinely cares about employees.
cons: Don't always hire to fit the culture resulting in dysfunctional group dynamics and long periods to get new teammates to follow the model when they have no interest in doing so.

pros: After working with a very disorganized company, I got a job as a bank teller at Wells Fargo and really appreciated the organization and clear expectations set for employees. Now that sales goals have gone away or at least decreased, I wouldn't hesitate to work at Wells again because I appreciate the value and respect they give to their costumers and I liked being a part of that. The pay was good.
cons: When I worked there, we had some big sales goals that I struggled to reach. Now that the company has done away with that for the main part, I think it would be a perfect place to work.

pros: Great company morals,  Great opportunity to grow advance or move around.   Good L&D departments to help personal development.   The new focus on Customer Experience over sales goals leads to an overall positive work environment.    Benefits are above average for most companies
cons: Large scale Businesses such as these do tend to lose focus a bit.   From customer service.    Due to over communication.

review_title: please donot join as contractor/skill center / cache recruit
pros:
Process oriented
Gender biased
Good hikes
Transportation
Meeting rooms
cons:
you need to work in the shifts according to the assigned project. skill center /cache concept is not good for an employee. The managers are allocating people very randomly without even properly seeing their skill set . If you don't get any project they will throw u in some proj which has shifts.

pros:
Benefits

The people are mostly wonderful
