Terrible Human Resources Dept. They only work to cover the company and care very little for the employees. More concerned about their reputational risk than finding out what's truly going on interdepartmentally.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer Centralized Sales in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Used to be great company, before all the corporate greed at the upper levels kicked in and the corruption and complete trickle down b.s. started
cons: Two-faced management - they say one thing but do another. They always tell  the sales people to do everything you can to make the customer happy, and then tie your hands behind your back which then upsets the clients - but you are the one who takes the brunt of the rage over the phone. That and a constantly changing comp plan to frustrate the sales people and make the managers p&l statement look good, so they can get their bonus!

review_title: Great Benefits | Environment Can Be Difficult
job_title: Personal Banker in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits such as sixteen week parental leave, 401-K match, team member discounts on certain products and HSA contributions.
cons: The bonus structure has changed significantly, but is still at times frustrating. Negative customer surveys impact the bonuses more than the positive ones and there is no transparency on how that works exactly. It can be difficult to advance depending on the district you're in and management. The pay can be great, but isn't as competitive as other financial service companies with positions doing less work.

review_title: Company Will Screw You Over QUICKLY
job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist in Homewood, AL
pros: Raises every 6 months, paid time off, 401K, lots of overtime if wanted
cons:
They will screw over an ENTIRE department in a heartbeat to save another city so they don't look bad.  Ask ANY former Birmingham employee about how 750 employees were laid off to save Charlotte, we were doing our job & getting things done & Charlotte has messed it up. 

The IC's have NO CLUE what the LSS job really does & will mess up a position by adding senseless things that are not investor required.

Insurance with United Health is terrible

review_title: Stable company with decent benefits.  Senior Management is terrible.
job_title: Marketing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Exempt employees receive 25 paid days off per year right from the hiring date.  The 410K gives a 100% match.
cons: The management team is very political and much more interested in covering their a** than in actually doing what is right for the company.  It's very hard to get anything done due to all the politics.  Every manager has their own agenda.  If something needs to get done that conflicts with that agenda, it will be made very hard to accomplish.

review_title: Financial office has young staff with high energy, which proves for great support
pros: It seems that there are great opportunities for advancement. Also, the staff seems to be much younger in the financial office, which shows that most people who are there for a while move up. The energy is really good and there is a great support team.
cons: High demands of work, which sometimes seem impossible.

review_title: Typical corporate culture focused on shareholders
pros: The recent successes and merge with Wachovia has earned the star performers at Wells Fargo opportunities to build their resumes.  The management team is keen to recognize the increased work loads brought on by the merger through gift cards and other shows of appreciation.
cons: The focus on profits and shareholder value overshadows the company's value in its staff.  Shows of appreciation can seem shallow when they are not accompanied by attempts to better distribute the workload.

review_title: The bank use to be WACHOVIA which payed about $12-14 but Wells Fargo starts everyone off with 10.50 experienced or NOT!
pros: My branch in Washington DC wasnt very busy.. Very professional work environment and it was a 9-5 so it allowed me to go to school and have a LIFE.. also AMAZING benefits & great coworkers..
cons: LOW pay compared to other banks.. I made 14.25 at CitiBank.. 12.22 at Bank of America.. & 13.50 at Capita One as a teller but Wells Fargo only starts you off with 10.50 EXPERIENCED OR NOT .. unless you are bilingual the pay is 11.50... This is in Washington DC/Maryland in year 2011

review_title: Not bad for a large corporation
pros: The company cares about customers and employees.  Benefits are above average and pay is competitive.  You can feel appreciated here.
cons: Management is very hierarchical, can be slow moving and sometimes clueless.  Each line of business has a slightly different culture. While the company professes to be employee and customer  focused, at the end of the day the bottom line $$s win.  Like any large corporation they are cutting benefits and scaling back FTE where ever they can. Most employees work LONG hours.

pros: Higher pay when you come from outside the banking world, health insurance, 401k plan. The quarterly bonuses for sales and service. The weekly schedule mostly is around 8:15a - 5:15pm, some days you get to leave earlier. Three weeks paid vacation (18 days) when you first start out.
cons: All about sales, sometimes compromising the customer service aspect. It is hard when you just get in and new to everything, but you get a hang of it and you see how the system works.

pros:
-Great brand recognition
-Peers were all great
-Great place to start your career and gain experience in a professional setting.
-Base pay was good compared to other retail banks
cons:
-little to no upward mobility in the Retail Branches
-Management shoves the career trajectory down your throat
-Incentive compensation is impossible to reach consistently in most branches
-Management will make empty promises regularly
-Sales culture expects you to regularly force unnecessary products down consumers throats...three checking accounts per person and a few savings accounts paying nothing is the norm.
-Constantly changing incentives goals and standards to make it as elusive as possible.

review_title: Great Benefits, Definitely a sales job.
pros: Good selection of people to work with, Good benefits package, Free accounts and discounts on their products and services, and Steady salary.
cons: A ton of sales pressure, Very strict policies pertaining to meeting goals. Company seems to "punish" some of it's employees when goals are not met. Specifically forcing managers to work six days a week, and attending early morning and late evening meeting when service scores or sales goals are not met. In order for service scores to be met, employees must receive a 5 out of 5 in all categories of the surveys done by Gallup. If only one is a 4, must go to meeting.

pros: Decent 401k match. That's it.
cons:
Turnover, 3 managers in 2 years.
Angry customers, all the time. Hard to sell to people that hate the company. 
Sales goals very unrealistic. Managers actually encourage gaming, just don't get caught, they won't back you up.
Work / life balance a joke. Branches open til 6, and if the branch goals aren't met, stay and call for solutions, sometimes til 8 pm. 
If you have kids, forget it. You will be discriminated! WF prefers young people with no kids, so they can pay next to nothing and work you overtime with no OT pay.
Upper and middle management very dishonest. 
Very low morale, EVERY employee I know is looking for another job!

review_title: Just a horrible place to work!
job_title: CONSUMER LOAN UNDERWRITER in Chester, PA
pros: Good money and benefits. High paying job.
cons: I've been here 3 years. High management and employee turnover. Deceitful managers who don't know what they are doing. Managers are only pipeline pushers. Highly stressful. The more you do the more the take. They want blood or something! Liars. Everyone drops the ball and pushes it off on you. HR department is worthless! They don't know which end is up. You have no life. They want all your time. Including nights and weekends. Once they get it, they turn their back on you!

job_title: Phone Banker I in Boise, ID
pros: Met some nice people. PTO
cons: If you want constant pressure to achieve unattainable sales and metric goals than this job is for you!  Pushing products and services that customers dont't need all day every day with scripts that will make you loose your mind. Boring job!!!  I felt sick every time I left the house to go to work. Coaching on a daily basis.  Mind numbing work and the employee turnover is off the charts.  Only 2 people left from my class and they'll probably be gone if they don't meet the sales requirements.  They don't care if your good at customer service, sales are the only thing they want. Customers be damned.  Always a couple of training class happening every month.  If they didn't they wouldn't have anyone manning the phones.

pros: Benefits, culturally competent environment, 12 days of PTO for the first year, clean office environment, opportunities to transfer to different branches
cons: Achievement is merely based on the 5 star system, nothing else matters but getting 5 stars, not the extra hours you put in to work, not being a team player, not going above and beyond for a customer. If you have a week full of 5's and the a 4 on the next, that will put a damper on anything you've achieved thus far since you can get written up and eventually fired for anything less than a 5. Very bureaucratic and top down.

pros: Wells Fargo brand is positive. Wells Insurance struggles with what they want to be when they grow up. Cost cutting their way to an NOI that satisfies the bank has run it's course. They either need to make a major acquisition or sell the commercial brokerage part.
cons: Cost cutting and being owned by a publically traded conservative giant who barely recognizes the insurance operations beyond feel good buzz words. Good 401K, typical benefits plans ( high deductible options mostly ), decent pay scales....spread really thin from a talent perspective.

review_title: Tough but rewarding- definitely a company for go-getters.
pros: If you are into sales and are motivated to climb the corporate ladder this is the place for you. While customer service is important sales is the number one focus.
cons: Sometimes the sales goals can be overreaching and a bit unrealistic. Even tellers are expected to sell at a high level despite the fact that it's labeled a customer service job and managers are always on top of you.

review_title: Great company to work for, but sadly lower-level managers can make it more difficult than it needs to be.
pros: Benefits. Advancement. Clear expectations. Pay. There's always something to learn and add to your job portfolio. Don't wait for opportunities; like every other professional environment, you should be the one to initiate your advancement.
cons: The branch you work at truly defines your experience. Sales pressure is simply a part of the job, but it depends on your branch manager whether it becomes overwhelming.

pros: large benefit package ( very costly though), probably never have a run on their funds.
cons: Management is clueless, upper management only cares about their bonuses, and they foster backstabbing, lying  and forcing products customers don't want on them all while pressuring employees to meet unobtainable bonus goals ( but all management treats these "bonus goals" as the bottom line, meet them or get fired. Ethical behavior is frowned upon, upper management employees have no ethics, but lower level employees are expected to meet ridiculous numbers while maintaining a much higher level of ethics than anyone else.

review_title: good benefits are the only thing they have going for them
job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Baltimore, MD
pros: Wells Fargo has a really good benefits package. When I was employed there, they matched fully up to 6% for 401k contributions.
cons: Work-life balance is really non-existent. Store Managers get demeaned by District Managers on a daily basis. Bankers have to make at least 20-50 dials daily if they do not have two or more checking account appointments daily. Promotions are a very gray area - they do not have a standard that they follow to measure and stack their employees up to each other. The managers have a tendency to favor some employees and promote them over others.

review_title: All about product pushing for sales...
pros: Some growth potential, relocation flexibility, decent benefits. Plenty of training so you're not thrown to the wolves if you're new to the industry.
cons: Wells Fargo has the highest sales goal requirements of any other bank & they increase every year & sometimes quarterly. It's all about the numbers & while they claim to care about employees, in the end everyone is just a number or a stepping stone to the next dollar.

pros: Working at Wells Fargo is better than being unemployed.  Wells Fargo offers 401 k matching and health care benefits.
cons: The sales pressure at Wells Fargo is overwhelming at times.  There are a number of branch employees who will turn to unethical practices in order to get management to stop the sales harassment.  Once employees turn to unethical practices, they are often promoted for their success. Obviously not every good sales person at Wells Fargo is unethical, however at the branch level, the people who are often the top performers have friends with 50+ closed accounts, open accounts with fake SSN's, no ID, order credit cards for people who did not agree to have one, close debit cards and open replacements, etc.

pros:
Decent pay
Free checking and savings account
cons:
Rude customers (might depend on location but this one had the worse)
Sales goals - if you fall short, you get written up which can lead to begin firing even if you are great in all other areas of customer service
Survey scores are hit or miss. If a customer doesn't give you all 5's on a survey it is considered a zero and you are written up after your second "bad" survey
Long hours, and sometimes have to stay up to an hour and a half after closing

review_title: A Place to Work if You Don't Want to Work Hard and Don't Want to Get Fired
job_title: Senior Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Collaborative culture
- In general, culture of respect
- Opportunities for cross-organizational transfers and career moves
- Offices all over the US with a lot of flexibility for working remotely (e.g., from home) in many locations and/or after having proven yourself.
- For the most part, an excellent executive leadership team - especially the top dozen or so leaders in the organization.  One level below that, the quality of the leaders declines.
- A really strong business with strong retail, mortgage and commercial banking customer base that will make $ billions for years to come, regardless of Wells Fargo's strategy or what anyone working actually does
- For those who don't want to work very hard, there is quite a bit of "fat" in the organization, so you can have a position without working very hard, and you probably can get away with it for years (if not an entire career)
cons:
- For those who do want to work hard, it can be stifling to work with people who don't want to work hard (see last bullet under "Pros") - especially when those individuals are part of executive management (and there are plenty of those)
- Wells Fargo is very bad about purging bad senior leaders.  Once leaders have gotten to a certain level, Wells Fargo sticks by them, and entire segments of Wells suffer under very poor leadership
- A lot of fat.  A lot of "that's not my job."  A lot of provincial, very "inside the box" thinkers.  Not the place for someone who is smart and motivated to accelerate a career.  There are 280,000 employees, and very few of them, even if excellent, will rise to the top.
- To be promoted, you have to be willing to let a lot slide and "go with the flow."  Agreeableness is promoted.  Anyone who rocks the boat is not.  Anyone who is critical of Wells Fargo team members who are ineffective - will be blacklisted as "aggressive"
- Much more likely to (get blacklisted) and get fired for raising your hand to alert management about problems; much more likely to be promoted for sweeping problems under the rug and saying everything is great
- Takes a very long time to get anything done
- Endless meetings with large numbers of participants where nothing substantial is decided
- Very little accountability  - especially for senior management

review_title: Working with the world's most valuable bank
pros: Wells Fargo is an incredibly diverse company, and this is evident from day 1. Aside from the culture and vision of the company, employees have great opportunities to advance internally. Assert yourself and work hard, and you'll see the fruits of your labor.
cons: The downside is really just how adamant they are about sales. It really is the lifeline of the company, and if you don't show skill in this area, be prepared to be overlooked.

review_title: Be ready to sell your soul!
job_title: Phone Banker II in Roanoke, VA
pros: A lot of benefits, paid time off, the ability to make up time you might of missed due to unseen circumstances, decent pay. The company is very flexible and willing to work with you concerning a LOT of things, almost unlimited overtime if you get it approved.
cons:
Pay is not enough for what you have to deal with on a regular basis. Abuse from customers and constant 'check ins' from your supervisor asking why you aren't meeting set goals. They ask you to sell products at an insane rate but then restrict you down to to only a few things you can reliably bring up to a customer and get them interested. When you're meeting or exceeding set goals it's like you're forgotten but don't let your numbers slip or half the floor worth of managers will be on top of you for a 1% below goal sell rate.or 5 seconds over talk time. Cliques are rampant and you will see bankers off the phone relaxing with managers talking about whatever and looking at videos of nothing related to work on computers. The tips and help they try to give you during the day to keep your numbers up is the same recycled garbage they spit out everyday and when you show them that their tip isn't working they avoid the situation, gloss completely over it and just bring up their tip again, or tell you to try harder. The people that call in with legitimate hardships are pushed aside and their pleas for fee reversals go completely unheard, but the customers with hefty balances can treat you like complete garbage and get hundreds in fees back just because they have money. So much for a being a company that cares.

You can't leave your specific ling of business even if you qualify for a different job until you've worked the same position for 1-2 years, good luck trying to branch out and learn more skill sets, it won't happen until so much of your soul is sucked out selling selling selling that by your 2 year anniversary, you're just a shell. They tell you there's job advancement, but what they mean is you can come in and work overtime to do the managers job of pestering everyone about their numbers.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great company! Despite everything that is in the news!!

review_title: An American company with American values
pros:
- job security
- compassionate mid-level and upper-level management
- pays up to 9% into an RRSP/NRSP (3% default, 6% matched)
- good insurance package
- free coffee
- new offices in some locations
- company appears to love diversity & equal opportunity
- lots of competent, talented people
cons:
- catty Mean Girls/frat boy atmosphere depending on the team you're in
- some silent acceptance of racist comments from certain individuals; company as a whole, however, does not espouse this kind of philosophy
- unspoken pact among team members that you work over the allotted 7.5 hours/day (or else they will complain)
- subtle encouragement to eat at your desk & work through lunch
- many rude entry-level workers and self-serving middle managers
- many cuts recently due to transition from GE to Wells Fargo
- projects take forever to get executed because there will be 700 calls about them, which makes work very unrewarding sometimes
- basically nonexistent work-life balance, expected to be at the office at all times unless you're in sales, in which case you're expected to be on the road at all times - double standard on policies about working from home
- limited vacation windows; you'll never be able to take holiday during Christmas/New Year's or during any other end-of-quarter month
- virtually no training. Learning is done almost entirely through trial and error
- limited communication and harmonization between and among teams; one question will solicit 6 different answers from 6 different people
- no sense from upper-mid-management about deadlines for projects and sideline administrative tasks; all work seems to come due end-of-year when everyone is already exhausted with normal work & holiday preparations. Work always ebbs and flows and is never constant; in the down periods you are expected to twiddle your thumbs & stare at your email inbox

job_title: Senior Content Strategist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- My immediate team is great. Some typical dysfunction, but for the most part, 5 stars for my team.
- Work/life balance is excellent - laptops are closed by 5pm at the latest (only rarely are there extraordinary needs that require after hours work)
- Incredibly diverse team, lots of women in leadership roles (at our level, anyway, not so much 'upstairs')
cons:
- Upper management is still resistant to approving full-time Work From Home, even with Covid-19 and a CEO who is remote from NY. Some folks are not being approved for FT WFH, even for jobs that have been done remotely for years now. 
- Conflict-avoidant culture... As reported in the press, serious problems and bad behavior still not directly addressed and allowed to go on for too long.
- Old, institutionalized, dinosaur mentality (mostly 'upstairs') and fear of change. Lots of old white guys in charge, so... yeah.
- Under-performers and folks who just won't do their jobs can easily hide, the org is so large. And because conflict avoidant, these problem folks are never dealt with.
- Salaries are below market for design jobs. Raises don't keep up with inflation.
- The process to get any little thing done is arduous and time intensive. There are so many groups and systems involved, it's redonkulous.
